In partnership with the Canterbury Tales Project, at that time led by Norman Blake in partnership with Peter Robinson and Elizabeth Solopova (up to 1998), and using images and other resources supplied by the Project, the Sheffield team transcribed eight manuscripts in full (Ad3, Corpus, Dd, Gg, Ellesmere, Ha4, Hengwrt, Lansdowne), sections of some seven other manuscripts, and all manuscripts of the Franklin's Tale. No part of these transcripts is contained in this iteration of the Project.

div.l: There as this lord was keper of the selle
The rule of seint Maure or of seint Beneit
Be cause it was olde and somdel streite
This ilke Monke let olde thinges pace
And helde aftir the newe world the space
He yaf nat of the text a pulled hen
That seith hunters beth nouȝt holy men
Ne that a Monke whan he is reccheles
Is likned to a fisshe that is waterles
That is to sein a monke withouten his cloistre
But thilke nat text helde he nat worth an oistre
And I said his opinioıı̄un was gode
What shuld he studie and make him self wode
Vpon a book in cloistre alwey to poore
Or swinken with his hondes or laboure
As Austyn bit hou shal the worlde be serued
Lat Austyn haue his swynke to him reserued
Therfor he was a prikesour ariȝt
Greyhoundes he had as swift as foule in fliȝt
Of priking ⁊and of huntyng for the hare
Was all his lust for no cost wolde he spare
I sy his sleues I purfiled at the hond
With grys ⁊and that the fynest of a lond
And for to fastene his hood vnder his chynne
He had of gold I wrouȝt a full curious pynne
A loue knotte in the gretter ende ther was
His heed was balled that shone as any glas
And eke his face and he had ben anoynt
He was lord full fatte and in gode poynt
His eyen stepe and rollyng in his hede
That stemed as a forneys of a lede
His bootes souple his hors in gret estat
Now certainly he was a faire prelat
He nas nat pale as a forpyned goost
A fatte swan loued he best of any roost
His Palfrey was as broun as any berye
A Frere ther was awantoun ⁊and a merye
A lymitoᵘur a full solempne man
In alle the ordres iiij is non that can
So mekill of daliaunce and faire langage
He had made full many a mariage
To yong wommen at his owne coste
Vnto his ordre he was a noble poste
Full wel be loued and famulier was he
With frankeleynes ouer all in his contre
And with worthi wommen of the toun
For he had power of confessioıı̄un
And said him self more than a curat
And of his ordre he was licenciat
Full swetely herd he confessioıı̄un
And plesaunt was his absolucioıı̄un
He was an esy man to yeue penᵃnce
Ther as he wist to haue a gode pitaunce
For vnto a pore ordre for to yeue
Is signe that a man is wel I shryue
For if he yaf he dorst wel make avaunt
He wist that a man was repentᵃunt
For many a man so hard is of his herte
He may not wepe al thouȝ him sore smerte
Therfor in stede of weping ⁊and praiers
Men mote yeue siluer to the poore freres
His typet was ay farced full of knyues
And pynnes for to yeue faire wyues
And certeinly he had a mery note
Wel coude he syngen and pleyen on a rote
Of yeddinges he bar vtterly the prys
His necke white was as the flour delys
Therto as strong was as a champioıı̄un
He knewe wel the tauernes in euery toun
And eueri hostiller and eueri tapstere
Bet than a lazer or a begstere
For vnto such a worthi man as he
Accordes nouȝt as by his faculte
To haue with such lazers aqueyntaunce
It is nat honest it may not auaunce
For to delen with such poraile
But all with riche and sellers of vitaile
And ouer all there as profiȝt shuld arise
Curteys he was and louly of seruice
Ther nas no man nowher so vertuous
He was the beste begger in his hous
For thouȝ a widewe had nouȝt a shoo
So plesaunt was his In principio
Yet wolde he haue a ferthing or he went
His purchace was wel better than his rent
And rage he couthe as it were riȝt a whelp
In louedayes there coude he moche helpe .
For ther he was not like as cloisterer
With a threde bare cope as is a pore scoler
But he was like a maister or a pope
Of double worsted was his semy cope
That rounded as a belle out of the presse
Somwhat he lipsed for his wantounesse
To make his englissh swete vpon his tonge
And in his harping whan that he had songe
His eyen twinkeled in his heed ariȝt
As don the sterres in the frosty niȝt
This worthi lymitoᵘur was I cleped Huberd
¶ A marchᵃunt was there with a forked berd
In motle and hiȝe vpon his hors he sat
Vpon his heed a flaundrissh beuer hat
His bootes clapsid faire and fetisly
His resons he spak full solemply
Sownyng alwey the encres of his wynnyng
He wold the see were kept for any thing
Betwix Middelbourgh and Orewelle
Wel coude he in eschaunge sheldes selle
This worthi man ful wel his wit besette
Ther wist no wiȝt that he was in dette
So estatly was he of his gouernᵃnce
With his bargeynes and with his cheuesshaunce
Forsothe he was a worthi man with all
But soth to seyn I not hou men him call
¶ A clerk ther was of Oxenford also
That vnto logik had long I go
And lene was his hors as is a rake
And he nas riȝt fat I vndertake
But loked holwe and therto soberly
Ful thredebar was his ouerest curtepy
For he had goten him no benefice
Ne was so worldly for to haue office
For him was leuer haue at his beddes hede
Twenty bokes I clad in blak and rede
Of Aristotle and his Philosophie
Then robes riche or fithel or gay sawtrye
But al be that he was a philosophre
Yet had he but litill gold in cofre
But al that he miȝt of his frendes hente
On bokes and on lernyng he it spente
And besily gan for the soules preye
Of hem that wherwith yaf him to scoleye
Of studie toke he most cure ⁊and moost hede
Nouȝt a worde spak he more than was nede
And that was seide in forme ⁊and reuerence
And short ⁊and quyk and full of high sentence
Sownyng in a moral vertu was his speche
And gladly wold he lerne and gladly wold he teche
A sergeaunt of the lawe war and wise
That often had ben at Parys
Ther was also full riche of excellence
Discret he was and of gret reuerence
He semed such his wordes weren so wyse
Iustice he was full often in assise
By patent and by plein cōmmissioıı̄un
For his science and his hiȝe renoun
Of fees and robes had he many oon
So gret a purchasour was nowher non
All was fee sympill to him in effect
His purchasing miȝt nouȝt be infect
Nowher so besy a man ther nas
And yet he semed besier than he was
In termes had he caas and domes alle
That from the tyme of kyng william were falle
Therto he coude endite and make a thing
Ther coude no wiȝt pynche at his writing
And eueri statute coude he pleyn by rote
He rode but homely in a medle cote
Gyrt with a ceynt of silke with barres smale
Of his array telle I no lenger tale .
A Frankeleyn was ther in his company
White was his berd as is the daysie
Of his complexioıı̄un he was sangueyn
Wel loued he by the morwe a soppe in wyn
To lyuen in delite was euer his wone
For he was Epicurus owne sone
That helde opinioıı̄un that pleyn delite
Was verry felicite parfiȝt
An housholder and that a gret was he
Seynt Iulian he was in his contre
His brede his Ale was alweies after oon
A better envyned man was neuer non
Withoute bake mete was neuer his hous
Of fissh and flessh and that was so plenteuous
It snewed in his hous of mete and drynke
Of alle deyntees that men coude thinke
Aftir the sondry sesons of the yere
So chaunged he his mete and his sopere
Ful many a fat pertrich had he in mewe
And many a breem ⁊and many a luce in stewe
Woo was his Cook but if his sauce were
Poynaunt and sharp and redy all his gere
His table dormaunt in his halle alwey
Stood redy couered all the long day
At sessions there was he lord and syre
Ful ofte tyme he was kniȝt of the shire
An anlas and a gipser all of sylk
Henge at his girdill white as morne milk
A shereue had he bene and comptour
Was nowher such a worthi vauasour
An haberdassher and a carpenter
A webbe a dyer and a Tapicer
And thei were clothid all in oo lyuere
Of a solempne and gret fraternite
Full fressh and newe hire gere a piked was
Here knyues were nat chaped with bras
But all with siluer wrouȝt ful clene and wel
Here girdeles and her pouches eueri dell
Wel semed iche of hem a faire burgeys
To sitten at gildehalle on a deys
Euerich for the wisdam that he can
Was shapely for to ben an alderman
For catell hadde thei I nouȝ and rent
And eke here wyues wold it wel assente
And elles certein were thei to blame
It is full faire to be callid madame
And gon to vigilies al to fore
And haue a mantell rially I bore
A Coke they had with hem for the nones
To boyle the chikenes with the mary bones
And pouder marchᵃunt tart ⁊and ganyngale
Wel coude he knowe a drauȝt of londoıı̄un ale
He coude roste sethe broile and frye
Make mortreux and wel bake A Pye
Gret harme was it as it thouȝt me
That on his shyne a mormal had he
For blankmanger that made with the beste
A shipman was ther wonyng fer by weste
For ouȝt I wot he was of Dertmouthe
He rood vpon a rouncy as he couthe
In a gowne of falding to the knee
A dagger hangyng in a lace had he
A boute his necke vnder his arme a doun
The hote somer had made his hewe al broun
And certeinly he was a gode felawe
Ful many a drauȝt of wyn had he drawe
From Burdeux ward while the shipman slepe
Of nyce conscience toke he no kepe
If that he fauȝt and had the hiȝer hand
By water he sent hem ouer to eueri land
But of his craft to rekne wel his tides
The streemes and his daungier him be sides
His herberwe and his mone ⁊and his lodemanage
Ther nas no such from hull to Cartage
Hardy he was and wise to vndertake
With many a tempest had his berd be shake
He knewe wel all the hauenes as thei were
Fro Gotlond to the cape of Fynistere
And eueri creike in Britayne ⁊and in Spayne
His barge I clepid was the Maudeleyne
With vs ther was a doctour of Phisik
In all the world ne was ther non him like
To speke of Phisik and of surgerye
For he was grounded in astronomye
He kept his pacient a full gret del
In houres be his magik naturel
Wel couthe he fortune the ascendent
Of his ymages for his pacient
He knewe the cause of eueri maladye
Were it of hote or colde or moist or drye
And where hit engendrid ⁊and of what humoᵘur
He was a verri parfiȝt practisour
The cause I knowe ⁊and of his harme the roote
A non he yaf the sike man his bote
Ful redy had he his appoticaries
To sende him drogges ⁊and his lectuaries
For eche of hem made othir for to wynne
Here frendship nas nat newe to be gynne
Wel knewe he the olde Esculapius
And deiscorides and eke rufus
Olde Ipocras haly and Galyen
Serapion Rafis and Auyzen
Aủer/reois Damascien and Constantyn
Bernard and Gatisden and Gilberteyn
Of his diete mesurable was he
For it was no superfluite
But of gret norisshing degestible
His study was but litill on the bible
In sangueyn and in Pers he clad was all
Lyned with teffata and with sendall
And yet he was but esy of despence
He kept that he wan in pestilence
For gold in Phisik is acordiall
Therfor he loued golde in speciall
A good wif was there beside Bathe
But she was somdell deef and that was scathe
Of cloth making she had such an haunte
She passed hem of ypres and of Gaunt
In all the parissh wif was there non
That to the offryng before here shuld goon
And if ther did certein so wroth was she
That she was out of alle charite
Here kerchers full fyne were of ground
I durst swere thei weyeden . x . pound
That on sonday weren vpon here hede
Here hosen weren of fyne scarlet rede
Full streite I tyed and shoes full moist and newe
Bolde was here face and faire ⁊and rede of hewe
She was a worthi womman all hir lyue
Husbondes at the chirche dore she had fyue
Withouten othir company in youthe
For therof nedeth not to speke as nouthe
And thries had she ben at Iherusalem
She had passid many a straunge streem
At Rome she had ben and at Boloyne
In Galys at seint Iame and at Coloigne
She couthe mechel of wandring by the wey
Gat tothed was she sothely for to sey
Vpon an Aumbler esily she sat
I wympled wel and on here hede an hatte
As brode as is a Bokeler or a targe
A foot mantel a boute here hipes large
And on hir feet a peire of spores sharp
In felaship wel couthe she laughe ⁊and carpe
Of remedies of loue she knewe ꝑper/par chaunce
For she couthe of that art the olde daunce
A gode man was ther of religioıı̄un
And was a pore persoıı̄un of a toun
But riche he was of holy thouȝt and werke
He was also a lerned man a Clerk
That Cristes gospel truly wolde preche
His ꝑper/parisshounes deuoutely wolde he teche
Benigne he was and wonder diligent
And in aduersite full pacient
And such he was proued ofte sithes
Full loth were him to cursyn for his tithes
But rather wolde he yeuen out of doute
Vnto his pouer ꝑper/parisshons aboute
Of his offryng and eke of his substaunce
He couthe in litill thing haue suffisaunce
Wide was his parissh and houses fer a sondre
But he laft nat for reyn ne for thundre
In sekenesse nor in mischief to visite
The ferrest in his parissh moch and lyte
Vpon his feet and in his hand a staf
This noble ensample to his sheep he yaf
That first he wrouȝt ⁊and aftirward he tauȝt
Out of the gospell he tho wordes cauȝt
And eke this figure hadded he therto
That if gold ruste what shuld yren do
For if a preest be foule on whom we trust
No wondre is a leude man to ruste
And shame it is if a preest take kepe
A shiten shepperd and a clene sheep
Wel ouȝt a preest ensaunple for to yeue
By his clennesse hou that his shepe shuld lyue
He set nat his benefice to hyre
And let his sheep accombred in the myre
And ran to londoıı̄un vnto seint Poules
To seken him a chauntrye for soules
Or with a bretherhede to ben witholde
But dwelt at hoom and kept wel his folde
So that the wolff ne made it not myscarye
He was a shepperd and not a mercenarye
And thouȝ he holy were and vertuous
He was not to synfull dispitous
Ne of his speche daungerous ne digne
But in his teching discret and benigne
To drawen folk to heuen by fayrenesse
By good ensample this was his besinesse
But it were any persone obstinat
What so he were of lowe or hiȝe estat
Him wolde he snybben sharpely for the nones
A better preest I trowe that nowher non is
He waited aftir no pompe and reuerence
Ne maked him a spiced conscience
But cristes lore and his apostles twelue
He tauȝt / but first he folwed it him selue .
With him ther was A plouȝ man that was his brother
That had I lad of dunge full many a fother
A trewe swinker and a good was he
Lyuyng in pees and parfiȝt charite
God loued he best with all his herte
At alle tymes thouȝ he gamed or smerte
And than his neiȝbour riȝt as him selue
He wold thressh and therto dyke and delue
For cristes sake for eueri pouer wiȝt
Withouten hyre if it lay in his miȝt
His tithes paid he full faire and well
Bothe of his propre swynk ⁊and his catell
In a tabard he rode vpon a mere
Ther was also A Reue and a Millere
A sompnoᵘur and a pardoner also
A Manciple and my self ther was nomo
The Millere was a stoute carle for the nones
Full big he was of braun and eke of bones
That preued wel for ouerall there he cam
At wrastlyng he wold haue alwey the ram
He was short shuldred a propre thikke knarre
There was no dore that he ne wolde heue of harre
Or breke it at a rennyng with his heed
His berd as any sowe or fox was rede
And therto brode as thouȝ it were a spade
Vp on the cop riȝt on his nose he hade
A wert / and theron stood a tuft of heres
Rede as the bristeles of sowes eres
His nose thrilles blak were and wide
A swerd and bokeler bar he be his side
His mouth gret was as a gret forneis
He was a iangeler and a goliardeis
And that was most of synne and harlotries
Wel couthe he stelen corn and tollen thries
And yet he had a thombe of gold parde
A white cote and a blew hood wered he
A bagpipe wel couthe he blowe and soun
And therwith all he brouȝt us out of toune
A gentil Manciple was ther of a Temple
Of which all acchatours miȝt take ensample
For to ben wise in byeng of vitayle
For whethir that he paid or took be tayle
Algate he waited so in his achate
That he was ay befor and in gode estate
Now is nat that of god a full faire grace
That such a leude mannes wit shal pace
The wisdam of an hep of lerned men
Of mastres had he mo than thries ten
That were of lawe expert and curious
Of which ther was a dosein in that hous
Worthi to ben stiwardes of rent and londe
Of any lord that is in Engelond
To make him lyue by his propre gode
In honour detteles but if he were wode
Or lyue as scarsely as him list desire
And able for to helpen al a shire
In any caas that miȝt falle or happe
And yet this Manciple set her alder cappe
The Reue was a slendir colerik man
His berd was shaue as niȝ as euer he can
His heer was be his eres ful rounde I shorn
His toppe was dokked like a prest beforn
Ful longe were his leggis and ful lene
I like a staf ther was no calf I seene
Wel couthe he kepe a gerner ⁊and a bynne
Ther was non auditoᵘur that coude on him wynne
Wel wist he by the droute and by the reyne
The yelding of his seed and of his greyne
His lordes shepe his nete his dayerye
His swyn . his hors . his stoor ⁊and his pultrie
Was holy in this Reues gouerning
And by his couenᵃnt yaf the rekening
Syn that his lord was . xx yere of age
Ther couthe no man bringe him in arrerage
Ther nas baillif ne hierde nor othir hyne
That he ne knewe his sliȝt and his couyne
They were a drad of him as of the deth
His wonyng was ful faire vpon an heeth
With grene trees shadewed was his place
He couthe bettir than his lord purchace
Ful riche he was a stored priuily
His lord he coude wel plesen subtily
To yeue and lend him of his owne good
And haue a thank and eke a cote and an hood
In youthe he had lerned a gode myster
He was a wel gode wright A Carpenter
This Reue sat vpon a full gode stot
That was pomely grey and hiȝt scot
A long surcote of Pers vpon he hade
And by his side he bar a rusty blade
Of Northfolk was this Reue of which I telle
Besides a toun men clepe it Baldeswelle
Tokked he was as is a frere a boute
And euer he rode the hinderest of oure route
A sompnoᵘur was ther with vs in that place
That had a fyre rede cherubynnes face
For saucefleme he was with eyen narwe
As hote he was ⁊and leccherous as is a sparwe
With scallid browes blak and piled berd
Of his visage children were a ferde
Ther nas quikke siluer litarge nor brymston
Boras Ceruse ne oyle of Tarter noon
No oynement that wold clense and byte
That him miȝt helpen of his whelkes white
Nor of the knobbes sitting on his chekes
Wel loued he garlik oynons and eke lekes
And for to drinken strong wyn rede as blood
Than wolde he speke and crye as he were wood
And whan he wel dronken had the wyn
Than wolde he speke no word but latyn
A fewe termes had he ij or iij
That he had lerned out of som decree
No wonder is he it herde all the day
And eke ye knowen wel hou that a Iay
Can clepe watte as wel as can the Pope
But who so couthe in othir thing him grope
Than had he spent all his Philosophie
Ay questio que iuris wolde he crye
He was a gentill harlot and a kynde
A better felaw shul men nouȝt fynde
He wolde suffre for a quart of wyn
A gode felawe to haue his concubyne
A twelmonth and excuse him at the fulle
Full priuely a fynche couthe he pulle
And if he fond owher a gode felawe
He wold techen him to haue non awe
In such caas of the Archedekenes curs
But if mannes soule were in his purs
For in his purs he shall I punysshed be
Purs is the Archedekenes helle said he
But wel I wot he lied riȝt in dede
Of cursing ouȝt eche gilty man drede
For curs will sle riȝt as assoilyng saueth
And also ware him of a significauit
In daungier had he at his owne gise
The yonge girles of the diocise
And knewe here counseill and was all here rede
A garlond had he set vpon his hede
As gret as it were for an Ale stake
A Bokeler had he made him of a cake .
With him ther rod a gentil pardoner
Of Rounceuale / his frend ⁊and his comper
That streite was comen from the court of Rome
Full loude he song come hider loue to me
This sompnoᵘur bar to him a stif burdoıı̄un
Was neuer trompe of half so gret a soun
This Pardoner had heer as yelwe as wax
But smothe it henge as doth a strike of flax
By vnces henge his lokkes that he hadde
And ther with he his shuldres ouer spradde
But thynne it lay by culpons by oon and oon
But hode for iolite wered he non
For it was trussed vp in his walett
Him thouȝt he rod all of the newe Iet
Discheuele saue his cappe he rode all bare
Such glaryng yen had he as an hare
A vernicle had he sewed vpon his cappe
His walet beforn him in his lappe
Bred ful of Pardoıı̄un comen from Rome al hote
A voyce he hath as small as hath a gote
No berde had he ne neuer shuld haue
As smothe it was as it were late shaue
I trowe he were a gelding or a mare
But of his craft fro Berwyk vnto ware
Ne was ther such an othir pardoner
For in his male he had a pilwe bere
Which that he said was oure lady vayle
He said he had a gobet of the sayle
That seint Petir had whan that he went
Vpon the see / til Ihıı̄un crist him hent
He had a crosse of latoıı̄un ful of stones
And in a glas he had pigges bones
But with this relikes whan that he fonde
A pouer persoıı̄un dwelling vpon londe
Vpon a day he gat more money
Than that the person gat in monthes twey
And thus with feyned flatery and iapes
He made the person and the people his apes
But truly to tellen at the last
He was in chirche a noble Ecclesiast
Wel couthe he rede a lesson or a story
But alderbest he song an offertory
For wel he wist whan that song was songe
He must preche and wel enfile his tonge
To wynne siluer as he wel coude
Therfor he song the merilier and loude
¶ Now haue I tolde you sothely in a clause
The estat . the array . the nombre and eke the cause
Why that assembled was this company
In Southwerk at the gentill hostilry
That hiȝt the Tabard fast by the Belle
But now is tyme for you to telle
How that we baren us that ilke niȝt
Whan we were in that hostelrye a liȝt
And aftir will I telle of oure viage
And all the remenᵃnt of oure pilgrimage
But first I pray you of your curtesy
That ye ne rette it nauȝt in vilanye
Thouȝ that I pleinly speke in this matere
To telle you here wordes and here chiere
Ne thouȝ I speke here wordes propirly
For this ye knowe als wel as I .
Who so shal tellen a tale aftir a man
He mote reherce as ny as euer he can
Euerich a worde if it be in his charge
All speke he neuer so rudely ne large
Orellis he mot telle his tale vntrewe
Or feyne thinges or fynden wordes newe
He may not spare al thouȝ he were his brothir
He mot aswel say oon wurd as an othir
Crist spak him self ful brode in holy wrytte
And wel ye wot no vilany is hit
Eke Plato seith who so can him rede
The wordes mot be cosin to the dede
Also I pray you foryeue it me
All haue I nat set folk in her degree
Here in this tale as that they shulde stonde
My wit is short ye may wel vnderstonde
¶ Gret chiere made oure oost vs euericheon
And to the soper he set vs anon
He serued vs with vitayle at the best
Strong was the wyn and wel to drynke us beste
A semely man was oure oost with all
For to ben A Marchall in an halle
A large man he was with yen stepe
A fairer Burgeys was non in chepe
Bolde of his speche and wys and wel I taught
And of manhod he lakkid riȝt nouȝt
Eke therto he was a mery man
And aftir soper pleyen he bigan
And spak of mirthe among othir thinges
Whan that we had mad oure rekenynges
And seide thus now lordinges truly
Ye ben to me right welcome hertely
For by my trouthe if that I shal nat lye
I sey not this yere so mery a company
Atones in this herberwe as is now
Fayn wolde I do you merthe and I wist hou
And of a mirthe I am riȝt now bethouȝt
To don you ese and it shal coste nouȝt
Ye gon to Caunterbury god you spede
The blisfull martir quyte you your mede
And wel I wot as ye gon by the wey
Ye shapen you to talen and to pley
For truly confort ne mirthe is noon
To riden by the wey dombe as the stoon
And therfor wol I maken you disport
As I said arst / and don you som comfort
And if you liketh all by oon assent
For to stonden at my Iugement
And for to werken as I shal you sey
To morwe whan ye ryden by the wey
Now be my fader soule that is ded
But ye be mery I wil yeue you my hed
¶ Holde vp your hond withoute more speche
Oure counseill was not longe to seche
Vs thouȝt it was not worth to make it wise
And graunted him withoute more auyse
And bad him sey his veredite as him leste
Now lordinges qd he herkeneth for the beste
But take it nat I pray you in disdeyn
This is the poynt to speke it short and playn
That eche of you to short with your wey
In this viage shal tellen tales twey
To Caunterburyward I mene it so
And homward he shal tellen othir ij
Of auentures that whilom haue be falle
And which of you bereth him best of alle
That is to seyn that tellith in this caas
Tales of best sentence and most solas
Shal haue a soper at oure alder cost
Here in this place sittyng by this post
Whan that we come agein fro Caunterbury
And for to make you the more mery
I wol my self godely with you ryde
Riȝt at myn owne cost and be your gide
And who so wil my iugement with sey
Shal pay all that we spende by the wey
And if ye vouchesaf that it be so
Telle me anon withoute wordes mo
And I wil erely shape me therfore
These thinges were graunted ⁊and oure othes swore
With full glad herte ⁊and preyen him also
That he wil vouchesaf for to do so
And that he wold be oure gouernoᵘur
And of oure tales iuge and reportoᵘur
And set a soper at a certain pris
And we wil ruled ben at his deuys
In highe and lowe ⁊and thus be oon assent
We ben accorded to the Iugement
And therupon the wyn was fet anon
We dronken and to reest went echeon
Withoute any lenger tarieng
A morwe whan that day gan to sprynge
Vp ros oure oost and was oure alder cok
And gadered us to gidre in a flok
And forth we ryden a litel more than paas
Vnto the watering of seint Thomas
And there oure oost bigan his hors areste
And seid lordes herkeneth if you leste
Ye wot your forward ⁊and I it you recorde
If euyn song ⁊and morwe song acorde
Lat se now who shal telle the first tale
As euer I mot drinke wyn or ale
Who so be rebell to my iugement
Shal pay for all that by the wey is spent
Now draweth cut or we further twynne
He which that hath the shortest shall begynne
¶ Sir qd he my mastir ⁊and my lord
Now draweth cutte for that is myn accord
Cometh nere qd he my lady Prioresse
And ye sir Clerk lat be your shamefastnesse
Ne studieth nouȝt ley honde to eueri man
Anon to drawe eueri wiȝt bigan
And shortly for to tellen as it was
Were it by auenture or soort or caas
The soth is this the cut fel to the kniȝt
Of which ful blithe ⁊and glad was eueri wiȝt
And tellen he mot his tale as it was resoıı̄un
By forward and by composicioıı̄un
As ye han herd what nedes wordes moo
And whan this godeman saw that it was soo
As he that wise was and obedient
To kepe his forward by his free assent
He seide syn I shal begynne the game
What welcome be the cutte on goddes name
Now lat us ride and herkeneth what I sey
And with that word we riden forth oure wey
And he bigan with riȝt a mery chiere
His tale anon ⁊and seide as ye may here .
Iamque domos patrias scithice post aspera gentis prelia laurigero et cetera .

div.l: (base) And how assegeged was ypolita
(base) The faire hardy queene of Scithia
(base) And of the feste / that was at hir weddynge
(base) And of the tempest at hir hom comynge
(base) But al that thyng I moot as now forbere

(base) Incipit narracio
(base) ¶ Here bygynneth the knyghtes tale.
(base) This duc of whom I make mencioun
(base) Whanne he was come / almoost to the town
(base) In al his wele / and in his mooste pryde
(base) He was war / as he caste his eye asyde
(base) Wher that ther kneled / in the heighe weye
(base) A compaignye of ladyes / tweye and tweye

(base) But swich a cry / and swich a wo they make

(base) ¶ What folk been ye / that at myn hom comynge

(base) Quod Theseus / haue ye so greet envie

(base) And telleth me / if it may been amended
(base) And why that ye / been clothed thus in blak /
(base) The eldeste lady / of hem alle spak

div.l: (base) ¶ She seyde / lord / to whom Fortune hath yiuen
(base) Victorie / and as a Conquerour to lyuen
(base) Noght greueth vs youre glorie / and youre honour
(base) But we biseken / mercy and socour
(base) Haue mercy on oure wo / and oure distresse
(base) Som drope of pitee / thurgh thy gentillesse
(base) Vpon vs wrecched wommen / lat thow falle
(base) For certes lord / ther is noon of vs alle
(base) That she ne hath been / a duchesse / or a queene
(base) Now be we caytyues / as it is wel seene
(base) Thanked be Fortune / and hir false wheel
(base) That noon estaat assureth to been weel
(base) Now certes lord / to abiden youre persence
(base) Heere in this temple / of the goddesse clemence
(base) We haue been waytynge / al this fourtenyght
(base) Now help vs /lord syth it is in thy myght
(base) ¶ I wrecche / which that wepe and waille thus
(base) Was whilom wyf / to kyng Cappaneus
(base) That starf at Thebes / cursed be the day
(base) And alle we / that been in this array
(base) And maken / al this lamentacioun
(base) We losten alle oure housbondes / at that town
(base) Whil that the sege / ther aboute lay
(base) And yet now / the olde Creoun weylaway
(base) That lord is now / of Thebes the Citee
(base) Fulfild of Ire / and of Iniquitee
(base) He for despit and for his tyrannye
(base) To doon / the dede bodyes vileynye
(base) Of alle oure lordes / whiche that been slawe

(base) And wol nat suffren hem / by noon assent
(base) Neyther to been yburyed / nor ybrent

div.l: (base) They fillen gruf and cryden pitously
(base) Haue / on vs wrecched wommen / som mercy
(base) And lat oure sorwe / synken in thyn herte
(base) ¶ This gentil Duc doun from his courser sterte
(base) With herte pitous / whan he herde hem speke
(base) Hym thoughte / that his herte wolde breke
(base) Whan he saugh hem / so pitous / and so maat
(base) That whilom weren / of so greet estaat
(base) And in hise armes / he hem alle vp hente
(base) And hem conforteth / in ful good entente
(base) And swoor his ooth / as he was trewe knyght
(base) He wolde doon / so ferforthly his myght
(base) Vpon the tiraunt Creon / hem to wreke
(base) That al the peple of Grece / sholde speke
(base) How Creoun was / of Theseus yserued
(base) As he that hadde his deeth / ful wel disserued
(base) And right anoon / withouten moore abood
(base) His baner he desplayeth / and forth rood
(base) To Thebesward / and al his oost bisyde
(base) No neer Atthenes / wolde he go ne ryde
(base) Ne take his ese / fully half a day
(base) But onward in his wey / that nyght he lay
(base) And sente anoon / ypolita the queene
(base) And Emelye / hir yonge suster sheene
(base) Vnto the town of Atthenes / to dwelle
(base) And forth he ryt ther nys namoore to telle

(base) The Mynotaur / which that he wan in Crete

div.l: (base) Forth he rode with grete power and myght
(base) Til that he cam to Thebes / and alighte
(base) Faire in a feeld / ther as he thoghte fighte
(base) ¶ But shortly / for to speken of this thyng
(base) With Creoun / which that was of Thebes kyng
(base) He faught and slow hym manly / as a knyght
(base) In pleyn bataille / and putte the folk to flyght
(base) And by assaut he wan the Citee after
(base) And rente adoun / bothe wal / and sparre / and rafter
(base) And to the ladyes / he restored agayn
(base) The bones / of hir freendes / that were slayn
(base) To doon obsequies / as was tho the gyse
(base) But it weere al to long for to deuyse
(base) The grete clamour / and the waymentynge

(base) Of the bodies / and the grete honour
(base) That Theseus / the noble Conquerour

(base) But shortly / for to telle is myn entente
(base) ¶ Whan that this worthy duc this Theseus

(base) Thurgh girt with many a greuous blody wownde

div.l: (base) The heraudes / knewe hem best in special

(base) Of Theseus / and he ful soone hem sente
(base) To Atthenes / to dwellen in prisoun
(base) Perpetuelly / he nolde no raunsoun
(base) ¶ And whan this worthy duc / hath thus ydoon

(base) With laurer corouned / as a conquerour
(base) And there he lyueth / in ioye / and in honour
(base) Terme of his lyf / what nedeth wordes mo

div.l: (base) And in the gardyn / at the sonne vp riste

(base) This sorweful prisoner / this Palamoun
(base) This wooful louere this Palamon

div.l: (base) Oure prison / for it may noon oother be
(base) Fortune / hath yeuen vs this aduersitee
(base) Som wikked aspect or disposicioun
(base) Of Saturne / by som constellacioun
(base) Hath yeuen vs this / althogh we hadde it sworn
(base) So stood the heuene / whan that we were born
(base) We mote endure it this is the short and playn
(base) This Palamoun answerde / and seyde agayn
(base) ¶ Cosyn for sothe / of this opinioun
(base) Thow hast a vayn ymaginacioun
(base) This prisoun / caused me noght to crye
(base) But I was hurt right now / thurgh out myn Iye
(base) In to myn herte / that wol my bane be
(base) The fairnesse / of that lady that I se
(base) Yond in the gardyn / romen to and fro

(base) I noot wher she be womman / or goddesse
(base) But Venus / is it soothly / as I gesse

(base) Yow in this gardyn / thus to transfigure
(base) Bifore me / sorweful wrecched creature
(base) Out of this prisoun / help that we may scape
(base) And if so be / my destynee be shape
(base) By eterne word / to dyen in prisoun
(base) Of oure lynage / haue som compassioun
(base) That is so lowe ybroght by tirannye
(base) ¶ And with that word / Arcite gan espye
(base) Where as this lady / romed to and fro

(base) That if that Palamon / was wounded soore
(base) Arcite is hurt . as muche as he / or moore
(base) And with a syk / . he seyde pitously
(base) The fresshe beautee / sleeth me sodeynly

div.l: (base) Of hire / that rometh in the yonder place
(base) And but I haue / hir mercy / and hir grace

(base) I nam but deed / ther nys namoore to seye
(base) ¶ This Palamon / whan he tho wordes herde
(base) Despitously / he loked / and answerde
(base) Wheither seistow this / in ernest or in pley
(base) ¶ Nay quod Arcite / in ernest by my fey
(base) God help me so / me list ful yuele pleye
(base) This Palamon / gan knytte his browes tweye
(base) ¶ It were to thee quod he / no greet honour
(base) For to be fals / ne for to be traytour
(base) To me / that am thy cosyn and thy brother
(base) Ysworn ful depe / and ech of vs til oother
(base) That neuere / for to dyen in the peyne
(base) Til that the deeth / departe shal vs tweyne
(base) Neither of vs / in loue to hyndre oother
(base) Ne in noon oother caas / my leeue brother
(base) But that thow sholdest trewely forthre me
(base) In euery caas / as I shal forthren thee
(base) This was thyn ooth / and myn also certeyn
(base) I woot right wel / thow darst it nat withseyn
(base) Thus artow of my conseil / out of doute
(base) And now / thow woldest falsly been aboute
(base) To loue my lady / whom I loue and serue
(base) And euere shal / til that myn herte sterue
(base) Now certes false Arcite / thow shalt nat so
(base) I loued hire first and tolde thee my wo
(base) As to my conseil / and my brother sworn
(base) To forthre me / as I haue told biforn

div.l: (base) ¶ Now been thise listes maad / and Theseus
(base) That at his grete cost arrayed thus
(base) The temples / and the Theatre euery del
(base) Whan it was doon / hym liked wonder wel
(base) But stynte I wole / of Theseus alite
(base) And speke of Palamon / and of Arcite
(base) ¶ The day approcheth / of hir retournynge
(base) That euerich / sholde an hundred knyghtes brynge
(base) The bataille to darreyne / as I yow tolde
(base) And til Atthenes / hir couenant for to holde
(base) Hath euerich of hem / broght a hundred knyghtes
(base) Wel armed for the werre / at alle rightes
(base) And sikerly / ther trowed many a man
(base) That neuere sithen / that the world bigan
(base) As for to speke / of knyghthod of hir hond
(base) As fer / as god hath maked see and lond
(base) Nas of so fewe / so noble a compaignye
(base) For euery wight that loued chiualrye
(base) And wolde his thankes / han a passant name
(base) Hath prayd / that he myghte been of that game
(base) And wel was hym / that ther to chosen was
(base) For if ther fille / tomorwe swich a cas
(base) Ye knowen wel / that euery lusty knyght /
(base) That loueth paramours / and hath his myght
(base) Were it in Engelond / or ellis where
(base) They wolde hir thankes / wilnen to be there
(base) To fighten for a lady / benedicitee
(base) It were a lusty sighte / for to see
(base) ¶ And right so / ferden they with Palamon
(base) With hym ther wenten / knyghtes many oon
(base) Som wol ben armed / in an haubergeoun
(base) And in a Brestplate / and in a light gypoun
(base) And som wol haue / a peire plates large
(base) And some willen haue a pruce schelde othir targe
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) And som wol haue / a Pruce sheeld / or a targe
(base) Som wol been armed / on his legges weel
(base) And haue an Ax / and som a Maas of steel
(base) Ther nys no newe gyse / that it nas oold
(base) Armed were they / as I haue yow toold
(base) Euerich / after his opinyoun
(base) ¶ Ther maystow seen / comynge with Palamoun
(base) Lygurge hymself the grete kyng of Trace
(base) Blak was his beerd / and manly was his face
(base) The cercles of his eyen / in his heed
(base) They gloweden / bitwixen yelow and reed
(base) And lyk a griffoun / loked he aboute
(base) With keempe herys / on his browes stoute
(base) His lymes grete / his brawnes / harde and stronge
(base) Hys shuldres brode / hise armes rounde and longe
(base) And as the gyse was / in his contree
(base) Ful hye / vpon a Chaar of gold stood he
(base) With foure white Boles / in the trays
(base) In stide of Cotearmure / ouer his harnays
(base) With nayles yelwe / and brighte as any gold
(base) He hadde a Berys Skyn / colblak / for old
(base) His longe heer / was kembed bihynde his bak
(base) As any Rauenes fethere / it shoon for blak
(base) A wrethe of gold / greet of huge wighte
(base) Vpon his heed / and ful of stones brighte
(base) Of fyne Rubyes / and of dyamauntz
(base) Aboute his Chaar / ther wente white Alauntz
(base) Twenty and mo / as grete as any steer
(base) To hunten at the leoun / and the deer
(base) And folwed hym / with mosel faste ybounde
(base) Colered of gold / and turrettes filed rounde
(base) An hundred lordes / hadde he in his route
(base) Armed ful wel / with hertes stierne and stoute
(base) ¶ With Arcita / in stories as men fynde
(base) The grete Emetrius / the kyng of Inde
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Vpon a Steede bay / trapped in steel
(base) Couered in a clooth of gold / dyapred weel
(base) Cam ridynge / lyk the god of Armes Mars
(base) His cote armure / was of clooth of Tars
(base) Couched with perlys white / and rounde and grete
(base) His sadel was / of brend gold newe ybete
(base) A Mantelet vpon his shulder hangynge
(base) Bretful of Rubies reede / as fyr sparklynge
(base) His crispe heer / lyk rynges was yronne
(base) And that was yelow / and glitred as the sonne
(base) His nose was heigh / hise eyen bright Citryn
(base) His lyppes rounde / his colour was sangwyn
(base) A fewe fraknes / in his face yspreynd
(base) Bitwixen yelow / and som del blak ymeynd
(base) And as a leoun / he his lookyng caste
(base) Of . xxv. yeer / his age I caste
(base) His beerd / was wel bigonne for to sprynge
(base) His voys / was as a trompe thonderynge
(base) Vpon his heed / he wered of laurer grene
(base) A gerland fressh / and lusty for to seene
(base) Vpon his hand / he bar for his deduyt
(base) An Egle tame / as any lilie whyt
(base) An hundred lordes / hadde he with hym there
(base) Al armed saue hir heddes / in al hir gere
(base) Ful richely / in alle manere thynges
(base) For trusteth wel / that dukes / Erles / kynges
(base) Were gadred / in this noble compaignye
(base) For loue / and for encrees of chiualrye
(base) Aboute this kyng ther ran on euery part
(base) Ful many a tame leoun and leopart
(base) ¶ And in this wise / thise lordes alle and some
(base) Been on the Sonday / to the Citee come
(base) Aboute pryme / and in the town alight
(base) ¶ This Theseus / this duc this worthy knyght
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Whan he hadde broght hem / in to his Citee
(base) And Inned hem / euerich at his degree
(base) He festeth hem / and dooth so gret labour
(base) To esen hem / and doon hem al honour
(base) That yet men wenen / that no mannes wit
(base) Of noon estaat ne koude amenden it /
(base) ¶ The Mynstralcye / the seruyce / at the feeste
(base) The grete yiftes / to the meeste and leeste
(base) The ryche array / of Theseus Paleys
(base) Ne who sat first or last vpon the deys
(base) What ladyes fairest been / and best daunsynge
(base) Or which of hem / kan daunse best and synge
(base) Ne who moost feelyngly / speketh of loue
(base) What haukes sitten / on the perche aboue
(base) What houndes lyggen / on the floor adown
(base) Of al this / make I now no mencioun
(base) But al theffect that thynketh me the beste
(base) Now comth the point and herkneth if yow leste
(base) ¶ The Sonday nyght er day bigan to sprynge
(base) Whan Palamon / the larke herde synge
(base) Althogh it nere nat day / by houres two
(base) Yet soong the larke / and Palamon right tho
(base) Vnto the temple purposeth he to go
(base) With holy herte / and with an heigh corage
(base) He roos / to wenden on his pilgrymage
(base) Vnto the blisful / Scitherea benygne
(base) I mene Venus / honurable and digne
(base) And in hir hour / he walketh forth a paas
(base) Vnto the lystes / ther hir temple was
(base) And down he kneleth / and with humble cheere
(base) And herte soor / he seyde as ye shal heere
(base) ¶ Faireste of faire / o lady myn Venus
(base) Doghter of Ioue / and spouse to Vulcanus
(base) Thow gladere / of the mount of Cytheron
(base) For thilke loue / thow haddest to Adoon
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Haue pitee / of my bittre teerys smerte
(base) And taak myn humble prayere at thyn herte
(base) ¶ Allas I ne haue no langage to telle
(base) Theffect. ne the tormentz of myn helle
(base) Myn herte / may myne harmes nat biwreye
(base) I am so confus / that I kan noght seye
(base) But mercy lady bright that knowest wele
(base) My thoght and seest what harmes that I feele
(base) Considre al this / and rewe vpon my soore
(base) As wisly / as I shal for euere moore
(base) Emforth my myght thy trewe seruant be
(base) And holden werre / alwey with chastitee
(base) That make I myn avow / so ye me helpe
(base) I kepe noght of armes for to yelpe
(base) Ne I ne axe noght to morwe / to haue victorie
(base) Ne renoun in this cas / ne veyne glorie
(base) Of prys of armes / blowen vp and down
(base) But I wolde haue / fully possessioun
(base) Of Emelye / and dye in thy seruyse
(base) Fynd thow the manere / how / and in what wyse
(base) I recche nat but it may bettre be
(base) To haue victorie of hem / or they of me
(base) So that I haue / my lady in myn armes
(base) For thogh so be / that Mars is god of armes
(base) Youre vertu is so greet in heuene aboue
(base) That if yow list I shal wel haue my loue
(base) ¶ Thy temple / wol I worshipe eueremo
(base) And on thyn Auter / wher I ryde or go
(base) I wol doon sacrifice / and fyres beete
(base) And if ye wol noght so / my lady sweete
(base) Thanne praye I thee / to morwe with a spere
(base) That Arcita / me thurgh the herte bere
(base) Thanne rekke I noght whan I haue lost my lyf
(base) Thogh that Arcita / wynne hire to his wyf
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) This is theffect and ende of my prayere
(base) Yif me my loue / thow blisful lady deere
(base) ¶ Whan the orison was doon / of Palamon
(base) His sacrifice he dide / and that anon
(base) Ful pitously / with alle circumstances
(base) Al telle I nat as now / his obseruances
(base) But at the laste / the Statue of Venus shook
(base) And made a signe / wher by that he took
(base) That his prayere / accepted was that day
(base) For thogh the signe / shewed a delay
(base) Yet wiste he wel / that graunted was his boone
(base) And with glad herte / he wente hym hoom ful soone
(base) ¶ The thridde hour in equal / that Palamon
(base) Bigan / to Venus temple / for to gon
(base) Vp roos the sonne / and vp roos Emelye
(base) And to the temple of Diane / gan hye
(base) Hir maydens / that she thider with hire ladde
(base) Ful redily with hem / the fyr they hadde
(base) Thencens / the clothes / and the remenant al
(base) That to the sacrifice / longen shal
(base) The hornes ful of Mede / as was the gyse
(base) Ther lakked noght to doon hir sacrifise
(base) ¶ Smokynge the temple / ful of clothes faire
(base) This Emelye / with herte debonaire
(base) Hir body wessh / with water of a welle
(base) Hire body wesshe with herte debonarie
(base) But hou she dide hir ryte / I dar nat telle
(base) But it be / any thyng in general
(base) And yet it were a game / to heren al
(base) To hym that meneth wel / it nere no charge
(base) But it is good / a man be at his large
(base) ¶ Hir brighte heer was kembed / vntressed al
(base) A corone / of a grene ook cerial
(base) Vpon hir heed was set ful fair and meete
(base) Two fyres / on the Auter gan she beete
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) And dide hir thynges / as men may biholde
(base) In Stace of Thebes / and othere bokes olde
(base) Whan kyndled was the fyr / with pitous cheere
(base) Vnto Diane / she spak / as ye may heere
(base) ¶ O chaste goddesse / of the wodes grene
(base) To whom / bothe heuene / and erthe / and See is seene
(base) Queene of the regne of Pluto / derk and lowe
(base) Goddesse of maydens / that myn herte hast knowe
(base) Ful many a yeer / and woost what I desire
(base) As keep me / fro thy vengeance and thyn Ire
(base) That Attheoun / aboghte crewelly
(base) Chaste goddesse / wel wostow that I
(base) Desire / to been a mayden / al my lyf
(base) Ne neuere wol I be / no loue / ne wyf
(base) I am thow woost yet of thy compaignye
(base) A mayde / and loue huntyng and venerye
(base) And for to walken / in the wodes wilde
(base) And noght to been a wyf / and be with childe
(base) Noght wol I knowe / compaignye of man
(base) Now help me lady / sith ye may and kan
(base) For tho thre formes / that thow hast in thee
(base) And Palamon / that hath swich loue to me
(base) And eek Arcite / that loueth me so soore
(base) This grace I praye thee / withoute moore
(base) As seend loue and pees / bitwix hem two
(base) And fro me / turn awey / hir hertes so
(base) That al hir hote loue / and hir desir
(base) And al hir bisy torment and hir fyr
(base) Be queynt and turned in another place
(base) And if so be / thow wolt noght do me grace
(base) Or if my destynee / be shape so
(base) That I shal nedes / haue oon of hem two
(base) As seend me hym / that moost desireth me
(base) Bihoold goddesse / of clene chastitee
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) The bittre teerys / that on my chekes falle
(base) Syn thow art mayde / and kepere of vs alle
(base) My maydenhode thow kepe / and wel conserue
(base) And whil I lyue / a mayde I wol thee serue
(base) ¶ The fyres brenne / vpon the Auter cleere
(base) Whil Emelie / is thus in hir prayere
(base) But sodeynly / she seigh a sighte queynte
(base) For right anon / oon of the fyres queynte
(base) And quyked agayn / and after that anon
(base) That oother fyr was queynt and al agon
(base) And as it queynte / it made a whistlynge
(base) As doon thise weete brondes / in hir brennynge
(base) And at the brondes ende / out ran anoon
(base) As it were / blody dropes many oon
(base) For which / so soore agast was Emelye
(base) That she was wel neigh mad / and gan to crye
(base) For she ne wiste / what it signyfied
(base) But oonly for the feere / thus hath she cryed
(base) And weep / that it was pitee for to heere
(base) ¶ And therwithal / Diane gan appeere
(base) With bowe in honde / right as an hunteresse
(base) And seyde doghter / stynt thyn heuynesse
(base) Among the goddes hye / it is affermed
(base) And by eterne word / writen and confermed
(base) Thou shalt be wedded / vnto oon of tho
(base) That han for thee / so muche care and wo
(base) But vnto which of hem / I may noght telle
(base) Fare wel / for I ne may no lenger dwelle
(base) The fires / whiche that on myn Auter brenne
(base) Shul thee declaren / er that thow go henne
(base) Thyn auenture of loue / as in this cas
(base) And with that word / the Arwes in the Caas
(base) Of the goddesse / clateren faste and rynge
(base) And forth she wente / and made a vanysshynge
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) For which / this Emelye astoned was
(base) And seyde / what amounteth this allas
(base) I putte me / in thy proteccioun
(base) Diane / and in thy disposicioun
(base) And hoom she gooth anoon / the nexte weye
(base) This is theffect ther nys namoore to seye
(base) ¶ The nexte houre of Mars / folwynge this
(base) Arcite / vnto the temple walked is
(base) Of fierse Mars / to doon his sacrifise
(base) With alle the rytes / of his payen wise
(base) With pitous herte / and heigh deuocioun
(base) Right thus to Mars / he seyde his orisoun
(base) ¶ O stronge god / that in the regnes colde
(base) Of Trace / honoured art and lord yholde
(base) And hast in euery regne / and euery lond
(base) Of armes / al the brydel in thyn hond
(base) And hem fortunest as thee list deuyse
(base) Accepte of me / my pitous sacrifise
(base) If so be / that my youthe may disserue
(base) And that my myght be worthy for to serue
(base) Thy godhede / that I may be oon of thyne
(base) Thanne praye I thee / to rewe vpon my pyne
(base) For thilke peyne / and thilke hote fyr
(base) In which / thow whilom brendest for desir
(base) Whan that thow vsedest the beautee
(base) Of faire yonge / fresshe Venus free
(base) And haddest hire / in armes at thy wille
(base) Although thee ones / on a tyme mysfille
(base) Whan Vulcanus / hadde caught thee in his laas
(base) And foond thee lyggyng by his wyf allas
(base) For thilke sorwe / that was in thyn herte
(base) Haue routhe as wel / vpon my peynes smerte
(base) I am yong / and vnkonnyng as thow woost /
(base) And as I trowe / with loue offended moost
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) That euere was / any lyues creature
(base) For she that dooth me / al this wo endure
(base) Ne reccheth neuere / wher I synke or fleete
(base) And wel I woot er she me mercy heete
(base) I moot with strengthe / wynne hire in the place
(base) And wel I woot withouten help and grace
(base) Of thee / ne may my strengthe noght auaille
(base) Thanne help me lord / tomorwe in my bataille
(base) For thilke fyr / that whilom brende thee
(base) As wel as thilke fyr / now brenneth me
(base) And do that I tomorwe / may haue victorie
(base) Myn be the trauaille / and thyn be the glorie
(base) Thy souereyn temple / wol I moost honouren
(base) Of any place / and alwey moost labouren
(base) In thy plesaunce / and in thy craftes stronge
(base) And in thy temple / I wol my baner honge
(base) And alle the armes / of my compaignye
(base) And euere mo / vn til that day I dye
(base) Eterne fyr / I wol bifore thee fynde
(base) And eek to this auow / I wol me bynde
(base) My berd / myn heer / that hangeth long adown
(base) That neuere yet ne felte offensioun
(base) Of Rasour / nor of Shere / I wol thee yiue
(base) And been thy trewe seruant whil I lyue
(base) Now lord haue routhe / vpon my sorwes soore
(base) Yif me the victorie / I axe thee namoore
(base) ¶ The prayere stynt of Arcita the stronge
(base) The rynges / on the temple dore that honge
(base) And eek the dores / clatereden ful faste
(base) Of which Arcita / som what hym agaste
(base) The fires brende / vpon the Auter brighte
(base) That it gan al the temple for to lighte
(base) A swete smel / anoon the ground vp yaf
(base) And Arcita / anoon his hand vp haf
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) And moore encens / in to the fyr he caste
(base) With othere rytes mo / and at the laste
(base) ¶ The statue of Mars / bigan his hauberk rynge
(base) And with that sown / he herde a murmurynge
(base) Ful lowe and dym / and seyde thus / victorie
(base) For which / he yaf to Mars / honour and glorie
(base) ¶ And thus with ioye / and hope / wel to fare
(base) Arcite anoon / vnto his In is fare
(base) As fayn as fowel / is of the brighte sonne
(base) ¶ And right anoon / swich stryf ther is bigonne
(base) For thilke grauntyng in the heuene aboue
(base) Bitwixe Venus / the goddesse of loue
(base) And Mars / the sterne god armipotente
(base) That Iuppiter / was bisy it to stente
(base) Til that the pale / Saturnus the colde
(base) That knew so manye / of auentures olde
(base) Foond in his olde experience / an art
(base) That he ful soone / hath plesed euery part
(base) As sooth is seyd / elde hath greet auantage
(base) In elde / is bothe wisdom and vsage
(base) Men may the olde at renne / and nat atrede
(base) Saturne anoon / to stynten stryf and drede
(base) Al be it that it is agayn his kynde
(base) Of al this stryf he kan remedie fynde
(base) ¶ My deere doghter Venus / quod Saturne
(base) My cours / that hath so wyde for to turne
(base) Hath moore power / than woot any man
(base) Myn is the drenchyng in the See so wan
(base) Myn is the prison / in the derke cote
(base) Myn is the stranglyng and hangyng by the throte
(base) The murmur / and the cherles rebellynge
(base) The groynyng and the pryuee empoysonynge
(base) I do vengeance / and pleyn correccioun
(base) Whil I dwelle / in the signe of the leoun
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Myn is the ruyne / of the heighe halles
(base) The fallyng of the toures / and of the walles
(base) Vpon the Mynour / or the Carpenter
(base) I slow Sampson / shakyng the piler
(base) And myne be / the maladies colde
(base) The derke tresons / and the castes olde
(base) My lookyng is the fader of pestilence
(base) Now weep namoore / I shal doon diligence
(base) That Palamon / that is thyn owene knyght
(base) Shal haue his lady / as thow hast hym hight
(base) Thogh Mars shal helpe his knyght yet nathelees
(base) Bitwixe yow / ther moot be som tyme pees
(base) Al be ye noght of o complexioun
(base) That causeth al day / swich diuisioun
(base) I am thyn Aiel / redy at thy wille
(base) Weep now namoore / I wol thy lust fulfille
(base) ¶ Now wol I stynten / of the goddes aboue
(base) Of Mars / and of Venus / goddesse of loue
(base) And telle yow / as pleynly as I kan
(base) The grete effect. for which that I bigan
(base) ¶ Explicit tercia pars ~
(base) ¶ Sequitʳ pars quarta ~
(base) ¶ Greet was the feeste / in Atthenes that day
(base) And eek the lusty sesoun / of that May
(base) Made euery wight to been in swich plesaunce
(base) That al that monday / Iusten they and daunce
(base) And spenden it in Venus heigh seruyse
(base) And by the cause / that they sholde ryse
(base) Erly / for to seen the grete sight
(base) Vnto hir reste / wente they at nyght
(base) And on the morwe / whan the day gan sprynge
(base) Of hors and harneys / noyse and claterynge
(base) Ther was in hostelryes / al aboute
(base) And to the paleys / rood ther many a route
(base) Of lordes / vpon steedes and palfreys
(base) Ther maist thow seen / deuysynge of harneys
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) So vnkouth / and so ryche / and wroght so weel
(base) Of Goldsmythrye / of Broudyng and of steel
(base) The sheldes brighte / testers / and trappures
(base) Gold hewen helmes / hauberkes / cote armures
(base) Lordes in parementz / on hir coursers
(base) Knyghtes of retenue / and eek Squyers
(base) Nailynge the speres / and the helmes bokelynge
(base) Gyggynge of sheeldes / with layners lasynge
(base) Ther as nede is / they were no thyng ydel
(base) The fomy steedes / on the golden brydel
(base) Gnawynge / and faste the Armurers also
(base) With fyle and hamer / prykyng to and fro
(base) Yemen on foote / and communes many oon
(base) With shorte staues / thikke as they may goon
(base) Pipes / trompes / Nakers / Claryounes
(base) That in the bataille / blowen blody sownes
(base) The paleys ful of peples / vp and down
(base) Heer thre / ther ten / holdynge hir questioun
(base) Deuynynge / of thise Thebans knyghtes two

(base) Ne how the ground / agast was of the lyght
(base) That was nat wont to seen the sonne bright
(base) Ne how the fyr / was couched first with stree
(base) And thanne with drye stikkes / clouen a three
(base) And thanne with grene wode / and spicerye
(base) And thanne with clooth of gold / and with perrye
(base) And thanne with cloth of golde and with perie
(base) And gerlandes hangynge / ful of many a flour
(base) The Mirre / thencens / withal so greet sauour
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Ne how Arcite / lay among al this
(base) Ne what richesse / aboute the body is
(base) Ne how that Emelye / as was the gyse
(base) Putte in the fyr / of funeral seruyse
(base) Ne how she swowned / whan men made the fyr
(base) Ne what she spak ne what was hir desir
(base) Ne what Iuels / men in the fyr caste
(base) Whan that the fyr was greet and brente faste
(base) Ne how somme caste hir sheeld / and somme hir spere
(base) And of hir vestimentz / whiche that they were
(base) And coppes fulle of Milk and wyn and blood
(base) In to the fyr / that brente as it were wood
(base) Ne how the Grekys / with An huge route
(base) Thries ryden / al the fyr aboute
(base) Vpon the left hand / with a loud shoutynge
(base) And thries / with hir speres claterynge
(base) And thryes wᵗith here sperys claterynge
(base) And thries / how the ladyes gonne crye
(base) And how that lad / was homward Emelye
(base) Ne how Arcite / is brent to Asshen colde
(base) Ne how that lychwake / was yholde
(base) Al thilke nyght ne how the grekys pleye
(base) The wake pleyes / ne kepe I noght to seye
(base) Who wrastleth best naked / with oille enoynt
(base) Ne who that baar hym best in no disioynt
(base) I wol nat tellen al / how they goon
(base) Hoom til Atthenes / whan the pleye is doon
(base) But shortly to the poynt than wol I wende
(base) And maken / of my longe tale an ende
(base) ¶ By proces / and by lengthe of certeyn yerys
(base) Al stynt is / the moornynge and the terys
(base) Of Grekys / by oon general assent
(base) Thanne semed me / ther was a parlement
(base) At Atthenes / vpon a certeyn point and caas
(base) Among the whiche pointes / yspoken was
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) To haue / with certeyn contrees alliance
(base) And haue fully / of Thebans obeisance
(base) For which / this noble Theseus anon
(base) Leet senden / after gentil Palamon
(base) Vnwist of hym / what was the cause and why
(base) But in his blake clothes / sorwefully
(base) He cam at his comandement / in hye
(base) Tho sente Theseus / for Emelye
(base) ¶ Whan they were set and hust was al the place
(base) And Theseus / abiden hath a space
(base) Er any word / cam from his wise brest /
(base) His eyen sette he / ther as was his lest
(base) And with a sad visage / he siked stille
(base) And after that right thus he seyde his wille
(base) ¶ The firste moeuere / of the cause aboue
(base) Whan he first made / the faire cheyne of loue
(base) Greet was theffect and heigh was his entente
(base) Wel wiste he why / and what ther of he mente
(base) For with that faire cheyne of loue he boond
(base) The fyr the Eyr / the water / and the loond
(base) In certeyn boundes / that they may nat flee
(base) That same Prince / and that moeuere quod he
(base) Hath stabliced / in this wrecched world adoun
(base) Certeine dayes / and duracioun
(base) To al / that is engendred / in this place
(base) Ouer the which day / they may nat pace
(base) Al mowe they yet / tho dayes abregge
(base) Ther nedeth / noon auctoritee to allegge
(base) For it is proued / by experience
(base) But that me list declaren my sentence
(base) Thanne may men wel / by this ordre discerne
(base) That thilke moeuere / stable is and eterne
(base) Wel may men knowe / but it be a fool
(base) That euery part. is diryued from his hool
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) For nature / hath nat taken his bigynnyng
(base) Of no partie / or of cantel of a thyng
(base) But of a thyng. that parfit is and stable
(base) Descendynge so / til it be corrumpable
(base) And therfore / for his wise purueiaunce
(base) He hath / so wel biset his ordinaunce
(base) That specis of thynges / and progressions
(base) Shullen enduren / by successions
(base) And noght eterne / withouten any lye
(base) This maist thow vnderstonde / and seen at Iye
(base) ¶ Loo the ook / that hath so long a norisshynge
(base) Fro the tyme / that it first gynneth sprynge
(base) And hath so long a lyf / as ye may see
(base) Yet at the laste / wasted is the tree
(base) ¶ Considreth eek / how that the harde stoon
(base) Vnder oure foot on which we ryde and goon
(base) It wasteth / as it lyth by the weye
(base) The brode Ryuer / som tyme wexeth dreye
(base) The grete townes / se we wane and wende
(base) Thanne se ye / that al this thyng hath ende
(base) Of man and womman / se we wel also
(base) That nedeth / in oon of thise termes two
(base) This is to seyn / in youthe / or ellis age
(base) He moot be deed / the kyng as shal a page
(base) Som in his bed / som in the depe see
(base) Som in the large feeld / as ye may se
(base) Ther helpeth noght al gooth that ilke weye
(base) Thanne may I seyn / that al this thyng moot deye
(base) What maketh this but Iuppiter the kyng
(base) That is Prince / and cause of alle thyng
(base) Conuertyng al vnto his propre welle
(base) From which it is diryued sooth to telle
(base) And heer agayns / no creature on lyue
(base) Of no degree / auailleth for to stryue
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) ¶ Thanne is it wisdom / as it thynketh me
(base) To maken vertu / of necessitee
(base) And take it wel / that we may nat eschue
(base) And nameliche / that to vs alle is due
(base) And who so gruccheth oght he dooth folye
(base) And rebel is / to hym that al may gye
(base) And certeinly / a man hath moost honour
(base) To dyen / in his excellence and flour
(base) Whan he is siker / of his goode name
(base) Thanne hath he doon / his freend ne hym no shame
(base) And gladder oghte / his freend been of his deeth
(base) Whan with honour / yolden is vp his breeth
(base) Than whan his name / apalled is for age
(base) For al forgeten is his vasselage
(base) Thanne is it best as for a worthy fame
(base) To dyen / whan he is best of name
(base) ¶ The contrarie of al this / is wilfulnesse
(base) Why grucchen we / why haue we heuynesse
(base) That goode Arcite / of chiualrie flour
(base) Departed is / with duetee / and with honour
(base) Out of this foule prison / of this lyf
(base) Why gruccheth heere / his cosyn and his wyf /
(base) Of his welfare / that loueth hem so weel
(base) Kan he hem thank nay god woot neuer a deel
(base) That bothe his soule / and eek hem self offende
(base) And yet they mowe / hir lustes nat amende
(base) ¶ What may I conclude / of this longe serye
(base) But after wo / I rede vs to be merye
(base) And thanken Iuppiter / of al his grace
(base) And er we / departen from this place
(base) I rede we make / of sorwes two
(base) O parfit Ioye / lastynge euere mo
(base) And loketh now / wher moost sorwe is her Inne
(base) Ther wol I first amenden and bigynne
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) ¶ Suster quod he / this is my ful assent
(base) With al thauys / heer of my parlement
(base) That gentil Palamon / youre owene knyght
(base) That serueth yow / with wyl and herte myght
(base) And euere hath doon / syn ye first hym knewe
(base) That ye shal of youre grace vpon hym rewe
(base) And taken hym / for housbond and for lord
(base) Leen me youre hond / for this is oure acord
(base) Lat se now / of youre wommanly pitee
(base) He is / a kynges brother sone pardee
(base) And thogh he were / a poure Bachiler
(base) Syn he hath serued yow / so many a yeer
(base) And had for yow / so greet aduersitee
(base) It moste been considred / leueth me
(base) For gentil mercy / oghte to passen right
(base) ¶ Thanne seyde he thus / to Palamon the knyght
(base) I trowe / ther nedeth litel sermonyng
(base) To make yow / assente to this thyng
(base) Com neer / and taketh youre lady by the hond
(base) Bitwixe hem / was maad anon the bond
(base) That highte matrymoigne / or mariage
(base) By al the conseil / and the Baronage
(base) And thus / with alle blisse / and melodye
(base) Hath Palamon / ywedded Emelye
(base) And god / that al this world hath wroght
(base) Sende hym his loue / that hath it deere aboght
(base) For now is Palamon / in alle wele
(base) Lyuynge in blisse / in richesse / and in heele
(base) And Emelye / hym loueth so tendrely
(base) And he / hir serueth so gentilly
(base) That was ther no word hem bitwene
(base) Of Ialousie / or any oother teene
(base) Thus endeth Palamon / and Emelye
(base) And god saue / al this faire compaignye Amen
(base) ¶ Here is ended / the knyghtes tale
