div.l: Here beginneth the Prolog of the Millere .

l.hi: W
han that the knight had thus his tale Itolde .

div.l: In al the company nas ther yong ne olde
That he ne seide it was a noble story
And worthi to be drawen in memory
And namely the gentiles euericheon
Oue oost lough ⁊and swore so mot I goon
This goth a riȝt vnbokeled is the male
Lat se now who shal telle an othir tale
For truly the game is wel bigonne
Now telleth ye sir monk if ye conne
Somwhat to quyte with the kniȝtes tale
The miller that dronken was al pale
So that vnnethe vpon his hors he sat
He nolde aualen neithir hode ne hat
Ne abide noman for his curtesie
But in pilates voice he gan to crie
And swore by armes blood and bones
I can a noble tale for the nones
With the which I wil quite now the kniȝtes tale
Oure oost sauȝ that he was dronken of Ale
And seide abide robyn leue brothir
Som bettir man shal telle first an othir
Abide and lat us werken thriftily
By goddes soule qd he that wil nat I
For I wil speke orellis go my wey
Oure oost answerid telle on a deuelwey
Thou art a fole thi wit is ouercome
Now herkeneth qd the Miller all ⁊and some
But first I make a protestacioıı̄un
That I am dronke I knowe it be my soun
And therfor if I mysspeke or say
Wite it the Ale of Southwerk I pray
For I will telle a legende and a lif
Bothe of a Carpenter and of his wif
Hou that a Clerk hath set the wriȝtes cappe
The Reue answered and seid stynt thi clappe
Let be thi leude dronken harlotrie
It is a synne and eke gret folie
To apeyren any man or him defame
And eke to bringe wyues in such fame
Thou maist Inouȝ of othir thinges sayn
This dronken Miller spak full sone again
And seid leue brothir Osewolde
Who that hath no wif is non Cokewolde
But I say therfor thou art oon
Ther bene ful gode wyues many oon
Whi art thou angry with my tale now
I haue a wif parde as wel as thou
Yet nolde I for the oxen in my plouȝ
Take vpon me more than I now
As demen of my self that I were oon
I wol bileue that I am noon
An husbond shal nat be inquisitif
Of goddis priuite nor of his wif
So he may fynden goddes foisoıı̄un there
Of the remenᵘnt nedeth not to enquere
What shuld I more sein but this Meller
He nolde his wordes for noman forbere
But tolde his cherles tale in his maner
Me thinketh that I shall reherce it here
And therfor eueri gentill wiȝt I prey
Demeth nouȝt for goddes loue that I sey
Of yuel entent but for I mot reherce
Here tales alle be thei better or werse
Orellis falsen som of my matiere
And therfor who so list it nouȝt here The miller
Torne ouer the leef and chese an othir tale
For ye shul fynde I nouȝ gret and smale
Of storial thing that toucheth gentilnesse
And eke moralite and holinesse
Blameth nat me if that ye chese amys
The Miller is a cherl ye knowe wel this
So was the Reue eke and othir moo
And harlotrie they tolden bothe twoo
Auiseth you and put me out of blame
And eke men shal not make ernest of game .
Here is ended the Prolog of the Meller And here beginneth his tale folwing .

l.hi: W
hilom ther was dwelling at Oxenford

div.l: A riche gnoff that gestes helde to borde
And of his craft he was a carpenter
With him ther was dwelling a pouer scoler
Had lerned art but all his fantasie
Was for torned for to lere astrologie
And coude a certain conclusions
To demen by interogacions
If that men axed him in certein houres
Whan that men shuld haue droute orellis shoures
Or if men axed him what shuld falle
Of eueri thing I may not reken alle
This Clerc was cleped hende Nicholas
Of derne loue he coude and of solace
And therto he was riȝt sly and ful pryue
And like a mayden meke for to see
A chambre had he in that hostelrie
Allone withoute any companye
Ful fetysly diȝt with herbes soote
And he him self as swete as is the roote The millers :
Of licorice or of any setevaile
His almagist his bokes gret and smale
His astrelap longing for his art
His augrym stones layen faire a part
On shelues couched at his beddes hede
His presse I couered with a faldyng rede
And al a boue ther lay a gay sautrie
On which he made a niȝt melodie
So swetely that al the chambre ronge
And Angelus ad Virginem he song
And aftir that he song the kinges note
Ful often blissed was his mery throte
And thus the swete clerc his tyme spent
Aftir his frendes finding and his rent
This Carpenter had wedded a newe wif
Which that he loued more than his lif
Of xviij yere she was of age
Ielouse he was and helde her narwe in cage
For she was wilde and yong and he was olde
And demed him self to ben like a Cokewolde
He knew nat Caton for his wit was rude
That bad men shuld wedde his similitude
Men shuld wedde aftir hir estat
For youthe and elde is often at debat
But sithe that he was fallen in the snare
He most endure as othir folk his care
Faire was this yong wif and ther with all
As any wesell her body gent ⁊and small
A ceynt she wered barred al of silk
A barmecloth as white as morne milk
Vpoıı̄un her lendes full many a gore
White was hir smok ⁊and brouded all bifore
And eke behinde on her coler aboute
Of cole blak silk withynne ⁊and eke withoute tale .
The tapes of the white voliper
Were of the same sute of hir coler
Hir felet birde of silk and set full hye
And sikerly she had a likerous ye
Ful smal I pulled wered her browes ij
And tho were bent and blak as any sloo
She was ful more blisfull for to see
Than is the newe pere Ienet tree
And softer than the wolle is of a whethir
And by hir girdill heng a purs of lethir
Tassed with silk apparailed with latoıı̄un
In all this world to seken vp and doun
Ther nys noman so wys that couthe thenche
So gay a popelott or such a wenche
Full briȝter was the shyning of hir hewe
Than in the tour the noble I forged newe
But all her song it was so loude and yerne
As any swalwe sitting on the berne
Therto she couthe skippe and make a game
As any kid or calf folwing her dame
Her mouth was swete as bragot or the methe
Or hoord of aples laid in hey or hethe
Wynsing she was as is a ioly colt
Long as a mast and vpriȝ as a bolt
A broche she bar on her loue coler
As brode as is the bose of a bokeler
Her shoes were laced on her leggis hye
She was a primerore a pygges ye
For any lord to liggen in his bed
Or yet for any gode yoman to wedde
Now sir and eft sir and so befell the caas
That on a day this hende Nicholas
Fill with this yong wif to rage and to play
While that hir husbond was at Osenay The millers :
As clerkes ben full subtill and full queynte
All priueli he cauȝt her by the queynte
And seid I wis but if I haue my wille
For derne loue of the lenmman I spille
And helde her hard by the haunche bones
And seid leman loue me wel at ones
Or I will dien also god me saue
And she sprong as a colt doth in the traue
And with her hed she wried fast awey
She seid I will nat kisse the be my fey
Fy lat be qd ich lat be Nicholas
Or I will crie out harrow and allas
Do your hondes for your curtesye
This Nicholas gan mercy for to crie
And spak so faire and profered him so fast
That she her loue graunted him at the last
And swore her othe be seint Thomas of kent
That she wolde be at his cōmmaundement
Whan that she may her leiser wel aspie
Myn husbond is so full of ielousie
That but ye waite wel and be priue
I wot riȝt wel I nam but ded qd she
Ye mot be ful derne as in this caas
Nay therof care ye not qd Nicholas
A clerc hath litherly bisett his while
But if he coude a carpenter begile
And thus thei accorded arn and I sworn
To waite a tyme as I haue told biforn
Whan Nicholas had don thus eueri dell
That thakked her aboute the lendes well
He kist her swete and takith his sautrie
And plaieth fast and makith melodie
Than fell it thus that to the parissh chirche
Cristes owne werkes for to werche tale .
This gode wif went on an haliday
Hir forhed shone as briȝt as any day
So was it wasshe whan she bet her werke
Now was there of that chirche a parissh clerk
The which that was I clepid Absoloıı̄un
Crull was his heer and as the gold it shone
And strouted as a fan large and brode
Ful streite and euene lay his ioly shode
His heed was red his eyen grey as glas
With poules windowe coruen on his shoes
In hoses rede he went fetisly
I clad he was full smal and propirly
All in a kirtill of a liȝt waget
Ful faire and thikke ben the pointes set
And therupoıı̄un he had a gay surplice
As white as is the blosme on the rys
A mery child he was as god me saue
Wel couthe he lete blood or clippe and shaue
And make a chartre of lond or quytaunce
In xxᵗy maner couthe he trippe and daunce
Aftir the scole of Oxenford tho
And with his legges casten to and froo
And pleien songes on a smale ribible
Therto he song somtyme a loude quynible
And as wel coude he pley on a giterne
In all the toun nas brewhous ne tauerne
That he ne visited with his solas
Ther any gaylard tapster was
But to sein he was somdel squaymous
Of farting and of speche daungerous
This Absoloıı̄un that ioly was and gay
Goth with A senser on the holiday
Sensing the wyues of the parissh fast
And many a loueli look on hem he cast The millers :
And namely on this Carpenteres wif
To loke on her he thouȝt a mery lif
She was so propre and swete and licorous
I dar wel sayn and if she had ben a mous
And he a Catte he wolde her hent anoıı̄un
This parissh Clerk this ioly Absoloıı̄un
Hath in his herte such A loue longing
That of no wif toke he non offryng
For curtesye he seide he wolde nooıı̄un
The mone whan it was niȝt ful briȝt shone
And Absoloıı̄un hath his giterne I take
For ꝑper/paramours he thouȝt for to wake
And forth he goth iolif and amerous
Til he come to the carpenteres hous
A litell aftir cokkes hadden I crowe
And dressid him vp by a shoot wyndowe
That was vpon the carpenteres wall
He singeth in his voice gentil and small
Now dere lady if thi wille be
I pray you that ye will rewe on me
Ful wel actordaunt to his giterning
This Carpenter awok and herd him synge
And spak vnto his wif and said anooıı̄un
What Alison herest thou nat Absoloıı̄un
That chaunteth thus vnder oure boures wall
And she answered her husbond ther with all
Yes god wot Iohıı̄un I here it eueri dell
This passeth forth what wol ye bet than well
Fro day to day this ioly Absoloıı̄un
So woweth hir that him is woo bigoıı̄un
He waketh all the niȝt and all the day
He kembeth his lokkis brode and makith him gay
He woweth hir by menes and by brocage
And swore he wold be hir owne page tale .
He singeth brokkyng as a nitingale
He sent her pyment methe ⁊and spiced Ale
And wafres piping hoot out of the glede
And for she was of toune he profered mede
For som folk wol be wonnen for richesse
And som for strokes and som for gentilnesse
Som tyme to shewe his liȝtnesse ⁊and mastrie
He plereth heroudes vpon a scaffold hye
But what auaileth him as in this caas
She loueth so this hende Nicholas
That Absolon may blowe the bukkes horn
He ne hath for his labour but a scorne
And thus she makith Absoloıı̄un hir Ape
And al his ernest torneth til A iape
For soth is this prouerbe it is no lie
Men seyn riȝt thus alwey the neigh slye
Maketh the fer leef to be loth
For thouȝ that Absolon be wood or wroth
Be cause that he fer was from hir siȝt
This ny Nicholas stood in his liȝt
Now bere the wel hende Nicholas
For Absolon may waile and syng allas
And so befel it on a satirday
This Carpenter was goon to Osenay
And hende Nicholas and Alisoıı̄un
Accorded ben to this conclusioıı̄un
That Nicholas shal shappen him a while
This sely ielouse husbond to bigile
And if so be the game went ariȝt
She shuld slepen in his armes al niȝt
For this was his desire and hir also
And riȝt anoon withoute wordes moo
This Nicholas no lenger wold tarie
But doth ful softe vnto his chambre carie The Millers
Bothe mete and drink for a day or twey
And to hir husbond bad her for to sey
Yf that he asked aftir Nicholas
She shuld sey she nist where he was
Of all that day she sy him nouȝt with eye
She trowed that he was in maladie
For no cry her mayde coude him calle
He nolde nat answere for no thing that miȝt falle
This passeth forth all thilke satirday
That Nicholas stille in his chambre lay
And ete and slep or did what him list
Till sonday that the sonne goth to reste
This sely Carpenter hath gret merueyle
Of Nicholas or what thing shuld him eyle
And said I am drad be seint Thomas
It stondeth nat ariȝt with Nicholas
God shield that he died sodeinly
This world is now ful tikell sikerly
I sy to day a corps born to chirche
That now on monday last I sy him wirche
Go vp qd he to his knaue anoıı̄un
Clepe at his dore or knokke with a stooıı̄un
Loke hou it is and telle me boldely
This knaue goth him vp full sturdily
And yet at the chambre dore while that he stood
He cried and knokked as that he were wood
What hou what do ye maistir Nicholay
Hou may ye slepen all the long day
But al for nouȝt he herd nouȝt o worde
An hole he fond full lowe vpoıı̄un a borde
Ther as the Cat was wont in for to crepe
And at the hole he loked yn ful depe
And at the last he had of him a siȝt
This Nicholas sat euer gaping vpriȝt tale .
As he had kiked on the newe mone
Adoun he goth and tolde his maister sone
In what array he sauȝ this ilke man
This Carpenter to blisse him bigan
And seid help us seint Frideswide
A man wot litill what shal him bitide
This man is falle with his astronomye
In som wodenesse or in som agonye
I thouȝt ay wel hou it shuld be
Men shuld nat knowe of goddes priuite
Ye blessid be alwey a leude man
That nouȝt but oonly his bileue can
So ferde an othir Clerc with astronomye
He walkid in the feldes for to prie
Vpoıı̄un the sterres what ther shuld bifalle
Till he was in a marlepit in a falle
He sauȝ not that but yet be seint Thomas
Me reweth sore of hende Nicholas
He shal be rated of his studiyng
If that I may by Ihıı̄uns heuene kyng
Gete me a staf that I may vnderspore
While that thou robyn heuest vp the dore
He shal out of his studying as I gesse
And to the chambre dore he gan him dresse
His carle was a strong carle for the nones
And by the haspe he hof it vp at ones
In the flore the dore fill anoıı̄un
This Nicholas sat ay as stille as stooıı̄un
And euer gaped vpward in the aire
This Carpenter wende that he were in despeir
And hent him by the shuldres miȝtily
And shoke him hard and cried spitously
What Nicholay what how loke adoun
Awake and thenke on cristes passioıı̄un The millers .
I crouche the from elues and fro wiȝtes
There wᵗith the niȝt spell seid he anoıı̄un ariȝtes
On iiij halwes of the house aboute
And on the thresshold on the dore withoute
Ihıı̄un crist and seint Benediȝtt
Blisse this hous from eueri wickid wiȝt
For the niȝtes verie the white Pater noster
Wher wonest thou seint Petres sustir
And at the last this hende Nicholas
Gan for to sike sore and seide allas
Shal all the world be lost eftsones now
This Carpenter answerid what seist thou
What thynke on god as we doıı̄un men that swynke
This Nicholas answerid fecche me drinke
And aftir wol I speke in priuite
Of certein thing that toucheth the and me
I wol telle it non othir man certein
This Carpenter goth doun and cometh agein
And brouȝt of miȝty ale a large quart
And whan that ech of hem had dronken his part
This Nicholas his dore fast shette
And doun the carpenter by him he sette
And seide Iohıı̄un myn oost lief and dere
Thou shalt vpoıı̄un thi trouthe swere me here
That to no wiȝt thou shalt this counseil wreie
For it is cristes counseill that I sey
And if thou telle it man thou art for lore
For this vengeaunce thou shalt haue therfor
That if thou wrey me thou shalt be wood
Nay crist forbede for his holi blood
Qd tho this seli man I nam no labbe
Ne thouȝ I sey I nam not lief to gabbe
Sey what thou wilt I shal it neuer telle
To child ne wif by him that haried helle tale .
Now Iohıı̄un qd Nicholas I will nouȝt lye
I haue founden in myn astrologye
As I haue loked in the mone briȝt
That now on monday next at quarter niȝt
Shal falle a reyn and that so wilde and wode
That half so gret was neuer Noes floōmd
This worlde he seide in lesse tyme than an houre
Shall all be dreynt so hidous is the shoure
Thus shal mankynde drenche and lese her lif
This Carpenter answered allas my wif
And shall she drenche allas myn Alisoıı̄un
For sorwe of this he fell almost adoun
And seide is ther no remedie in this caas
Whi yes for god qd hende Nicholas
Yf thou wilt werken aftir lore and reed
Thou maist not werken aftir thine oune hede
For this Salamoıı̄un that was ful trewe
Werke all by my counseill ⁊and thou shalt not rewe
And if thou werken wolt by my counseill
I vndertake withoute mast or saile
Yet shall I saue her the and me
Hast thou nat herd hou saued was Noe
Whan that oure lord had warned him biforıı̄un
That all the world with water shuld be lorıı̄un
Yes qd this Carpenter full yore a goo
Hast thou nat herd qd Nicholas also
The sorwe of Noe with his felaship
Or he miȝt gete his wif to ship
Him had beleuer I dar wel vndertake
Thilke tyme than alle his whetheres blake
That she had had a ship hir self allone
And therfor wost thou what is best to done
This axeth haste and of an hastif thing
Men may not preche or make tarying The millers
Anoıı̄un go gete us faste in to this Inne
A kneding trow orellis a kemelyn
For eche of us but loke that thei be large
In which we mowen swymmen as in a barge
And han therynne vitailes suffisaunt
But for a day fy on the remenᵘnt
The water shal a slake and gon awey
A boute Prime vpon the nexte day
But Robyn may nouȝt not wite of this thi knaue
And eke thi mayde Gille I may nouȝt saue
Axe not whi for thouȝ thou axe me
I wol nouȝt tellen goddis priuite
Sufficeth the but if thi wittes mad
To haue as gret a grace as Noe had
Thi wif shal I wel sauen out of doute
Go now thi wey and spede the here aboute
But whan thou hast for hir and the and me
I geten vs these kneding tubbes three
Than shalt thou hang hem in the roof full hye
That noman of oure purueiauᵘnce aspie
And whan thou thus hast doıı̄un as I haue seid
And hast oure vitaile faire in hem leide
And eke an ax to smyte the corde a too
Whan that the water cometh that we may goo
And breke an hole on hy vpoıı̄un the gable
Vnto this gardyn ward ouer the stable
That we may frely passen forth oure wey
Whan that the grete shoure is gon awey
Than shalt thou swymme as merye I vndertake
As doth the white doke aftir his drake
Than wol I clepe hou Alisoıı̄un hou Iohıı̄un
Be merye for the flode wol passe anoıı̄un
And thou wilt seyn heil maistir Nicholay
Gode morwe I see the wel for it is day tale .
And than shul we be lordes all oure lif
Of all the worlde as Noe and his wif
But of o thing I warne the full riȝt
Be wel auised on that ilke niȝt
That we ben entred in to the shippes borde
That noıı̄un of vs ne speke nouȝt o worde
Ne clepe ne crie but ben in his praier
For it is goddes owne hest dere
Thi wif and thou mot hange fer atwynne
For that bitwix you shal be no synne
Nomore in loking than ther shal in dede
This ordenᵘnce is seid go god the spede
To morwe at niȝt whan thei ben alle a slepe
In to oure kneding tubbes wol we crepe
And sitten there abiding goddes grace
Go now thi wey I haue no lenger space
To make of this no lenger sermonyng
Men sein thus send the wise and sey no thing
Thou art so wys it nedeth nat to teche
Go saue oure lif and that I the beseche
This sely Carpenter go forth his wey
Ful ofte he seide allas and welawey
And to his wif he tolde his priuite
And she was war and knewe it bet than he
What al this queynte cast was for to sey
But natheles she ferde as she wolde deye
And seid Allas go forth thi wey anoıı̄un
Helpe us to scape orellis we ben ded echoıı̄un
I am thi trewe verry weddid wif
Go dere spouse and help to saue oure lif
Loo which a gret thing is affeccioıı̄un
Men may die of Imaginacioıı̄un
So depe may impression be take
This sely Carpenter begynneth quake The millers .
Him thenketh verreylich that he may see
Noes flode come walking as the see
To drenchen Alison his hony dere
He wepeth waileth he makith sory chiere
He siketh with many a full sory swough
And goth and geteth him a kneding trough
And aftir a tubbe and a kemelyn
And priuily he sent hem to his Inne
And henge in the roof in priuitee
His owne hand he made ladderes thre
And clymben by the ronges and by the staues
Therto leten as men dwelling for drede in Caves
And hem vitailed bothe trough and tubbe
With brede and chese and gode Ale in a Iubbe
Suffising riȝt I nouȝ as for a day
But or that he had mad al this array
He sent his knaue and eke his wenche also
Vpoıı̄un his nede to londoıı̄un for to go
And on the monday whan it drouȝ to niȝt
But shet his dore withoute candel liȝt
And dressid all thing as it shuld be
And shortly vp thei clomben all three
They setten stille wel a forlong way
Now Pater noster Clum qd Nicholay
And Clum qd Iohıı̄un and Clum qd Alisoıı̄un
This Carpenter seide his deuocioıı̄un
And stille he sat and biddeth his praier
Awaiting on the rayn if he it here
The ded sleep for wery besinesse
Fil on this carpenter riȝt as I gesse
Aboute curfew tyme or litil more
For trauaile of his gost he groneth sore
And ofte he routeth for his hed mys lay
Doun on the laddere stalketh Nicholay tale .
And Alisoun ful softe a doun she spedde
Withouten wordes mo thei goıı̄un to bedde
Ther as the carpenter is wont to lye
Ther was the reuel and the melodie
And thus lieth Alison and Nicholas
In besinesse of mirthe and in solas
Til that the belle of laudes gan to rynge
And freres in the chauncel gan to synge
¶ This parissh Clerc this amerous Absoloıı̄un
That is for loue alwey so woo bigooıı̄un
Vpon the monday was at Osenay
With company him to disport and play
And asked vpon a caas a cloisterer
Ful priueli aftir Iohıı̄un the Carpenter
And he drow him apart out of the chirche
And seid I not I sauȝ him here nat wirche
Sith satirday I trowe that he be went
For tymber ther oure Abbot hath him sent
For he is wont for tymbre for to goo
And dwellen at the Graunge a day or two
Orellis he is at his house certein
Where that he be I can nouȝt sothely sayn
This Absolon ful ioly was and liȝt
And thouȝt now is tyme to wake al niȝt
For sikerly I sauȝ him not stiryng
Aboute his dore syn day bigan to springe
So mote I thryue I shal at Cok crowe
Full priueli knokken at his wyow
That stant ful lowe vpoıı̄un his boures wall
To Alisoıı̄un now wol I tellen all
My loue longing for yet I shal not misse
That at the leest wey I shal here kisse
Som maner comfort shal I haue parfay
My mouth hath icchid al this long day The Millers :
That is a signe of kissing at the leest
All niȝt me met eke I was at feest
Therfor I will go sleep an houre or twey
And all the niȝt than wol I wake and pley
Whan that the first cok hath crowe anoıı̄un
Vprist this ioly louer Absoloıı̄un
And him arraieth gay at point deuys
But first he cheweth greynes and licorys
To smellen soote or he had kempt his heer
Vnder his tunge a trewe loue he bere
For therby wende he to be gracious
He rometh to the Carpenters house
And stille he stant vnder the shoot windowe
Vnto his breest it rauȝt it was so lowe
And softe he couȝhed with a semy soun
What do ye hony combe swete Alisoıı̄un
My faire bird myn owne Cynamome
Awaketh lemman myn and spekith to me
Wel litill thinken ye vpoıı̄un my woo
That for your loue I swete there I goo
No wonder is thouȝ that I swelt and swete
I moᵘurne as doth the lambe aftir the tete
I wys lemman I haue such loue longing
That lik a turtil trewe is my moᵘurnyng
I may not eten nomore than a maide
Go fro the windowe Iak fool she saide
As help me god it wol nat be come ba me
I loue an othir orellis I were to blame
Wel bet than the by Ihıı̄un Absoloıı̄un
Go forth thi wey or I wil caste a stooıı̄un
And let me slepe a xxᵗy deuel wey
Allas qd Absolon and welawey
That true loue was euer so euill biset
Than kisse me syn it may not be no bet tale .
For Ihıı̄uns loue and for the loue of me
Wilt nat thou than go thi wey ther with qd she
Ye certes lemman qd this Absoloıı̄un
Than make the redy qd she I come ailoıı̄un
This Absoloıı̄un doun set him on his knees
And seid I am a lord at alle degrees
For aftir this I hope ther cometh more
Lemman thi grace and swete bird thine ore
The window she vndoth and that in hast
Haue do qd she come of and spede the fast
Lest that oure neiȝbours the espie
This Absolon gan wipe his mouth ful drye
Derke was the niȝt as picche or as the cole
And at the windowe out she put her hole
And Absolon him fill no bet ne wers
But with his mouth he kissed hir naked ars
Ful sauerly or he wer war of this
A bak he stert and thouȝt it was amys
For wel he wist a womman hath no berde
He felt a thing I rouȝ and long I hered
And seid fy Allas what haue I doo
Te he qd she and clapt the windowe to
And Absolon goth forth a sory paas
A berde a berde seide hende Nicholas
By goddes corpus this goth faire and well
This seli Absolon herde it eueri dell
And on his lippe he gan for anger bite
And to him self he seid I shal the quite
Who rubbeth now who freteth now his lippes
With dust wᵗith sond wᵗith straw wᵗith cloth wᵗith chippes
But Absolon / that seith ful ofte Allas
My soule betake vnto Sathanas
But me were leuer than al this toun qd he
Of this despite awroken for to be The millers .
Allas qd he allas I ne had I bleynt
His hoot loue was colde and al I queynt
For fro the tyme that he had kist hir ars
Of ꝑper/paramours he set nouȝt a kers
For he was heled of his maladie
Ful ofte ꝑper/paramours he gan defie
And wepe as doth a child that is I bete
A softe paas he went ouer the strete
Vnto a smyth men clepe Daun Geruays
That in his forge smithed plouȝ harneis
He sharpeth share and culter besily
This Absolon knokketh all besily
And seid vnto Geruays and that anon
What who art thou it am I Absoloıı̄un
What Absoloıı̄un what cristes swete tree
Whi rise ye so rathe ey benedicite
What eileth you som gay gerle god it wot
Hath brouȝt you thus vpoıı̄un the veritot
Be seint Note ye wot wel what I mene
This Absoloıı̄un ne rouȝt not a bene
Of all his pley no word agein he gaf
He had more tow on his distaf
Than Gerueys knewe and seid frend so dere
The hote culter in thi chimeny here
As lene it me I haue therwith to done
I wil bringe it the agein ful sone
Gerueys answerid certes were it gold
Or in a poke nobeles all vntold
Thou shuldest haue as I am trewe smith
Ey cristes foo what wil ye do ther with
Therof qd Absolon be as be may
I shal wel telle the to morwe day
And cauȝt the culter by the colde stele
Full softe out at the dore he gan stele tale .
And went vnto the carpenters wall
He couȝhed first and knokked ther with all
Vpoıı̄un the window riȝt as he did ere
This Alisoıı̄un answered who is there
That knokketh so I warante it a theef
Whi nay qd he god wot my swete leef
I am Absoloıı̄un thine owne derlyng
Of gold qd he I haue the brouȝt a ryng
My moder yaue it me so god me saue
Ful fyn it is and therto wel I graue
This wil I yeuen the if thou me kisse
This Nicholas was risen for to pisse
And thouȝt he wold amenden all the iape
He shuld kisse his ars or that he scape
And vp the windowe did he hastili
And out his ars he put priuily
Ouer the buttok vnto the haunche booıı̄un
And ther with spak this clerk this Absoloıı̄un
Speke swete birde I not wher thou art
This Nicholas anoıı̄un let fle a fart
As gret as it had ben a thonder dynt
That wᵗith the strok he was almost I bleynt
And he was redy with his Iren hote
And Nicholas in the ars he smot
Of goth the skyn an hand brede aboute
The hote culter brenneth so his toute
And for the smert he wend for to dye
As he were wood for woo he gan to crie
Help water water help for goddes herte
This Carpenter out of his slomber sterte
And herd oon crien water as he were wode
And thouȝt allas now cometh Noes flode
And set him vp withoute wordes moo
And with an ax he smote the corde a two
And doun goth all he fonde neithir to selle
No brede ne Ale til he come to the celle
Vpoıı̄un the flore and there a swoune he lay
Vp stirt hir Alisoıı̄un and Nicholay
And cried out and harrow in the strete
The neiȝbours bothe smale and grete
In ronnen for to gauren on this man
That a swoune lay bothe pale and wan
For with that fall he brosten had his arme
But stonde he most to his owne harme
For whan he spak he was anoıı̄un bore doun
With hende Nicholas and Alisoun
They told eueri man that he was wood
He was agast so of Noes flood
Throuȝ fantasy that of his vanite
He had I bouȝt him kneding tubbes iij
And had hem hanged in the roof aboue
And that he preied hem for goddes loue
To sitten in the roof ꝑper/par company
The folk gan laughen at his fantasye
And to the roof thei kiken and thei gape
And torned all his harme vnto a iape
For what so this Carpenter answerid
It was for nouȝt noman his reson herd
With othes grete he was so sworn adoun
That he was holden wood in all the toun
For eueri Clerc anoıı̄un riȝt helde with othir
They seide the man was wood my leue brothir
And eueri wiȝt gan laughe at his strif
Thus swyued was the Carpenters wif
For all his keping and al his ielousie
And Absoloıı̄un hath kist her nethir eye
And Nicholas is scalded in his toute
This tale is don and god saue all the route h
Here is ended the Millers tale

div.l: And ther they setten steuene for to mete
And playen at the dys in such a strete
For in toun nas ther no prentice
That fairer coude cast a peire of dyce
Than Perkyn coude / and therto he was free
Of his dispence in place of priuite
That fond his maister wel in his chaffare
For oft tyme he fond his box full bare
For sikerli a prentice reuelour
That haunteth dys ryot or ꝑper/paramoᵘur
His maistir shal it in his shop a bye
Al haue he no part of the menstralcye
For thefte and ryott thei ben conuertible
Al can he play on giterne or ribible
Reuel and trouthe as in a lowe degree
They ben ful wroth al day as men may see
This ioly prentice with his mastir bode
Til he were ny out of his prentice hode
All were he snibbed bothe erly and late
And somtyme led with reuel to Newgate
But at the last his maistir him be thouȝt
Vpon a day whan he his papir souȝt
Of a prouerbe that seith this same word
Wel bet is roten apple out of hoord
Than that it rote al the remenᵃnt
So fareth it by a riotouse seruᵃnt
It is full lasse harme to lete him pace
Than he shende all the seruᵃntes in the place
Therfor his maistir yaf him acquetᵃunce
And bad him go with sorwe and with meschᵃunce
And thus this ioly prentice had his leue
Now let him all the niȝt or leue
And for ther is no theef withoute a louk
That helpeth him to waste and to souke
Of that he bribe can or borwe may
Anon he sent his bed and his array
Vnto a comper of his owne soort
That loued dys reuel and disport
And had a wif that helde for contenᵃnce
A shoppe / and swyued for her sustenᵃnce .

What shuld I tellen hem syn thei be tolde
In youthe he made of Ceys and Alcione
And sith hath he spoke of euerichron
Thise noble wyues and these louers eke
Who so that wol his large volume seke
Cleped the seyntes legende of Cupide
Ther may he seen the large woundes wide
Of lucresse and of Babilan Tisbe
The swerd of Dido for the false Ene
The tree of Phillis for her demophoıı̄un
The pleynt of Dyanyre and of Ermyoıı̄un
Of Adriane and of ysiphile
The barein Isle stonding in the see
The dreynt lyander for his erro
The terees of Eleyne and eke the woo
Of brixseide and of lodomya
The cruelte of the quene of Medea
The litel children hanging by the halse
For thi Iason that was of loue so fals
Oyꝑper/parmistra Penolope Alceste
Youre wifhod he comendeth with the beste
But certeinli no word writeth he
Of thilke wikke ensample of Canace
That loued hir owne brothir synfully
Of such cursed stories I say fy
Orellis of Tyro Appolloneus
Hou that cursed kyng Antiochus
Beraft his douȝter of hir maydenhede
That is so horrible a tale for to rede
Whan he here threwe vpon the pament
And therfor he of full auisement
Nolde neuer write in non of his sermouns
Of such vnkynde abhominacions
Ne I ne wol non reherce if that I may
But of my tale hou shal I do this day
Me were loth to be likned douȝteles
To muses that men clepyd pierides
Metamorphosos wot what I mene
But natheles I recche nouȝt a bene
Thouȝ I come aftir him with hawe bake
I speke in prose and let him rymes make
And with that word he with a sobre chiere
Began his tale as ye shall aftir here
Here endith the Prolog of the Man of Lawe
And here beginneth his tale folwing

l.hi: O hateful harme cōmdicion of pouerte

div.l: With thirst wᵗith colde wᵗith hunger so confounded
To aske helpe the shameth in thine herte
If thou ne axe with nede art thou so wounded
That verry nede vnwrappid al thi wounde hid
Maugre thine hede thou most for Indigence
Or stele or begge or borwe thi despence
Thou blamest crist and seist ful bitterly
He mys deꝑper/parteth richesse temꝑper/parall
Thi neiȝboᵘur thou witest synfully
And seist thou hast to litell ⁊and he hath al
Parfay thou seist somtyme he rekne shal
Whan his taile shal brenne in the glede
For he nouȝt helpeth nedefull in her nede
Herk what is the menyng of thise wise
Bet to dye is than to haue indigence
Thi self neiȝboᵘur wol the despise
If thou be pore farwel thi reuerence
Yet of the wise man take this sentence
Xlas the daies of pouer men ben wicke
Bewar therfor or thou come to that prikke
Yf thou be pouer thi brothir hateth the
And alle thi frendes fleen from the Allas
O riche Marchᵃuntes full of wele be ye
O noble prudent folk as in this caas
Your bagges ben not filled with ambes aas
But with Sys synk that renneth for your chᵃunce
At cristemasse mery mot we daunce
Ye seken lande and seefor your wynnyng
As wise men ye knowe all the estat
Of Regnes ye ben fadres of tydinges
And tales bothe of pees and of debat
I were riȝt now of tales desolat
Nor that a Marchaunt goon is many a yere
Me tauȝt a tale such as ye shal here
In surrye somwhile dwelt a company
Of chapmen riche and therto sad and true
That wide where sent her spicerye
Clothes of gold and satynes riche of hewe
Hir chaffare was so thrifty and so newe
That eueri wight had deynte to chaffare
With hem and eke to selle hem her ware
Now fil it that the maistres of that soort
Han shapen hem to Rome for to wende
Were it in chapmanhod or for disport
Non othir message wold they thider sende
But comen hem self to Rome this is the ende
And in such place as thouȝt hem auᵃntage
For hir entent to take hir herbigage
Soioᵘurned han this marchᵃuntes in that toun
A certein as fill to hir plesaunce
But so befell that the excellent renoıı̄un
Of the Emꝑper/parours douȝter Dame Custaunce
Reported was with eueri circumstaunce
Vnto the surrien marchᵃuntes in such wise
Fro day to day as I shall you deuise
This was the comune voice of eueri man
Oure Emꝑper/parour of Rome god him se
The doughter hath that sithen the world began
To rekne as wel hir godenesse as beaute
Nas neuer such an othir as is she
I pray to god in honour hir sustene
And wold she were of Europe the quene
In hir is high beaute withoute pride
Youthe withouten grenehode or foly
To all hir werkes vertu is her gide
Humblesse hath slayn in hir tyrannye
She is mirroᵘur of all curtesye
Her herte is verry Chamber of holinesse
Hir hond ministre of fredom for almesse
And all this voice was soth as god is trewe
But now to purpos lat us torne agein
Thise Marchᵃuntes han don frauȝt hir shippes newe
And when they han this blisfull maide sayn
Hom to Surrye beth they went agein
And don here nedes as they haue don yore
And lyuen in wele I can sey you namore
Now fill it that thise Marchᵃuntez stoden in grace
Of him that was the Soudan of Surry
For whan they come from any straunge place
He wold of his benigne curtesye
Maken hem gode chiere and besili aspie
Tidinges of sondri roialines for to lere
The wondres that they miȝt seen or here
Amonges othir thinges specially
The Marchᵃuntez han told him of Dam Custaunce
So gret nobelesse in ernest seriously
That this soudan hath cauȝt so gret plesaunce
To han hir figure in his remembrᵃunce
And al his lust and al his besi cure
Was for to loue hir whiles her lif wold dure
Paraduenture in thilke large book
Which that cleped heuene I write was
With sterres whan that he his birth took
That he for loue shuld han deth Allas
For in the sterres clerer than is glas
Is write god wot who so coude it rede
The deth of eueri man withoute drede
In sterres many a wynter ther biforn
Was writen the deth of Ector Achilles
Of pompe Iulius or they were born
The strif of Thebes and of hercules
Of sampsoıı̄un turnus and of Socrates
The deth but mēmnes wittes ben so dulle
That no wiȝt can rede it at the fulle
This Soudan for his priue counseil sent
And shortly of this mater for to pace
He hath to hem declared his entent
And seith hem certein but he miȝt han grace
To han Custaunce with him in litil space
That he nas but ded and charged hem in hye
To shapen for his lif som remedie
Diuerse men diuerse thinges seiden
They argumentez casten vp and doun
Many a subtil reson forth thei leyden
Thei speken of magik and ambusioıı̄un
But finally as in conclusioıı̄un
They can nouȝt seen in that noon quantite auᵃuntage
Ne in noon othir wey saue mariage
Than sauȝ thei ther yn such difficulte
By wey of resoıı̄un for to speke al pleyn
By cause that ther was such diuersite
Bitwen her bothe lawes that they sayn
They trowe that no cristen prince wolde fayn
Wedden hir childe vnder oure lawes so swete
That vs was tauȝt by Mahound oure ꝓprophete
And he answereth rather than I lese
Custaunce I wol be cristened douteles
I mot ben hirs I may non othir chese
I pray you holdeth your argumentes in pees
Saueth my lif and beth nouȝt recheles
To geten hir that hath my lif in cure
For in this woo I may nouȝt longe endure
What nedeth gretter dilatacioıı̄un
I sey be tretice and ambassaterie
And by the popes mediacioıı̄un
And all the chirche and the chiualrie
That in destruccioıı̄un of Maumetrye
And increse of cristes lawe dere
They ben accorded so as ye shal here
Hou that the Soudan and his baronage
And alle his lieges shuld I cristened be
And he shal han Custaunce in mariage
And certein gold I not what quantite
And herto founden sufficient surete
This same accord was sworn on eithir side
Now faire Custaunce Almiȝty god thi gide
Now wold som men waiten as I gesse
That I shuld tellen all the purueiaunce
That the Emꝑper/parour of his gret nobelesse
Hath shapen for his douȝter dame Custaunce
Wel may men knowen that so gret ordenᵃnce
May no man tellen in a litill clause
As was arraied for so hy a cause
Busshopis ben shapen with hir for to wende
Lordes and ladies kniȝtes of renoun
And othir folk I now this is the ende
And notified is throuȝ out the toun
That eueri wiȝt with gode deuocioıı̄un
Shuld pray crist that he this mariage
Receyue in gree and spede this viage
The day is come of her departing
I sey the the woful day fatal is come
That ther may be no lenger tarieng
But forthward they hem dresse alle ⁊and some
Custaunce that with sorwe al ouer come
Ful pale arist and dressed hir to wende
For wel she seeth ther is non othir ende
Allas what wonder is thouȝ she wepte
That shall be sent to straunge nacioıı̄un
Fro frendes that so tenderly her kepte
And to be bounden vnder subieccioıı̄un
Of oon she knewe nat his condicioıı̄un
Husbondes ben all gode and han ben yore
That knowen wyues I dar sey nomore
Fader she said in thi wrecchid child Custaunce
Thy yong douȝter fostered vp so soft
And ye my moder my souerain plesaunce
Ouer all thing out take crist on lofte
Custaunce your douȝter her recōmmendith ofte
Vnto your grace for I shall to Surrye
Ne shall I neuer seen you more with ye
Allas vnto the barbary nacioıı̄un
I most anon sithen it is your wille
But crist that starf for oure redempcioıı̄un
So yeue me grace his hestes to fulfille
I wrecche womman no force thouȝ I spille
Wommen arn born to thraldom ⁊and penᵃunce
And to ben vnder māmnes gouernᵃnce
I trowe at Troy whan Pirrus brak the wal
Or Ilion that brend Thebes the Citee
That Rome for the harme throuȝ hanybal
That Romayns han ventused tymes thre
Nas herd swich tendre weping for pitee
As in the chaunbre for hir departing
But forth she mot whethir she wepe or sing
O first moeuyng cruel firmament
With thi diurnal sweigh that croudest ay
And hurlest al fro Est til occident
That naturally wold holde an othir way
Thi crouding set the heuene in such array
At the bigynnyng of this fiers viage
That cruel Mars hath slayn this mariage
Infortunat ascendent tortuous
Of which the lord is helpeles falle Allas
Out of the angle in to the derkest hous
O Mars of Atazir as in this caas
O fieble Mone vnappy ben thi paas
Thou knittest the ther thou art not receyued
Ther thou were wel fro thennes art thou weyued
Inspirat Emꝑper/parour of Rome Allas
Was there no Philisophre in all thi toun
Is noon tyme bet than othir in such caas
Of viage is there noon eleccioıı̄un
Namely to folk of hiȝe condicioıı̄un
Nat whan a roote is of a birthe I knowe
Allas we ben to leude or to slowe
To ship is brouȝt this wofull faire mayde
Solempnely with eueri circumstaunce
Now Ihıı̄un crist be with you alle she saide
There is nomore but fare wel faire Custaunce
She pyneth her to make gode contenᵃnce
And forth I late her sailen in this manere
And torne I wol agein to my matere
The moder of this soudan welle of vices
Espied hath her sones pleyn entent
Hou he wolde lete his olde sacrifices
And riȝt anon she for hir counseil sent
And they ben comen to knowe what she ment
And whan assembled was all this folk I fere
She set her doun and seide as ye shal here
Lordes qd she ye knowen euerichon
Hou that my sone in point is for to lete
The holi lawes of oure alkaron
Youen by goddes message machomete
But oon avow to grete god I hete
The lif shal rather out of my body sterte
Or Machometes lawe out of myn herte
What shuld us tiden of this newe lawe
But thraldom to oure bodies and penᵃnce
And aftirward to helle to be drawe
For we reneied Mahoıı̄un oure creaunce
But lordes wol ye maken assuraunce
As I shal seyn assentyng to my lore
And I shal make vs saf for euermore
Thei sworen and assenten eueri man
To lyue with hir and die ⁊and by her stonde
And euerich in the best wise he can
To strengthen hir shal al his frendes fonde
And she hath this emprise I take on honde
Which ye shall heren that I shal deuise
And to hem alle she spak riȝt in this wise
We shal first feyne cristiendom to take
Colde water shall not greue vs but a lite
And I shall such a feste and reuel make
That as I trowe I shall the soudan quite
For thouȝ his wif be cristened neuer so white
She shal haue nede to wasshe awey the rede
Thouȝ she a font full of water wᵗith her lede
O soudenesse roote of Iniquite
Virago thou Semyran the seconde
O serpent vnder femynite
Like to the serpent depe in helle I bounde
O feyned womman that all may confounde
Vertu and Innocence throuȝ thi malice
Is bred in the as nest of eueri vice
O sathan enuyous syn thilke day
That thou were chaced from oure heritage
Wel knowest thou to wommen the olde way
Thou madest Eua to bringe in seruage
Thou wilt fordon this cristien mariage
Thi Instrumentes so welawey the while
Makest thou of wommen whan thou wilt bigile
This soudenesse whom I shal thus blame ⁊and warie
Let priuily her counsaill goon his way
What shulde I in this tale lenger tarie
She rideth to the soudan on a day
And seid him that she wold reneye hir lay
And cristiendom of prestes hondes fonge
Repenting her she hethen was so longe
Beseching him to don her that honoᵘur
That she most han the cristien folk to feste
To plesen hem I wol do my labour
The soudan seith I wol don at your heste
And kneling thanketh hir of that requeste
So glad he was he nist what to seye
She kist hir sone and hom she goth hir wey
Arryued ben these cristen folk to londe
In Surry with a gret solempne route
And hastlich this Soudan sent his sonde
First to his moder and all the reigne aboute
And seide his wif was come out of doute
And praied her to riden agein the quene
The honour of his reigne to sustene
Gret was the prees and riche was the array
Whan Surryens and Romaynes met I fere
The Moder of the soudan riche and gay
Receyueth her with als a glad chiere
As any Moder miȝt her douȝter dere
And to the nexe Citee there beside
A softe paas solempnely thei ride
Nouȝt trow I the triumphe of Iulius
Of which that lukan makith such a boost
Was rialler ne more curious
Then was the assemble of this blisfull oost
But this Scorpioıı̄un this wickid goost
The soudenesse for all flatering
Caste vnder this ful mortally to stynge
The Soudan cometh him self sone aftir this
So rially that wonder is to telle
He welcometh hir with all ioye and blisse
And thus in mirthe and ioye I lete hem dwelle
The frute of this mater is that I telle
Whan tyme come men thought it for the beste
That reuel stynte and men goon to reste
The tyme come this olde soudenesse
Ordeyned hath this feste of which I tolde
And to the feste cristien folk hem dresse
In generall bothe yong and olde
Here may men feste and rialte biholde
And deintees mo than I can you deuise
But al to dere thei bouȝt it or thei rise
O sodein woo that euer art successour
To worldly blis spreynd is with bitternesse
The ende of the ioye of oure worldly labour
Woo occupieth the fyn of oure gladnesse
Herk this counseill for thi sikernesse
Vpon thi glade day haue in thi mynde
The vnwar woo or harme that cometh behinde
For shortly for to tellen at a worde
The soudan and the cristien euericheoıı̄un
Been al to hewe ⁊and stiked at the borde
But it were oonly Dame Custaunce allone
This olde soudenesse this cursed kreoıı̄un
Hath with her frendes doon this cursed dede
For she hir self wolde al the contre lede
Ne ther nas Surryn noon that was conuerted
That of the counseil of the Soudan woot
That he nas all to hewe or he asterted
And Custaunce han thei take anon foot hoot
And in a ship al stierles god woot
Thei han hir set and bid her lerne saile
Out of Surry ageinward to ytaile
A certain tresour that she thider ladde
And soth to sain vitaile gret plente
They han her yeuen ⁊and clothes eke she hadde
And forth she saileth in the salt see
O my Custaunce full of benignite
O Emꝑper/parours yong douȝter dere
He that is lord ouer fortune be thi stere
She blissed her and with full pitous voice
Vnto the crosse of Crist thus said she
O clere O welefull auter holi croice
Rede of the lambes blood full of pitee
That wossh the worlde from the olde iniquite
Me fro the fende and his clawes kepe
That day that I shal drenchen in the depe
Uictoriouse tree proteccioıı̄un of trewe
That only worthi were for to bere
The kyng of heuene with his woundes newe
The white lambe that hurt was wᵗith a spere
Flemer of fendes out of him and her
On which thi lyues feithfully extenden
Me kepe and yeue me myght my lif to amenden
Yeres and daies flete this creature
Throuȝ oute the See of Grece vnto the straite
Of Marrok as it was hir auenture
O many a sory mele may she bayte
Aftir hir deth full often may she wayte
Or that the wilde wawes wil her dryue
Vnto the place there she shal arryue
Men miȝt axen whi she was not slayn
Eke at the feste / who miȝt her body saue
And I answere to that demaund agein
That eueri wiȝt saue he maistir or knaue
Who saued Daniel in the horrible Caue
Was with the lyon fret or he sterte
No wiȝt but god that he bar in his herte
God list to shewe his wonderful miracle
In hir that she shuld seen his miȝty werkes
Crist which that is to eueri harme triacle
By certein menes often as knowen Clerkes
Doth thing for certein ende that full derk is
To māmnes wit that for oure ignoraunce
Ne konne not knowe his prudent purueiauᵃnce
Now sith she was nouȝt at the feste I slawe
Who kept hir fro the drenching in the see
Who kept Ionas in the fisshes mawe
Til he was spouted vp at Nynyve
Wel may men knowen it was no wiȝt but he
That kepte peple Ebaryk fro drenching
With drie feet throuȝ out the See passing
Who bad the iiij spirites of the tempest
That power han to annoyen land and See
Bothe North and South ⁊and also west and Est
Anoyeth neithir See ne londe ne tree
Sothely the comaundoᵘur of that was he
That fro the tempest ay this womman kepte
As wel whan she wook as whan she slepte
Where might this womman mete ⁊and drink haue
Thre yere and more hou lasteth her vitaile
Who fedde the Egipcien Mary in the caue
Or in desert nouȝt but Crist saunz faile
Fyue thousand folk was as gret meruaile
With loues fyue and fisshes ij to fede
God sent his foison at hir gret nede ~
She dryueth forth to oure occian
Throuȝ oute wilde See til at last
Vnder an holde that nempnen I ne can
Fer in the Northumberland the wawe hir caste
And in the sond hir ship stiked so faste
That thennes wold it nouȝt of all a tide
The will of crist was that she shulde a bide
The Constable of the castell doun is fare
To seen this wrakke and al the ship he souȝt
And fonde the weri womman ful of care
He fonde also the tresour that she brouȝt
In her langage mercy she besought
The lif out of hir body for to twynne
Here to delyuer of woo that she was ynne
A maner latyn corrupt was hir speche
But algates ther by was she vnderstande
The Constable whan him list no lenger seche
This wofull womman brought he to londe
She kneleth doun and thanketh goddes sonde
But what she was she wold no man sey
For foule ne faire thouȝ that she shuld deye
She seide she was so amased in the see
That she forgat hir mynde be hir trouthe
The Conestable hath of hir so gret pitee
And eke his wif that thei wepen for routhe
She was so diligent withouten slouthe
To serue and please euerich in that place
That alle hir louen that loken on her face ~
The Conestable and Dame Ermegild his wif
Were Payens and of that contrey eueri where
But Ermegild loued hir riȝt as her lif
And Custaunce hath so longe soioᵘurned there
In Orisons with many a bitter tere
Til Ihıı̄un hath conuerted throuȝ his grace
Dame Ermegild Constablesse of that place
In all that lond no cristien dorst route
All cristien folk ben fled fro that contre
Throuȝ Payens that conquereden al a boute
The plages of the North by land and See
To wales fledde the Cristiante
The olde Britons dwelling in this Isle
Ther was her refute for the mene while ~
But yet more cristien Britons so exiled
That ther nas som in her priuite
Honoured crist and hethen folk begiled
And ny the castell such ther dwelten three
That oon of hem was blynd ⁊and miȝt not see
But it were with thik eyen of his mynde
With which men seen aftir that thei be blynde
Briȝt was the sonne as in that someres day
For which the constable and his wif also
And Custaunce han I take the riȝt way
Toward the See a forlong wey or ij
To playen and romen to and fro
And in her walk the blynde man they mette
Croked and olde with yen fast I shette ~
In the name of Crist cried this blynde bretoun
Dame Ermegild yeue me my siȝt agein
This lady wax affraied of that soun
Lest that her husbond shortly for to sayn
Wolde her for Ihesu cristes loue haue slayn
Til Custaunce mad hir bold ⁊and bad hir wirche
The will of Crist as douȝter of holi chirche ~
The Constable wax abasshed of that siȝt
And seide what amounteth all this fare
Custaunce answerid sir it is cristes miȝt
That helpeth folk out of the fendes snare
And so ferforth she gan oure lay declare
That she the constable or it was eue
Conuerteth and on crist made him bileue ~
This constable was no thing lord of this place
Of which I speke there he Custaunce fonde
But kept it strongly many a winter space
Vnder Alla kyng of Northumberland
That was full wise ⁊and worthi of his honde
Agein the Scottes as men may wel here
But torne I wol agein to my matere
Sathan that euer vs waiteth to bigile
Sauȝ of Custaunce all hir perfeccioıı̄un
And cast anon hou he miȝt quite hir while
And made a yong kniȝt that dwelt in the toun
Loue her so hote of foul affeccioıı̄un
That verrily him thouȝt he shuld spille
But he of her ones miȝt haue his wille ~
He woweth her but it auailleth nouȝt
She wolde no synne by no weye
And for despit he compased in his thouȝt
To make her on shamefull deth to dye
He waiteth whan the constable was awey
And priuily vpon a niȝt he crepte
In Ermegildes chambre whil she slepte ~
Wery forwaked in her Orisouns
Slepith Custaunce and Ermegild also
This kniȝt throuȝ sathanas temptacions
Alle softly is to the bed I goo
And cut the throte of Ermegild a two
And leid the blody knif by Dame Custaunce
And went his wey ther god yef him meschᵃunce
Sone aftir cometh this constable hom agein
And eke Alla that king was of that lond
And sauȝ his wif dispitously I slayn
For which full ofte he wepte ⁊and wrong his honde
And in the bed the blody knif he fonde
By dame Custaunce allas what miȝt she seye
For verri woo hir wit was all aweye ~
To kyng Alla was told all this meschᵃunce
And eke the tyme and wher and what wise
That in a ship was founde this Custaunce
As here beforn that ye han herd deuise
The kinges herte of pite gan arise
Whan he say so benigne a creature
disese and
For as the lambe toward his deth is brouȝt
So stant this Innocent befor the king
This false kniȝt that hath this tresoıı̄un wrouȝt
Bereth her on honde that she hath don this thing
But natheles ther was gret moᵘurnyng
Among the peple and sey they can not gesse
That she had don so gret a wikkidnesse ~
For thei han sein her euer so vertuous
And louing Ermegild riȝt as her lif
Of this bar witnesse euerich in the hous
Saue he that Ermegild slouȝ wᵗith his knif
This gentil kyng hath cauȝt a gret motif
Of this witnesse and thouȝt he wold enquere
Deppere in this caas a trouth for to lere ~
Allas Custaunce thou hast no champioıı̄un
Ne fiȝt canst thou not so welawey
But he that for oure redempcioıı̄un
Bond sathan and yet lith there he lay
So be thi strong Champioıı̄un this day
For but crist opene miracle kithe
Withouten gilt thou shalt be slayn as swithe ~
She sit hir doun on knees and thus she saide
Inmortal god that sauedest Susanne
Fro fals blame and thou merciful mayde
Mary I mene douȝter of seint Anne
Beforn whoz childe Aungels syng Osanne
If I be gilteles of this felonie
My socour be orellis shal I dye ~
Haue ye nat seyn somtyme a pale face
Among a prees of him that hath be lad
Toward his deth where grace
And such a colour in his face hath had
Men miȝt knowe his face that was bistad
Amonges alle the faces in that route
So stant Custance and loketh aboute ~
O quenes lyuyng in prosperite
Duchesses and the ladyes euerichoıı̄un
Haue som routhe on hir aduersite
An Emꝑper/parours douȝter stant allon
She hath no wiȝt to whom to make her mone
O blode roiall that stondest in this drede
Fer ben thi frendes at thi gret nede ~
This Alla king hath such compassioıı̄un
As gentil herte is full of pitee
That from his yen ran the water doun
Now hastlich doth fecche a book qd he
And if this knight wol sweren hou that she
This womman slow yet we wil vs auise
Whom that we wol that shal be oure iustice ~
A Bretoıı̄un book writen the Euᵃngiles
Was fet and on this book he swore anon
She giltif was and in the mene whiles
An hand him smot vpon the nekke boon
That doun he fel at ones as a stoon
And bothe his yen brusten out of his face
In siȝt of eueri body in that place ~
A voice was herd in generall audience
And seid thou hast dislaundred gilteles
The douȝter of holi chirche in hy presence
Thus hast thou doon and yet I holde my pees
Of this meruail agast was all the prees
And mazed folk they stoden euerichon
For drede of wrecche saue Custance allon
Grete was the drede and eke the repentᵃunce
Of hem that hadden wrong suspeccioıı̄un
Vpon this sely Inent Custaunce
And for this miracle in conclusioıı̄un
And by Custaunce mediacioıı̄un
The kyng and
Conuerted was thankid be cristes grace
This false kniȝt was slayn for his vntrouthe
By iugement of Alla hastili
And yet Custaunce had of his deth gret routhe
And aftir this Ihesus of his mercy
Made Alla wedde ful solempnely
This ioly maiden that is so briȝt and shene
And thus hath Crist made Custaunce a quene ~
But who was wofull if I shal not lye
Of this wedding but Donegild and nomo
The kynges moder full of Tyrannie
Hir thouȝt her cursed hert brast a two
She wold not hir sone had don soo
Hir thouȝt a despit that he shuld take
So straunge a creature vnto his make ~
Me list nouȝt of the chaf ne of the stree
Maken so long a tale as of the corn
What shuld I tellen of the rialte
Of mariage or which cours goth biforn
Who bloweth in a trompe or in an horn
The frute of eueri tale is for to seye
They ete and drink daunce syng and pleye
They goon to bedde as it was skill and riȝt
For thouȝ that wyues ben ful holi thinges
They most take in pacience at niȝt
Such maner necessaries as ben plesinges
To folk that han wedded hem with rynges
And ley a litill her holinesse a side
As for the tyme it may non othir bitide ~
On hir he gat a knaue child anon
And to a busshop and his constable eke
He toke his wif whan he is goon
To Scotlandward his fomen for to seke
Now faire Custaunce that is so humble ⁊and meke
So longe is goon with childe til that stille
She halt hir chambre abiding cristes wille ~
The tyme is come a knaue child she bere
Maurcius at the fonstoıı̄un they him calle
This constable doth come forth a messanger
And wrot vnto his king that cleped was Alle
Hou that this blisfull tyding is be falle
And othir tidinges spedefull for to seye
He tath the letter and forth he goth his weye ~
This Massanger to don his auᵃntage
Vnto the kynges moder rideth swithe
And salueth her full faire in his langage
Madame quod he ye may be glad and blithe
And thanke god an C thousand sithe
My lady quene shulde withouten doute
To ioye and blisse of all this reigne aboute ~
So here the letteres sealed of this thing
That I mot bere with all the hast I may
If ye will ouȝt vnto your owne sone the kyng
I am your seruᵃnt bothe niȝt and day
Donegild answered as now at this tyme nay
But here all niȝt I wol thou take thi reest
To morwe wol I sey the what me leste
This Massanger drank sadly ale and wyn
And stolen were his letteres priuily
Out of his box while he slepe as a swyn
And counterfeted was ful subtily
Anothir lettre wrouȝt ful synfully
Vnto the kyng direct of this matere
Fro his constable as ye shal aftir here ~
This lettre spak the quene deliuered was
Of so horrible a fendlich creature
That in the castell noon so hardy was
That eny while dorst therynne endure
The moder was an elf by auenture
I comen by Charmes or by Sorcery
And eueri wiȝt hateth her company
Wo was this king whan he this letter had seyn
But to no wiȝt he tolde his wordes sore
But of his owne hond he wrot agein
Welcome the sonde of Crist for euermore
To me that am now lerned in this lore
Lord welcome be thi lust and thi plesaunce
My lust I put all in thi ordenᵃnce
Kepeth this child al be it foule or faire
And eke my wif vnto myn hom comyng
Crist whan him list may sende me an haire
More agreable than this to my likyng
This letter he seleth priuily weping
Which to the massanger was take sone
And forth he goth ther is nomore to done ~
O Massanger fulfilled of dronkenesse
Strong is thi breth thi lymes faltren ay
And thou biwreiest all thi sekirnesse
Thi mynde is lorn thou iangelest as a iay
Thi face is turned in a newe array
Ther dronkenesse reigneth in any route
Ther is no counseill had withouten doute ~
O donegild I ne haue non Englissh digne
Vnto thi malice and thi Tyrannie
And therfor to the fende I the resigne
Lat him enditen of thi Traitorye
Fy mannissh fy O nay be god I lye
Fy fendlich spirit for I dar wel telle
Thouȝ thou here walke thi spirit is in helle
This Massanger cometh from the kyng agein
And at the kinges modirs court he liȝt
And she was of this massanger ful fayn
And plesed him in all that euer she miȝt
He drank and wel his girdill vnder piȝt
He clepeth and he fnorteth in his gise
All niȝt til the sonne gan arise
Eft were his letteres stolen euerichon
And counterfeted lres in this wise
The kyng cōmmaundeth his constable anon
Vp peyne of hanging and on hy Iwyse
That he ne shulde suffre in no wise
Custaunce withynne his reigne for to a bide
Thre dayes and a quarter of a tide ~
But in the same ship as he hir fonde
Hir and her yong sone and all hir gere
She shuld put and croude fro the londe
And charge her that she neuer eft come there
O my custaunce wel may thi goost han fere
And sleping in thi dreem ben in penᵃnce
Whan Donegild cast all this ordinᵃnce
This Massanger on morwe whan he wook
Vnto the castell halt the next wey
And to the Constable he the letter took
And whan that he this pitous lrēm say
Ful ofte he seide allas and welawey
Lord Crist hou may this world endure
So full of synne is many a creature ~
X xxȝty god if that it be thi wille
Sith thou art riȝtful iuge hou may it be
That thou wilt suffren innocentez to spille
And wicked folk regnen in prosperite
O gode Custaunce allas so wo is me
That I mot be thi tormentoᵘur or dye
On shames deth ther is non othir weye ~
Wepen bothe yong and olde in that place
Whan that the kyng this cursed lrēm sent
And Custaunce with a dedly pale face
The iiij day toward hir ship she went
But natheles she takith in gode entent
The will of Crist and kneling on the stronde
She said lord ay welcome be thi sonde ~
He that me kept fro the false blame
Whiles I was in the lond amonges you
He can me kepe fro harme ⁊and eke fro shame
In salt see all thouȝ I see nat hou
As strong as euer he was he is riȝt now
In him trust I and in his moder dere
That is to me my saile ⁊and eke my stere ~
Hir litill child lay weping in her harme
And kneling pitously to him she saide
Pees litill sone I will don the non harme
With that her kercher of hir hed she breide
And ouer her litill child than she it leyde
And in her arme she lulleth it ful fast
And in to heuene hir yen vp she cast ~
Moder qd she and briȝt maide Mary
Soth is that throuȝ wōmmmanes eggement
Mankynde was lost ⁊and dampned ay to die
For which thi child was on the crosse I rent
Thi blisfull yen sauȝ all his torment
Than is ther non comparisoıı̄un betwene
Thi woo and any woo man may sustene ~
Thou sauȝ thi sone I slayn beforn thine yen
And yet now lyueth my litill child parfay
Now lady briȝt to whom alle wooful crien
Thou glory of wommanhod thou fair may
Thou heuene of refute briȝt sterre of day
Rewe on my childe that of thi gentilesse
That rewest on eueri rufull in distresse ~
O litill child allas what is thi gilt
That neuer wroutest synne as yet parde
Whi wil thine hard fader haue the spilt
O mercy dere Constable qd she
As lat my litill childe dwelle here with the
And if thou darst nouȝt saue him fro blame
So kisse him ones in his fadirs name ~
With that she lokid bakward to the londe
And seid fare wel husbonde routheles
And vp she rist and walketh doun the stronde
Toward the ship hir folweth all the prees
And euer she praieth her childe to holde his pees
And takith hir leue and with an holi entent
She blesseth her and in the ship she went ~
Vitailed was the ship it is no drede
Habundantly for hir full long space
And othir necessaries that shulde nede
She had I nouȝ y heried be goddes grace
For wynde and wedir almiȝty god purchace
And bringe her hoom I can no better sey
But in the see she dryueth forth her way
Alla the kyng cometh hom sone aftir this
Vnto his castell of which I tolde
And axeth where his wif and is child is
The Constable gan aboute his herte colde
And pleynly all the maner he him tolde
As ye han herd I can telle you no bettre
And sheweth the kyng his seall and his lrēm
And seid lord as ye comaunded me
Vp peyne of deth so haue I don certein
This Massanger tormented was
Most beknowen and tellen plat and pleyn
Fro niȝt to niȝt in what place he had leyn
And thus by wit and subtill enquering
Ymagined was by whom this harme gan spring
The honde was knowe that the lettre wrot
And all the venym of this cursed dede
But in what wise certeinly I not
The effecte is this that Alla out of drede
His moder slow that may men pleinly rede
For that she traitoᵘur was to hir ligeaunce
This olde Donegild endeth thus wᵗith meschᵃunce ~
This sorwe that this Alla niȝt and day
Maketh for his wif and for his child also
Ther is no tonge that it telle may
But now woll to custaunce go
That fleteth in the see in peyne and woo
V yere and more as liked cristes sonde
Or that hir ship approched vnto londe ~
Vnder an hethen castel at leste
Of which the name in my text nouȝt I fynde
Custaunce ⁊and eke her child the see vpcast
Almiȝty god that saued all mankynde
Haue on Custaunce and on her child som mynde
That fallen is in hethen hond heft sone
In poynt to spille as I shall telle you sone
Doun fro the castell cometh ther many a wiȝt
To gauren on this ship and on custaunce
But shortly from the castel on a niȝt
The lordes
But blisfull Mary helpe hir riȝt anon
For with her strogelyng wel and miȝhtyly
The theef fil ouer the borde all sodeinly
And in the see he dreynt for vengeaunce
And thus hath crist vnwemmed kept Custaunce ~
O foul lust of luxurie lo thine ende
Nat only that thou fayntest māmnes mynde
But verrily thou wilt his body shende
The ende of thi werk or of thi lustes blynde
Is compleynyng hou many oon may man fynde
That nouȝt for werk but somtyme for thentent
To don this synne be slayn or shent ~
Hou may this wxxk womman haue this strengthe
Her to defende agein this renegat
O golias vnmesurable of lengthe
Hou miȝt Dauid make the so mat
So yong and of armoᵘur so desolat
Hou dorst he loke vpon thi dredfall face
Wel may men see it was but goddes grace ~
Who yaf Iudith corage or hardinesse
To sleen holefernes in his tent
And to delyueren out of wrecchidnesse
The people of god I sey for this entent
That riȝt as god spirit and vigoᵘur sent
To hem and
To make an ende of alle hir heuinesse
Now lat vs stynte of Custaunce but a throwe
And speke we of the Romayn Emꝑper/parour
That out of Surrye hath by letteres I knowe
The slauȝter of cristiene folk and dishonoᵘur
Don to his douȝter by a false Traitoᵘur
I mene the cursed wickid soudenesse
That at the feste let sle bothe more and lesse
For which this Emꝑper/parour hath sent anon
His Senatoᵘur with riall ordenᵃunce
And othir lordes god wot many oon
On Surreyns to take hy vengeaunce
They brennen sleen and bringen hem to mischᵃunce
Full many a day but shortly this is the ende
Homward to Rome they shapen hem to wende ~
This senatour repaireth with victory
To Romeward full rially
And met the ship dryuyng
In which Custaunce sit ful pitously
No thing ne knewe he what she was ne whi
She was in such array ne she nel nat sey
Of hir estat thouȝ she shuld deye
And bringeth her to Rome ⁊and to his wif
He yaf hir and hir yong sone also
And with the senatour she lad her lif
Thus can oure lady bringe out of woo
Wofull Custaunce and many anothir moo
I wol retorne and lete I wol Custaunce
Vnder the Senatours gouernᵃunce
Kyng Alla which that his moder hath slayn
Vpon a day fel in such repentaunce
That if I shortly tellen shal and pleyn
To Rome he cometh to receyuen his penᵃunce
And put him in the popes ordenᵃunce
In hy and lowe and Ihıı̄un crist besouȝt
Foryeue his wickid werkes that he wrouȝt
The fame anon throuȝ Rome toun is born
Hou Alla kyng shal come on pilgrimage
By herbegeours that wenten him beforn
For which the Senatour as was the vsage
Rode him agein and many of his lynage
As wel to shewe his hy magnificence
As don any kyng any reuerence ~
Gret chiere doth this noble Senatour
To kyng Alla and he to him also
Euerich of hem doth othir gret honoᵘur
And so be fell that in a day or ij
This Senatour is to kyng Alla I goo
To feste and shortly if I shal not lye
Custaunces sone in his companye ~
Som men wold seyn at request of Custaunce
This Senatour had lad this child to the feste
I may nouȝt telle eueri circumstaunce
Be as be may ther was he at leste
But sooth is this that at his modres heeste
Beforn Alla during the metes space
The child stood loking in the kynges face ~
This Alla kyng hath of the child gret wonder
And to the Senatour he seid anon
Whoz is that faire childe that stondeth yonder
I not qd he by god and be seint Iohn
A moder he hath but fader hath he non
That I of woot and shortly in a stounde
He told Alla hou that the child was founde ~
But god wot qd this Senatour also
So vertuous a lyuer in my lif
Ne saw I neuer as she is ne herd of mo
Of wordeli wommen maide ne of wif
I dar wel sain her had leuer a knif
Throuȝ out her breest and ben a wōmman wicke
Ther is no man coude bringe her to that prikke ~
Now was this child as like vnto Custaunce
As possible is a creature to be
This Alla hath the face in remembrᵃunce
Of Dame Custaunce and theron mused he
If that the childes moder were ouȝt she
That is his wif and priuily he sight
And sped him from the table all that he miȝt ~
Parfay thouȝt he fantome is myn heed
I ouȝt deme of skilfull iugement
That in the salt see my wif is ded
And aftirward he made his argument
What wot I whethir that crist hath hider sent
My wif be see as wel as he hir sent
To myn contre fro thennes that she went ~
And aftir noon hom with this senatoᵘur
Goth Alla for to seen this wonder chaunce
This Senatour doth Alla gret honoᵘur
And hastili he sent aftir Custaunce
But trusteth hir list nouȝt to daunce
Whan that she wist wherfor was that sonde
Vnnethe vpon her feet she miȝt stonde
Whan Alla sauȝ his wif faire he hir gret
And wept that it was routhe for to see
For at the first loke he on hir sette
He knewe wel verrily that it was she
And for sorwe as dombe stant as a tree
So was hir herte shet in hir distresse
Whan she remembred his vnkyndenesse
Twies she swouned in his owne siȝt
He wepte and excused him pitously
Now god qd he and his ahalwes briȝt
So wiseli on my soule haue mercy
That of your harme as gilteles am I
As is Maurice my sone so lik your face
Elles the fende me sette out of this place
Long was the snobbing and the bitter peyne
Or that hir wofull hertes miȝt a cese
Gret was the pitee for to here hem pleyne
Throuȝ wich pleintes gan hir sorwe encrese
I pray you all my sorwe to relese
I may nouȝt telle hir woo til to morwe
I am so sori for to speke of sorwe ~
But finally whan the soth is wist
That Alla gilteles was of hir woo
I trowe an hundred tymes ben they kist
And such a blisse is ther betwix hem two
That saue the ioye that lasteth euer mo
Ther is non lik that any creature
Hath seyn or shal while the world may dure
Tho preied she hir husbond mekely
In releue of hir long pitous pyne
That he wolde pray her fader specially
That of his mageste he wold enclyne
To vouchesaf som day wᵗith him to dyne
She preieth him eke he shuld be no weye
Vnto hir fader no wurd of it seye
Som man wold sayn hou that the childe Maurice
Doth this message vntill the Emꝑper/parour
But as I gesse Alla was nouȝt so nyce
To him that was so souerein of honoᵘur
As he that is of cristen folk the flour
Setit any child but it is bet to deme
He went him self and so it may wel seme ~
This Emꝑper/parour hath graunted gentilly
To come to dyner as he him besought
And wel rede I he loked besily
Vpon this childe and on his douȝter thought
Alla goth to his ynne and as him ouȝt
Arraied for this feste in eueri wise
As ferforth as connyng may suffice ~
The morwe come and Alla gan him dresse
And eke his wif this Emꝑper/parour for to mete
And forth thei ryde in Ioye and in gladnesse
And whan she say her fader in the strete
She liȝt adoun and fallith him to fete
Fader qd she youre yong childe Custaunce
Is now full clene of your remembrᵃunce ~
I am your douȝter Custaunce qd she
That whilom ye han sent vnto Surrye
It am I Fader that in the salt see
Was put allone and dampned for to dye
Now gode fader mercy I you crie
Send me nomore vnto noon hethenesse
But thank my lord here of his kendenesse
Who can the pitous ioye tellen al
Betwix hem three syn they ben thus I met
But day of my tale make an ende I shal
The day goth fast I will no lenger let
Thise glade folk to dyner they hem set
In ioye and blisse I lete hem at the mete dwelle
A thousand fold wel more than I can telle ~
This childe Maurice was sithen Emꝑper/parour
Made by the pope lyued and cristienly
To cristes chirche he did gret honoᵘur
But I lete all this story passe by
Of Custaunce is my tale specially
In olde Romeyn gestes may men fynde
Maurices lif I bere it nouȝt in mynde ~
This kyng Alla whan he his tyme say
With his Custaunce his holi swif so swete
To Engelond be they come the riȝt wey
Where as they ben in ioye and in quiete
But litill while it lasteth I you behete
Wyt of this worlde / for tyme wol nouȝt abide
Fro day to niȝt it chaungeth as the tide ~
Who lyued euer in such delite a day
That him ne meued either conscience
Or Ire or talent or symkynnes affray
Enuie or Pride or Passion or offense
I ne sey but for this ende this sentence
That litill while in ioye or in plesaunce
Lasteth the blisse of Alla with Custaunce ~
For deth that takith of hye and lowe his rente
Whan passed was a yere euene as I gesse
Out of this world this kyng Alla he hent
For whom Custaunce hath full gret heuinesse
Now lat vs praie god his soule blesse
And dame Custaunce finally to sey
Toward the toun of Rome she goth hir wey
To Rome is come this holi creature
And fyndeth her frendes hole and sound
Now is she scaped al hir auenture
And whan she had hir fader I founde
Doun on hir knees falleth she to grounde
Weping for terdernesse in herte blithe
She heried god an hundred thousand sithe ~
In vertu and holinesse and almesse dede
They lyuen alle and neuer a sondre wende
Til deꝑper/parte hem this lif thi lede
And fareth now wel my tale is at an ende
Now Ihıı̄un crist that of his miȝt may sende
Ioye aftir woo gouerne vs in his grace
And kepe vs alle that beth in this place ~
Here endeth the tale of the man of lawe ~

div.l: And seide gode men herkeneth euerichon
This was a thrifty tale for the nones
Sir parissh prest for goddes bones
Telle us a tale as was thi forward yore
I see wel that the lerned men in lore
Can moche gode be goddes dignite
The persoıı̄un him answerid Benedicite
What eileth the man so sinfully to swere
Oure oost answerid o Iankyn be ye there
I smelle a loller in the wynd qd he
Now gode men qd oure oost herkene me
Abideth for goddis digne passioıı̄un
For we shul han a predicacioıı̄un
This loller here wol prechen us som what
Nay be my fader soule that shal he not
Seide the sompnoᵘur here shal he nouȝt preche
He shall no gospel glose here ne teche
We leuen alle in the grete god qd he
He wolde sowen som difficulte
Or springe cokkell in oure clene corn
And therfor oost I warne the beforn
My Ioly body shall a tale telle
And I shall clynken you so mery a belle
That it shall waken all this company
But it shal not ben of Philosophie
Ne Phisilias ne termes of queynt lawe
Ther is but litill latyn in my mawe ~
Here endith the Prolog of the Squier

div.l: And gently I preise wel thi wit
Qd the Marchᵃunt considering thi youthe
So felingly thou spekest I allowe the
As to my doom ther is noon that is here
Of Eloquence that shall be thi peere
If that thou lyue god gif the gode chaunce
And in vertu sende the continuaunce
For of thi speche I haue gret deynte
I haue a sone and by the Trinite
I had leuer than xxty . pound worth lond
Thouȝ it riȝt now were fallen in my hand

But if a man be vertuous with all

For he to vertues list not to entende

And lese all that he hath is his vsage
And he had leuer to talken with a page

Where he miȝt lerne gentilnesse of riȝt
Straw for your gentilnesse qd oure oost
What Marchᵃunt sir wel thou wost
That eche of you mot telle at lest

I pray you haueth me at no disdein

Vnto your will now herkeneth what I sey
I wil not you contrarie in no wise
As fer as my wittes wolen suffice
I pray to god that I may plese you
Than wot I wel that it is gode I now .
