div.l: A lusty kniȝt that was born at Pauye
In which he leued in gret prosꝑper/parite
And hoo ther a wifles man was he
And folwed ay his bodeli delite
On wommēm ther was his appetite
As don these fooles that ben seculere
And whan that he was passed ho there
Were it for holinesse or for dotage
I can not sey but such a gret corage
Had this kniȝt to ben a wedded man
That day and niȝt he doth all that he can
To aspie where that he miȝt wedded be
Praing oure lord to graunte him that he
Might ones knowe that blisful lif
That is betwix husbond and wif
And for to lyue vnder that holi bonde
With which god first man to wōmman bande
Non othir lif seith he is worth a bene
For wedlok is so esy and so clene
That in this world it is a paradys
This said this olde kniȝt that was so wise
And certeinli as soth as god is a king
To take a wif is a glorious thing
And namely whan a man is olde and hore Mercatoris
Then is a wif the frute of his tresore
Than shuld he take a yong wif and a feire
On which he miȝt engendren him an eyre
And lede his lif in ioye and in solace
Where as this bachillers synge allas
Whan that thei fynde any aduersite
In loue which nys but childes vanite
And truly it ouȝt wel to be soo
That bachillers haue ofte peynes and woo
On brutel grounde thei bielde broutelnesse
They fynde whan thei wene sikernesse
They lyue but as a brid or a beest
In liberte and vnder none areste
There as a wedded man in his estat
Lyueth his lif blisfull and ordinat
Vnder the yok of mariage bounde
Wel may his herte in ioye and blisse habounde
For who can be so buxum as a wif
Who is so trewe and eke so ententif
To kepe him sike and hole as is his make
For wel ne woo she nel not him forsake
She nys not weri him to loue and serue
Thouȝ that he lie bedred til that he sterue
And yet som clerkes sein it is not so
Of which Theofastre is oon of tho
What force thouȝ Theofastre list lye
Ne take no wif qd he for husbondrie
As for to spare in houshold thi dispence
A trewe seruᵃnt doth more diligence
Thi gode to kepe than thine owne wif
For she wil clayme half part all hir lif
And if that thou be seke so god me saue
The verri frendes othir a trewe knaue
Wol kepe the bet than she that waiteth ay Fabula
After thi gode and hath do many a day
This entent and an hundred sithes werse
Writ this man ther god his foule curse
But take no kepe of such vanite
Defie Theofraste and herkenith me
A wif is goddes yefte verrili
All aboue othir maner yeftes hardeli
As londes rentes pasture or comune
Or mebles al by yefte of fortune
That passen as a shadewe on a wal
But drede nouȝt if pleinli speken I shal
A wif wol last and in thi hous endure
Wel lenger than the lust ꝑper/paraduenture
Mariage is a full gret sacrament
He which hath no wif I holde him shent
He lyueth helpeles and is all desolat
I speke of folk in seculer estat
And herkene whi I sey this not for nouȝt
The womman is for the māmnes helpe wrouȝt
This hiȝe god whan he had Adam I maked
And saw him allone body naked
God of his gret godenesse seide thenne
Let vs now make an helper to mane
I like to him silf and that he made Eue
Here by may ye see and here by may ye preue
That wif is māmnes help ⁊and his comfort
His paradys terrestre and his disport
So buxum and so vertuous is she
They must nedes lyue in vnite
Of flessh thei be and o flessh as I gesse
Hath but oon hert in will and in distresse
A wif seint Mary Benedicite
Hou miȝt a man haue any aduersite
That hath a wif certes I am not seye Mercatoris
The blisse that is betwix hem twey
Ther may no tonge telle or herte thenke
If he be pore she helpith him to swinke
She kepeth his gode and neuer a del wasteth
All that her husbond liketh
She nouȝt ones nay whan he seith yee
Doth this seith he al redi sir seith she
O blisfull ordre . O wedlok preciouse
Thou art so mery and eke so vertuous
And so comended and aproued eke
That eueri man that holt him worth a leke
Vpon his bare knees ouȝt all his lif
Thank his god that him hath sent a wif
Othir pray to god him for to sende
A wif to last vnto his lyues ende
For than his lif is set in sikernesse
He may nouȝt be deceyued as I gesse
So that he worche aftir his wyues reed
Than may he boldeli bere vp his hed
Thei ben so trewe and also vertuouse
For which if thou wilt werche as I the wisse
Do al wey so as wommen wol the rede
Lo hou that Iacob as these clerkes rede
By gode counseill of his moder Rebekke
Bande the kides skyn aboute his nekke
For which his fader benisoıı̄un he wan
Lo Iudith in the storie telle I can
By wise counseill she goddes peple kepte
And slow him Holofernes whiles he slepte
Lo hou Abigail by gode counseill hou she
Saued hir husbond naked whan that he
Shuld a be slayn and loked aftir also
By gode counseill deliuered out of woo
The people of god and made him of Mardoche Fabula
Of Assuer enhaunced for to be
Ther is no thing in gre suꝑper/parlatif
As seith Senek abouen an humble wif
Suffre thi wyues tonge as Catoıı̄un bit
She shal comaunde and thou shalt suffre it
And she wol obeie as curtesie
A wif is keper of thi husbondrie
Wel may the seke biwaile ⁊and wepe
Ther as is no wif the house to kepe
I warne the if wisly thou wilt wirche
Loue wel thi wif as crist loued his chirche
If thou louest thi self wel thou louest thi wif
No man hath his flessh but in his lif
He fostereth it and therfor bid I the
Cherisshe thi wif or thou shalt neuer the
Husbonde and wif what so men iape and pley
Of wordeli folk holden the siker wey
They ben so knitte ther may non harme bitide
And nameli vpon the wyues side
For which this Ianuarie of which I tolde
Considered hath withynne his daies olde
The lusti lif the vertuous quiete
That is in mariage hony swete
And for his frendes on a day he sent
To tellen hem the feet of his entent
With face sad he hath his tale hem tolde
He seide frendes I am hore and olde
And almost god wot vpon my pittes brinke
Vpon my soule somwhat most I thinke
I haue my body folili despended
Blessid be god that it shall be amended
For I wol be certein a wedded man
And that anon in all the hast I can
Vnto som maide faire and tender of age Mercatoris
I pray you shapith for my mariage
All sodeinly for I will nat abide
And I will fonde espie on my side
To whom I may be wedded hastili
But in as moch as ye ben mo than I
Ye shullen rather such a thing espien
Than I and where me lust best to allien
But o thing warne I you my frendes dere
I wol non olde wif haue in non manere
She shal not passe xvj yere certein
Yong flessh / that wold I haue fayn
Worse is qd he a pike than a pikerel
And better than the olde beef is the yonge veel
I will no womman xxxty wynter of age
It nys but benestraw and gret forage
And eke this olde widewes god it wot
They conne so moch craft of wades bote
So moche broken harm whan hem lest
That with hem shuld I lyue neuer in reste
For sondri scoles makith subtil clerkes
Whan of many a scole half a clerc is
But certeinli a yong thing may men gie
Riȝt as men may warme wex wᵗith handes plie
Wherfor I sey you pleinli in a cause
I wold non olde wif riȝt for this cause
For if so were I had somme mischᵃunce
That I in her ne coude haue no plesaunce
Than shuld I lede my lif in Envie
And so streight to the deuel whan I dye
Ne children shuld I non vpon hir getyn
Yet had me leuer houndes had me etyn
Than that myn heritage shuld falle
In straunge hand and thus I telle you al
I do nouȝt I wot not the cause whi Fabula
Men shuld wedde and furthermore wot I
Ther spekith many man of mariage
That wot nomore of it than wot my page
For which causes men shuld take a wif
If he ne may chaste be he his lif
Take him a wif with gret deuocion
By cause of leefull procreacioıı̄un
Of children / to the honoᵘur of god aboue
And nouȝt oonly for ꝑper/paramoᵘur othir for loue
And for thei shuld leccherie eschewe
And yelde hir dettes whiles it is dewe
Or for that eche man shuld helpen othir
In mischief as a sustir shal to a brothir
And lyue in chaste ful euenly
And sires be your leue that am not I
For god be thanked I dar make auᵃnt
I fele my lymes starke and suffisaunt
To do all that a man be longeth to
I wot my self best what I may do
Thouȝ that I be hore I fare as doth a tree
That blosmeth or the frute I waxed be
And blosmy tree is neuer drie ne dede
I fele me nowher hoor but on my hede
Myn herte and my lymes ben as grene
As laurer throuȝ the yere is for to sene
And sithen ye haue herd all myn entent
I pray you to my will that ye assent
Diuerse men diuersli him tolde
Of mariage many ensamples olde
Some blamed it som preised it certein
But at the last shortly for to seyn
As all day fallith altercacion
Bitwen frendes in disputacioıı̄un
Ther fill a strif betwix his bretheren ijᵒ Mercatoris
Of which that oon was clepid Placebo
Iustinus sothly callid was the othir
Placebo said O Ianuare Brothir
Full litill had ye my lord so dere
Counseill to aske of any that is here
But that ye ben so full of sapience
That you ne liketh for your high prudence
To warfe fro the wordes of Salomon
This word seid he to vs euericheon
Werke all thing be counseill thus seid he
And than shalt thou repente the
But thouȝ that Salomon speke such a worde
Myn owne dere brothir and my lord
So god bringe my soule at ease and reste
I holde your counseil for the beste
For brothir myn of me take this motif
I haue now be a court man al my lif
And god wot thouȝ I vnworthi be
I haue stonden in full gret degree
Abouten lordes in full gret estat
Yet had I neuer with non of hem debat
I neuer contraried hem truly
I wot wel that my lord can more than I
What that he seith I holde it ferme and stable
I sey the same orellis thing semblable
A full greet fooll is any counseilloᵘur
That serueth any lord of high honoᵘur
That dar presume or ones thenke it
That his counseill shuld passe his lordes wit

Which ielousie it was so outerageous
That neithir in halle neithir in non othir house
Ne in non othir place neuer the moo
He nolde suffre her to ride nor go
But yef that he had hand on her alway
For which ful ofte wepith the fressh May
That loued Damyan so hugely
That she must either dyen sodeinly Mercatoris
Orellis she mut haue him at hir lust
She waiteth whan her herte shuld to breste
Vpon that othir side this Damyan
By comen is the sorwefullest man
That euer was / for neithir niȝt nor day
Miȝt he speke a worde with that fressh May
All to his purpos of non such matier
But if that Ianuare must it here
That had an hand vpon her for euermo
And natheles by writing to and fro
And preuy signes wist he what she ment
And she knewe wel the fyne of his entent
O Ianuarie what miȝt it the auaile
Thouȝ thou miȝtest see as fer as shippes saile
For as gode is a blynde man deceyued be
As be deceyued whan a man may see
Loo Arguus which that had an . C . yen
For all that he coude pouren or pryen
Yet was he blent and so be mo
That wenen wisly that it is nouȝt soo
Passe ouer is an ese and say nomore
This fressh May which I speke of so sore
In warme wax hath emprentid the cliket
That Ianuare bar of the same wikett
By which in to his gardyn ofte he went
And Damyan that knewe all his entent
The cliket counterfeted priuily
Ther nys namore to sey but hastisly
Som wonder by this cliket shal be tide
Which that ye shul here if that ye wil abide
O noble Ouide sothly seist thou god wot
What sleiȝt is that / of loue be long and hote
That he nil fynde oute in som manere
By Priamus and Tesbe may men lere Fabula
Thouȝ they were kept full longe and streite oueral
They ben accorded romyng throuȝ a stonewal
That no wiȝt coude fynde out such a sliȝt
But now to purpos er that daies eight
Were passed of the moneth of Iule bifelle
That Ianuarie hath caught so gret a wille
Throuȝ eggyng of his weye him to pleye
In this gardyn and no wiȝt but thei tweye
That in a morwe vnto this May said he
Rise vp my wif my loue my lady free
The turtles voice is herd my douce swete
The wynter is gon with all his reynes wete
Come forth with thine yen columbyne now
For fairer ben thi brestes and the wyne than is
The gardin is closed all a boute
Come forth my swete spouse out of doute
Thou hast me wounded in myn herte O wif
No spot of the nas neuer in all thi lif
Come forth and let us take oure disport
I chese the for my wif and for confort
Such olde leude wordes vsed he
On Damyan a signe made she
That he shuld goo beforn with his clikett
This Damyan hath vp heued the wikett
And doun he stert and that in such manere
That no wiȝt miȝt it see and here
And stille he sit vnder a bussh anon
This Ianuarie is blynde as a stoon
With Mayus in his hand ⁊and no wiȝt moo
Into his fressh gardyn is he goo
And clappith to the wiket sodeinli
Now wif qd he here nys but thou and I
Thou art the creature that I best loue
For by that lord Ihuc that sit aboue Mercatoris
I had leuer dyen on a knif
Than you offenden dere trewe wif
For goddes sake thenke hou I the chese
Nouȝt for no couetise douȝteles
But oonly for the loue that I had to the
And thouȝ that I be olde and may not see
Be now to me trewe as I wol telle you whi
Certes iij thinges shul ye wynne therby
For loue of Crist and to your self honoure
And all myn heritage toune and toure
I yeue it you and makith you chartres as you lest
This shal be don to morwe or the sunne reste
So wisly god my soule bringe in blisse
And I pray you on this couenᵃnt ye me kisse
And thouȝ that I be ielouse wite me nouȝt
Ye ben so deprented in my thouȝt
Than whan I considere your beaute
And therwith all the vnlikli youthe of me
I may nouȝt certes thouȝ I shuld dye
For bere to be out of your companie
For verri loue that is withouten doute
Now kisse me wif and let vs rome aboute
This fressh May whan she this wurdes herde
Benigly to Ianuarie answerd
But first and forward she began to wepe
I haue qd she a soule for to kepe
As wel as ye and also myn honour
And of my wifhod eke the tendre flour
With that I haue assured you in your honde
Whan that the preest to you my body bonde
Wherfor I wil answere in this manere
With the leue of you my lord so dere
I pray god that neuer dawe that day
That I ne sterue as foule as any womman may Fabula
Yef euer I do vnto my kyn that shame
Orellis I empeire so my name
That I be false and if I do that lakke
Do stripe me and put me in a sakke
And in the nexte ryuer do me drenche
I am a gentil womman and no wenche
Whi speke ye thus but men ben eủer/re vntrewe
And wōmmen han reproue of you ay newe
Ye can no continuance as I leue
But speke to vs as for vntrust ⁊and in reproue
And with that word she sauȝ where Damyan
Sat in the bussh and coughe he bigan
And with hir fyngre signes made she
That Damyan shuld clymbe on a tree
That charged was with frute and vp he went
For verrili he knewe all hir entent
And eueri signe that she coude make
Wel bet than Ianuare her owne make
For in a lettre she had told him al
Of this mater hou he worche shal
And thus I let him sitte in the pirie
And Ianuarie and Mayus romyng ful merie
Briȝt was the day and blwe the firmament
Phebus of gold doun hath his stremes sent
To glade eueri flour with his warmnesse
He was that tyme in Gemynes as I gesse
But litill fro his declinacioıı̄un
And Cancer Iouis exaltacioıı̄un
And so bifel that in the briȝt mowe tide
That in the gardyn on the further side
Pluto that is the kyng of fairie
And many a lady that is in his company
Folwing his wif the quene Proserpina
Which that he rauisshed out of Proserpina Mercatoris
While that she gadered floures in a mede
In Claudiane ye may the story rede
Hou in his griseli carte he hir sette
This kyng of Fairye adoun him sette
Vpon a benche y turned faire and grene
And riȝt anon seid he thus to his quene
My wIf qd he that no wiȝt may sey nay
The experience preueth it eueri day
The tresoıı̄un which that womman doth to man
Ten hundred thousand telle I can
No table of your vntrouth and brotilnesse
O Salamon richest of alle richesse
Fulfilled of sapience and worldly glorie
Full worthi ben thi wordes to memorie
To eueri wiȝt that wit and resoıı̄un can
Thus preiseth he yet the bounte of man
Among a thousand men yet fonde he oon
But of alle wommen yet fonde he neủer/re non
Thus seide the kyng that knewe yoᵘur wickidnesse
And Ihuc filius Cirak as I gesse
Ne spekith of you but seldom reuerence
A wilde fuyre a corupt pestilence
So falle vpon your bodyes yet to niȝt
Ne see ye nouȝt this honourable kniȝt
Be cause allas that he is blinde and olde
His owne man shal make him Cokewolde
Loo where he sit the leccheour in the tree
Now wol I graunte of my mageste
Vnto this olde worthi blinde kniȝt
That he shal haue ayen his yen siȝt
Whan that his wif wold do him vilanie
Than shal he knowe all her harlotrie
Bothe in reproue of her and othir mo
Ye qd Serpentina and will ye soo Fabula
Now be my modres sires soule I swere
Than shal I yeue here sufficient answere
And alle wommen saftir for your sake
That thouȝ they be in any gilt I take
With face bold they shul hem self excuse
And bere hem doun that wold hem alle accuse
For lacke of answere non of hem shal dyen
All had ye seyn a thing with your yen
Yet wolde we it so visage hardeli
And wepe and swere and chide subtili
That ye shal be as leude as her gees
What rekkith me of your auctoritees
I wot wel that this Iewe this Salamon
Fande of vs wommen folies many oon
But thouȝ that he ne fande no gode womman
There hath I founde many an othir man
Wommen ful trewe and gode ⁊and vertuouse
Witnesse on hem that duellid in cristes house
With martirdom thei proued her constaunce
This romayne gestes makith remembrᵃunce
Of many a verry trewe wif also
But sir ne be not wroth al be it so
Thouȝ that he saide he fonde no gode womman
I pray you takith the sentence of the man
He ment thus that in souerain bounte
Nys non but god neither he ne she
Ey for verry god that nys but one
What make ye so moch of Salomon
That thouȝ he made a temple goddes house
What thouȝ he were riche ⁊and glorious
He made eke a temple of false goddes
Who miȝt make a thing that more forboden is
Parde as faire as ye his name enplastre
He was a leccheour and an Idolastre Mercatoris
And in his elde he verry god forsoke
And yef that god made as seith the boke
I spared him for his fadres sake he shulde
Haue lost his reigne sonner than he wolde
I set nouȝt of all the vilanie
That ye of wommen write a boterflie
I am a womman nedes must I speke
Othir ellis swelle and my herte breke
For sithenes he saide we ben iangelers
As euer mot I brouke my tresses
I shall nouȝt spare for no curtesie
To speke him harme that wolde vs vilanie
Dame qd this Pluto be no lenger wroth
I yef it vp certes I swere be my oth
That I wol graunte him his siȝt ayen
My worde shal stonde that warne I the certein
I am a kniȝt it sit me nouȝt to lye
And I am a quene qd she of fayrie
Her answere shall she haue I vndertake
Let vs herof no mo wordes make
Forsothe I wol no lenger you contrarie
Now let vs turne ayen to Ianuarie
That in the gardyn with his fressh May
Syngeth wel merier than the Popingay
Now I loue the best and shal and othir non
So longe aboute the alley is he goon
Til he was comen agein thilke pery
Where that this Damyan sitteth ful mery
And sigh among the faire leues grene
This faire May that is so briȝt and shene
Gan for to sike and seid allas my side
Now sir qd she for ouȝt that may bitide
I must haue of the perys that I see
Or I mot dye so sore longith me Fabula
To ete of the smale perys grene
Helpe for hir loue that is of heuene quene
I telle you wel a womman in my plite
May haue of frute so gret an appetite
That she may dye but she of it haue
Allas qd she ne had I here a knaue
That coude clymbe allas allas qd he
For I am blynde ye sir no force qd she
But wolde ye vouchesaf for goddis sake
The pirye withynne your armes take
For wel I wot that ye may trust me
Than shuld I clymbe wel I nouȝ qd she
So I my foot miȝt set vpon your bak
Certes qd he therynne ne shal be no lak
Myȝt I you helpe with myn herte blode
He stouped doun and on his bak she stode
And cauȝt her be a twist and vp she goth
Ladyes I pray you be not wroth
I can not glose I am a rude man
And sodeinli anon this Damian
Gan vp pulle the smok and yn he thronge
And whan that Pluto sy this gret wronge
To Ianuarie he yaf his yen sight
That he miȝt se as wel as euer he miȝt
And whan that he had his siȝt agein
Ne was neuer man of sight so fayn
But on his wif his thouȝt was euer mo
And to the tree he cast his yen two
And sauȝ that Damian his wif had dressid
In such a wife as it may not be expressid
But yef I wolde speke vncurteisly
And vp he yaf a roryng and a cry
As doth the moder whan the child shal dye
Out help harrow allas he gan to crye Mercatoris
O stronge lady store what doest thou
And she answerid sir what eileth you
Haueth resoıı̄un and pacience in your mynde
I haue you holpen of bothe your yen blynde
Vp perill of my soule I shall not lyen
Thus me was tauȝt to hele with your yen
Was no thing bet to maken you to see
Than iangelyng with a man vpon a tree
God wot I did it in wel gode entente
Straungeli qd he but algate yn it went
God you bothe on shames deth to dyen
He swyued the I sauȝ it with myn yen
And ellis be I hanged be the halse
Than is qd she my medicine is false
For certeinli if ye miȝt see
Ye wolde not sey these wordes vnto me
Ye haue som glymsing and no parfiȝt siȝt
I see qd he as wel as euer I miȝt
I thanked be god with bothe myn yen twoo
And be my trouth me thouȝt that ye did soo
Ye mase mase gode sir qd she
This thank haue I for that I made you see
Allas qd she that euer I was so kynde
Now dame qd he let passe out of mynde
Come doun my loue and I haue mys said
God helpe me so as I am euil apaid
But be my fader soule I wende haue seyn
Hou that this Damian had be you leyn
And that thi smok had leyn vpon thi breest
Ye sir qd she ye may don as you lest
But sir a man that wakith out of his slepe
He may not sodeinli wel take kepe
Vpon a thing ne se it parfiȝtly
Til that he be adawed verrili Fabula
Riȝt so a man that long hath blynde be
Ne may not sodeinly so wel see
First whan his sight is newe ayein
As he that hath a day or twey I seyn
Till that your siȝt sateled be a while
Ther may ful many a sight you bigile
By war I prey you for be heuene kyng
Ful many a man wenith to see a thing
It is al an othir than it semith
He that mys conceyueth mys demeth
And with that word she lepe doun fro the tree
To Ianuare who is glad but he
He kisseth hir and clippeth her ful ofte
And on her wombe he stroketh her ful ofte
And to his Paleys hom he hath hir lad
Now gode men I pray you to be glad
Thus endid is my tale of Ianuarie
God blisse vs and his moder seint Marie . Amen

Here endith the Marchᵃuntes tale
And here beginneth the Prolog of the Clerk
of Oxenford .
And here beginneth the Prolog of the Clerk of Oxenford.

l.hi: Sir clerk of oxenford our oost saide

div.l: Ye ride as stille and coy as doth a mayde
That were newe spoused sitting at the borde
This day ne herd I of your tonge a worde
I trowe ye studie for som sophyme
But Salamou seith eueri thing hath tyme
For goddes sake as beth of bettir chiere
It is no tyme for to studien here
Telle us som meri tale be your fey
For what man that is entred in a pley
He nedes must vnto the pley assente
But prechith nouȝt as freres don in lente
To make vs for oure olde synnes wepe
Ne that thi tale makith us for to slepe
Telle us som meri thing of aduentures
Your termes your colours and figures
Kepe hem in store til so be ye endite
High stile / as whan that men to kinges write
Spekith so playne at this tyme we you pray
That we may vnderstande what ye say
This worthi Clerk benigli answerd
Ooste qd he I am vnder your yerde
Ye han of vs as now the gouernᵃnce
And therfor wold I do you obeissaunce
As fer as resoıı̄un axeth hardili
I wol you telle a tale which that I
Lerned at Paddowe of a worthi clerk
As preued be his wordes and his werk
He is now ded and nailed in his cheste
I pray to god so yeue his soule reste
Fraunceis Petrak the laureat Poete
Hight this clerk whoz retorik swete
Enlumyned all ytaile of Poetrye
As lynyan did of Philosophie
Othir lawe othir art particuler
But deth that wol nat suffre vs to duellen here
But as it were a twynkeling of an ye
Hem both a hath slayne and al shal we dye
But forth to tellen of this worthi man
That taught me this tale as I began
I sey that first he with high stile enditeth
Or he the body of his tale writeth
A Prohemye in the which descryueth he
Pemond and Saluces the contre
And spekith of Appenen the hilles high
That ben the boundes of west lombardye
And of mount Vesulus in special
Where as the Poo out of a welle smal
Takith his first springing ⁊and his sours
That estward ay encresith in his cours
To Emele ward to Ferare and Venyse
Which a long thing were to deuise
And truly as to my iugement
Me thinketh it a thing inꝑper/partinent
Saue that he wole conueyen his matere
But this is his tale which ye may here

Hic finitur Prologus Clerici Oxonie
Et hic Incipit bona fabula nıı̄uncupata Grisilde de qua
dam muliere que Raro videtur et ce
Grisilde
There is right at the west syde of ytayle
Doun at the roote of Vesulus the colde
A lusty playn habundant of vytayle
Where many a toun and tour thou maist beholde
That founden were in tyme of fadres olde
And many an othir delectable sight
And Saluces this noble contre hiȝt.
A Markes whilom lord was of that lond
As were his worthi elderes him before
And obeisshaunt ay redy to his hond
Were alle his lieges bothe lesse and more
Thus in delite he lyueth and hath don yore
By loued and drad through fauoᵘur of fortune
Bothe of his lordes and of his comune
Ther he with was to speken of lynage
The gentilest I borne of lombardye
A faire persone and strong and yong of age
And ful of honour and of curtesye
Dyscret Inough his contre for to gye
Sauf in som thing that he was to blame
And walter was this yong lordes name.
I blame him thus that he considered nouȝt
In tyme comyng what might him be tyde
But on his lust present was all his thouȝt
As for to hauke and hunte on euery side
Well ny all othir cures let he slide
And eke he nolde and that was werst of al
Wedde no wif for ought that might be fal.
Only that poynt his peple bar so sore
That flokmele vpon a day to him they went
And oon of hem that wisest was of lore
Orellis that the lord best wolde assente
That he shulde telle him what the peple ment
Orellis coude he shewe wel such matere
He to this markes seide as ye shal here
O noble Markes your humanite
Assureth us and yeueth vs hardinesse
As ofte as tyme is of necessite
That we to you may telle oure heuynesse
Accepteth lord than of your gentilnesse
That we with pitous herte vnto you pleyne
And let your eres not my wyce disdeyne
All haue I not to do in this matere
More than an othir man hath in this place
Yet forasmuch as ye my lord so dere
Han alwey shewid me fauour and grace
I dar the better aske of you a space
Of audience to shewen oure request
And ye my lord to do riȝt as you lest
For certes lord so well us liketh you
And al your werke and euer han don that we
Ne coude not deuysen oure self hou
We miȝten lyue in more felicite
Saf oon thing lord if it your will be
That for to be a weddid man you leste
Than we your peple in souerain hertes reste.
Boweth your necke vnder that blisfull yok
Of souereinte and nouȝt of seruice
Which that men clepen spousaill or wedlok
And thenkith lord amonges your thouȝtes wise
How that oure dayes passe in sondry wyse
For thouȝ we slepe or wake or rome or ryde
Ay fleeth the tyme it will noman abide
And thouȝ your grene youthe floure as yet
In crepith age all wey as stille as stone
And deth manaceth eueri age and smyt
In ech estat for ther escapith none
And also certes as we knowe echoıı̄un
That we shall dye and vncertayn we alle
Ben of that day that deth shall on us falle.
Accepteth than of us the trewe entent
That neuer yet refuseden your heest
And we will lorde if that ye will assente
Chese you a wif in short tyme at the leste
Borne of the gentilest and of the meste
Of all this lond so that it ouȝt seme
Honoᵘur to god and to you as we can deme.
Delyuer us oute of all this besy drede
And take a wif for hiȝe goddis sake
For if so befill as god for bede
That throuȝ your deth your lynage shulde slake
And that a straunge successour shulde take
Your heritage O woo were us on lyue
Wherfor we pray you sir hastily to wyue
Here meke preioᵘur and her pitous chere
Made this markes herte to haue pitee
Ye woll qd he myn owne peple dere
To that I neuer er thouȝt streyne me
I me reioysshed of my liberte
That seldyn tyme is founden in mariage
Ther I was free I most be in seruage
But natheles I see your trewe entent
And truste vpon your witte and haue don ay
Wherfor of my free will I will assent
To wedde me as sone as euer I may
But there as ye han proferid me to day
To chese me a wif I you relese
That choys and pray you that profre cese
For god it wot that children often been
Vnlike her worthi elderes hem before
Bounte cometh al of god ⁊and not of strene
Of which they ben I gendred and I bore
I trust in goddis bounte and therfor
Myn mariage and myn estat and reste
I him be take he may do as him leste.
Lete me allone in chesing of my wif
That charge vpon my bak I will endure
But I pray you and charge you vpon your lif
That what wif I take ye me assure
To wurship her whill that her lif may dure
In worde and werke bothe here and euery where
As she an Emperours douȝter were.
And furthermore this shall ye swere that ye
Ageins my chois shall neuer grucche ne stryue
For syn I shall for goo my liberte
At your request as euer mot I thryue
Ther as myn herte is sette ther will I wyue
And but ye will assente in such manere
I pray you speke nomore of this mater.
With hertly will they sworen and assenten
To alle this thing there seid no wiȝt nay
Byseching him of grace or that thei wenten
That he wold graunte hem a certayn day
Of his spousaill as sone as euer he may
For yat alwey the peple somwhat dredde
Lest than the Markes no wif wolde wedde.
He graunted hem a day such as him leste
On which he wolde be wedded sikerly
And seide he did all this at here requeste
And they with humble entent and buxomly
Knelyng vpon here knees full humblyy
Him thanken alle and thus they han an ende
Of her entent and home agein they wende.
And hereupon he to his officers
Commaundeth for the feste to purueye
And to his priue kniȝtes and squiers
Such charge yaf as him liste on hem leye
And they to his cōmmaundement obeye
And eche of hem doth all his diligence
To do vnto the feste A reuerence.
NOȝt fer from thilke paleys honourable
Where as this markes shope his mariage
Ther stood a throop a siȝt delectable
In which that pore folk of that village
Hadden her bestes and her herbigage
And of her labour toke here sustenᵃnce
Aftir that the erthe yaf hem habundaunce
Among this pouer folk there dwellid a man
Which that was holden pouerest of hem alle
But high god somtyme send can
His grete grace in to a litill oxe stalle
Ianicula men of that throop him calle
A douȝter had he faire I nouȝ to siȝt
And Grisildes this yong mayden hiȝt
But for to speke of vertuous beaute
Than was she oon of the fairest vnder sonne
Full pouerly I fostred vp was she
Ne licorous lust was in here herte I ronne
Well ofter of the welle than of the tonne
She drank and for she wolde vertu please
She knewe well labour but non ydel ease.
But thouȝ this mayden tender were of age
Yeet in the breest of hir virginite
Ther was enclosed up A sad corage
And in gret reuerence and chierte
Here olde pouer fadir fostred she
A fewe sheep spynnyng on felde she kepte
She wolde not be idell till she slepte.
And whan she homward cam she wolde bringe
Wortes or othir herbes tymes ofte
The which she shredde and sethe for his lyuyng
And made here bedde harde and no thing softe
And ay she kepte here fadres lif on lofte
With euery obeyssaunce and diligence
That childe may do to the fadres reuerence
Vpon Grysilde the pouer creature
Full often tyme the markes set his ee
As he on huntyng rode ꝑper/paraduenture
And whan it fill that he miȝt here espie
He not with wanton lokyng of folye
His eyen cast on here but in sadde wise
Vpon here chere he wolde him ofte auyse.
Commending in his herte here wommanhede
And eke here vertu passing any wiȝt
Of so yong age as wel in chere as dede
For thouȝ the peple haue no gret insight
In vertu / he considerid full right
Here bounte and dispose that he wolde
Wedde here oonly yf euer he wedde shulde.
The day of wedding cam but no wiȝt can
Telle what womman that it shulde be
For which merueyle wondreth many a man
And seiden whan they were in priuite
Woll oure lord leue yit his vanitee
Wol he not wedde allas allas the while
Why wol he thus him self and us bigyle
But natheles this markis hath don make
Of gemmes set in golde and in asure
Broches and rynges for Grisildis sake
And of hir clothyng took he the mesure
Of a mayde lyk to hir stature
And eek of othere aournementes alle
That vnto swich a weddyng sholde falle
¶ The tyme of vndren of the same day
Approcheth that this wedding shulde be
And all the Paleys put was in array
Bothe halle and chambres ech in his degree
Houses of office stuffed with plente
There maist thou se of deynteuous vitayle
That may be founde as fer as last ytayle.
This riall markes richely arrayed
Lordes and ladyes in his companye
The which vnto the feste were I praied
And of his retenue the bachillerye
With many a soune of sondry melodye
Vnto the village of the which I tolde
In this array the riȝt way han they holde.
Grisilde god wot of this is full Innocent
That for here shapen was all this array
To fecche water at a welle is went
And torneth home as sone as euer she may
For well she had herd seide that ilke day
The Markes shulde wedde / and if she miȝt
She wolde fayn han seen som of that sight
She thought I woll with othir maydenes stonde
That been my felawes in oure dore and see
The Markes and therfor will I fonde
To don at home as sone as it may be
The labour which that longeth vnto me
And than I may at leyser here beholde
Yf she this day vnto the castell holde.
And as she wolde ouer the threshold gon
The Markes cam and gan here for to calle
And she sette doun here waterpot anon
Beside the thresholde in this oxes stalle
And doun vpon here knees she gan to falle
And with sadde contenᵃnce kneld stille
Till she had herd what was the lordes wille
This thouȝtfull Markes spake vnto this mayde
Full soberly and seide in this manere
Where is your fadir Grisildis he saide
And she with reuerence and humble chere
Answerid lord he is all redy here
And yn she goth withoute lenger lette
And to the Markes she hir fadir mette.
He by the hand toke this pouer man
And seide thus whan he him on side
Ianicula I non othir may ne can
Lenger the plesaunce of myn herte hide
If that thou vouchesaf what so be tyde
Thi douȝter wol I take or that I wende
As for my wif vnto here lyues ende.
Thou louest me that woot I wel certeyn
And art my feithful liege man I bore
And al that liketh me I dar wel sayn
It liketh the / and specially therfore
Telle me that poynt as I haue seid the before
Yef that thou wolt vnto that purpos drawe
To take me as for thi sone in lawe
This sodein caas this man a stoned soo
That rede he wax abasshed and all quakyng
He stood / and vnnethe seide he wordes moo
But oonly thus lord quod he my willyng
Is as ye will ne ageinst your likyng
I will no thing myn owne lord so dere
Right as you lust gouerneth this matere.
Yet woll I qd this Markes softely
That in thi chambre I thou and she
Haue A collacioıı̄un and woost thou why
For I will aske of it here wille be
To be my wif and be ruled aftre me
And al this shall be doon in thi presence
I will not speke oute of thin audience.
And in her chambre whill they were aboute
Here trete which that ye shall aftir here
The peple cam in to the hous withoute
And wondren in how honest manere
Ententifly she kepte hir fadir dere
But vtterly Grisildes wonder miȝt
For neuer erst sawe she such a sight.
¶ No wonder is thouȝ that she were a stoned
To see so greet a geest come in to that place
She neuer was to such geestes woned
For which she lokid with full pale face
But shortly forthe this mater for to chace
These arn the wordes that this markes seide
To this benigne verrile feithful mayde.
Grisilde he said ye shall well vnderstond
It liketh vnto youre fadir and on to me
That I you wedde and eke it may so stonde
As I suppose ye will that it so be
But this demaund aske I first qd he
That syn it shall be don in hasty wise
Wol ye assente orellis you auyse.
I sey this be ye redy with good herte
To all my lust and that I frely may
As me best thinketh to do you laugh or smert
And neuer ye to grucche it niȝt nor day
And eke whan I sey ya ne sey not nay
Nothir be word ne frounyng contenᵃnce
Swere this and here I swere oure alliaunce.
Wondring vpon this word quakyng for drede
She said lord vndigne and vnworthy
Am I to thilke honour that ye me bede
But as ye will your silf so woll I
And here I swere that neuer willingly
In werk ne thouȝt I wol you disobey
For to be deed though me were loth to deye.
This Is Inow Grisilde myn qd he
And forth he goth with a full sobre chiere
Out at the dore and aftir that cam she
And to the peple seide in this manere
This is my wif qd he that stondeth here
Honoureth here and loueth here I you pray
Who so me loueth there is namore to say.
And for that no thing of here olde gere
She shulde bringe in to his hous he bad
That the womman shulde dispoyle here right there
Of which these ladyes were no thing glad
To halde here clothes where yn she was clad
But natheles this mayden briȝt of hewe
From fote to heed they clothen han all newe.
Her heres han they kempt that lay vntressid
Full rudely and with here fyngeres smale
A crowne on here heed they han I dressid
And set is full of ouches gret and smale
Of here array what shuld I make a tale
Vnnethe the peple here knewe for here fayrnesse
Whan she transmeued was in such richesse.
But Markes hath here spoused with a ryng
Brouȝt for the same cause and than here sette
Vpon an hors snowe white and well amiblyng
And to his paleys or he lenger lette
With ioyefull peple that here ladde and mette
Conueyed here and thus the day they spende
In reuel till that the sonne gan descende
And sothely forth this mater for to chace
I sey that to this newe markesesse
God hath such fauoᵘur sent here of his grace
That it ne semyd not by liklynesse
That she that was born and fedde in rudenesse
As in a kote or in an oxes stalle
Was as well tauȝt as any wiȝt in an emperours halle
To euery wiȝt she woxen is so dere
And wurshipfull and folk there as she was bore
And from here birthe knowe here yere by yere
Vnnethe trowed they but dorst haue swore
That to Ianicula of which I spak before
She douȝter was but as by coniecture
Hem thouȝt she was an othir creature
For thouȝ that euer vertuous was she
She was encresid in such excellence
Of thewes gode I set in hiȝe bounte
And so discret and fayre of eloquence
So benigne and digne of reuerence
And coude so the peples herte embrace
That eche here loueth that loketh on here face.
Not oonly of saluces in the toun
Publissed the bounte of here name
But eke beside in eche a regioıı̄un
Yef oon saith well an othir saith the same
So spredith of here hiȝe bounte the fame
That men and wommen as well yong as olde
Goon to saluce vpon here to byholde.
Thus Walter lowly nay but rially
Weddid with fortunat honestee
In goddis pees lyueth full esily
At home and grace outeward Inough had he
And for he saugh that vnder lowe degree
Was ofte vertu hid the peple him helde
A prudent man and that is sene full selde
Not oonly this Grisilde throuȝ here witte
Coude all the fete of wyues homlynesse
But eke whan the case required it
The comune profiȝt coude she redresse
Ther nas discord rancour ne heuynesse
In all that lond that she ne coude apese
And wisely bringe hem alle in hertes ese
Though that her husbond absent were or non
If gentill men or othir of here contre
Were wroth she wolde hem bringe at oon
So wise and ripe wordes had she
And Iugementes of so gret equite
That she fro heuene sent was as men wende
People to faire and euery wrong to amende.
Nat long tyme aftir that this Grisilde
Was weddid she A douȝter hath I bore
All had here leuer han born a knaue childe
Glad was this Markes and his folk therfor
For thouȝ a mayden child come all bifore
She may vnto A knaue child atteyne
By liklyhed syn she is not bareyn
Secunda Pars.
Ther fill as it byfallith tymes moo
Whan that this child hath souked but a throwe
This Markes in his herte longith so
To tempte his wif here sadnesse for to knowe
That he ne miȝt out of his herte throwe
This merueylous desire for to assaye
Nedeles god woot he thouȝt here for to affraye.
He had assaied here I nough bifore
And fande euer hir gode what nedith it
Here for to tempte and euery more and more
But as for me I sey that euill is it
Though some men preise it for A sotill witte
To assay a wif whan it is no nede
And put her in anguissh and in drede
For wich this Markes wrouȝt in this manere
He cam a niȝt a lone there as she lay
With sterne face and with truble chiere
And seide thus Grisilde qd he that day
That I you toke out of your pore array
And put you in estat in hiȝe nobelesse
Ye haue it not forgeten as I gesse
I sey Grisilde this present dignite
In which I haue put you as I trowe
Maketh you not forgetfull for to be
That I you toke in pore estat full lowe
For any wele ye mote your self knowe
Take heed of euery word what I sey
There is no wiȝt that herith it but we twey.
Ye wot your self wel hou that ye cam here
In to this hous it is not longe agoo
And thouȝ to me ye bene riȝt leef and dere
Vnto my gentiles ye ben no thing soo
They sey to me it is riȝt gret shame and woo
For to ben subgectis and bene in seruage
To the that born art of a small lynage.
And namely syn thi douȝter was I bore
This wordes han they spoken douteles
But I desire as I haue don bifore
To lede my lif with hem in reste and pees
I may not in this caas be recheles
I mot do with thi douȝter for the beste
Nat as I wolde but as my gentilese leste.
And yet god woot this is full loth to me
But natheles withouten your wityng
I will not do but thus will I qd he
That ye to me assenten in this thing
Shewe now your pacience in your werkyng
That ye me hiȝt and swore in your village
The day that maked was oure mariage.
Whan she had herd all this she not ameued
Was neithir in word chiere ne contenᵃnce
For as it semed she was not agreued
She said lord all lithe in your plesaunce
My childe and I with herty obeissance
Ben youres alle and ye mowe saue or spille
Your owne thing werkith aftir your owne wille
Ther may no thing so mot god my soule saue
Like vnto me that you may displese
Ne I desire no thing for to haue
Ne drede for to lese saufly ye
This will is in myn herte and ay shall be
No lengthe tyme or deth may this deface
Ne chaunge my corage to an othir place.
Glad was this Markes for here answering
But he feyned as he were not so
All drery was his chiere and his lokyng
Whan that he shulde out of the chambre goo
Sone aftir this a forlong wey or twoo
He priuely hath tolde all his entent
Vnto A man and to his wif him sent
A maner sergeaunt was this priue man
The which he feithfull often founden hadde
In thinges grete and eke such folk wel can
Don execucioıı̄un on thinges badde
The lord knewe well that he him loued and dredde
And whan this sergeaunt knewe wel his lordes wille
In to the chambre he stalkith him full stille
Madame he seide ye mot foryeue it me
Thouȝ I do thing to which I am constreyned
Ye ben so wys that riȝt well knowen ye
That lordes hestis may not be feyned
They mowe well be bewayled and compleyned
But men mot nedes to her lust obeye
And so will I ther is nomore to sey.
This childe am I commaunded for to take
And spake nomore but out the childe he hente
Dispitously and gan a chiere make
Riȝt as he wolde han slayn it or he wente
Grisildes mote all suffre and all consente
And as a lambe she sitteth meke and stille
And let this cruell sergeaunt han all his wille.
Suspecious was the fame of that man
Suspect his face suspect his wordes also
Suspect the tyme in which he this bigan
Alas here douȝter that she loued so
She wende he wolde han slayn it riȝt so
But natheles she wepte nouȝt nor siked
Confermyng here to that the Markes liked.
But at the last speke she bigan
And namely she to the sergeaunt praide
So as he was a worthi gentill man
That she miȝt kisse here childe or that it deyde
And in here barme this litill childe she leyde
With full sadde face and gan the childe to kisse blisse
And lulled it and aftir gan it kisse.
And thus she saide aftir in here benigne voyce
Fare well my childe I shall the neuer see
But syn I haue marked the with the croyce
Of thilke fader blessid mot he be
That for us diede vpon a cros of tree
Thi soule litill childe I now be take
For this niȝt dyen shalt thou for my sake.
I trowe that to a Norice in this caas
It had ben hard this routhe for to see
Well miȝt a moder than han cried allas
But natheles stedfast and so sadde was she
That she endured all aduersite
And to the sergeaunt mekely she saide
Haue here agein your litil yonge mayde
Goth now qd she and do my lordes heste
But oon thing will I pray you of your grace
That but my lord forbad you at the leste
Burieth this litill body in som place
That bestis ne no briddes it to race
But he no word to the purpos wolde sey
But toke the childe and went vpon his wey.
This sergeaunt cam in to his lord agein
And of Grisildes wordes and here chiere
He tolde him point for poynte in short and pleyne
And him presentith with his douȝter dere
Somwhat this lord had routhe in his manere
But natheles his purpos had he stille
As lordes don whan they will han ther wille.
And bade this sergeaunt that he priuely
With alle circumstaunces tenderly
And carye it in a cofre or in A lappe
But vpon peyne his heed of for to swappe
That noman shuld knowe of this entent
Ne whan he come nor whider he went.
But at Boloigne to his sustir dere
That thilke tyme of Pauyk was Countesse
He shulde it take and shewe there this matere
Byseching here to do here besinesse
This childe to fostren in al gentilnesse
And whoz childe that it was he bade here hide
From euery wiȝt for auȝt that may be tide
This sergeaunt goth and hath fulfilled this thing
But now to the Markes now retorne we
For now goth he full ymagynyng
If be his wifes chere he miȝt se
Or by her word aperceyue that she
Were chaunged / but here coude he neuer fynde
But euer in oon I like sadde and kynde.
As glad as humble as besy in seruice
And eke in loue as she was wont to be
Was she to him in euery maner wise
Ne of hir douȝter neuer a word spak she
None accident for none aduersite
Was seyn in here ne neuer her douȝter name
Ne nempned she for ernest ne for game.
Tercia Pars.
In this estat there passid beth iiij yere
Or she with childe was but as god wolde
A knaue childe she bar by this waltere
Ful gracious and full faire for to beholde
And whan that folk vnto his fadir tolde
Not oonly he but all his contre merye
Was for this childe and god they thanke and herye
Whan it was ij yere olde and from the breest
Departed from his noryce on a day
This Markes cauȝt yet an othir leest
To tempte his wif yet ofter if he may
O nedeles was she tempted in assay
But weddid men ne knowe no mesure
Whan that they fynde a pacient creature.
Wif qd this Markes ye han herd or this
My people sikely berith oure mariage
And namely syn my sone I born is
Now it is wers than euer it was in all oure age
The murmoᵘur sleeth myn herte and my corage
For to myn eres cometh the voyce so smert
That well ny destroyed hath all myn hert
Now sey they thus whan Walter is agon
Than shall the blood of Ianicule succede
And be oure lord for othir haue we none
Such wordes seith my people it is no drede
Wel ouȝt I of such murmoᵘur take hede
For certeinly I drede such sentence
Thouȝ that they not pleinly speke in my audience.
I wold haue my pees if that I miȝt
Wherfor I am disposid vtterly
As I his sustir serued be niȝt
Riȝt so thenke I to serue him priuely
This warne I you for ye not sodeinly
Oute of your self for no woo shulde crye
Beth pacient I pray you now and eke merye.
I haue qd she saide thus and euer shall
I woll no thing ne nil no thing certeyn
But as you list not greueth me at all
Thouȝ that my doughter and my sone be sleyn
At your cōmmaundement that is to seyn
I haue had no part of children tweyne
But first sekenesse and aftir woo and peyne.
Ye be my lord do with your owne thing
Riȝt as you list askith no rede of me
For as I lefte at home all my clothing
Whan I cam furst to you right so qd she
Lefte I my will and alle my liberte
And toke your clothing wherfor I you pray
Doth your plesaunce I will to your lust obeye.
And certes yef I hadde prescience
Youre will to knowe or yet your lust me tolde
I wolde it do withoute negligence
But now I woot your lust and what ye wolde
All youre plesaunce ferme and stable holde ~
For wist I that my deth miȝt do you ease
Riȝt gladly wolde I deye you to plese ~
Deth may make no comparisoıı̄un
Vnto oure loue and whan this Markes say
The constaunce of his wif he cast a doun
His eyen ij and wondreth that she may
In pacience suffre all this array
And forth he goth with drery contenᵃnce
But to his hert it was riȝt high plesaunce.
This vgely sergeaunt in the same wise
That he here douȝter cauȝt riȝt so qd she
Or werse yef men wers can deuise
Hath sent here sone that was full of beaute
And euer in oon so pacient was she
That she no chiere made of heuynesse
But kist here sone and aftir gan it blesse.
Saf this she prayd him if that he miȝt
Here litill sone he wolde in erthe graue
His tendre lymes delicat to siȝt
Fro foules and fro bestis for to saue
But she non answere of him miȝt haue
He went his wey as him no thing thouȝt
But to Boloigne he tendirly it brouȝt.
This Markes wondreth euer lenger the more
Vpon here pacience and yef that he
Ne had sothely knowen there bifore
That parfiȝtly here children loued she
He wolde haue wend that of som sotiltee
And of malice or for cruel corage
That she had sufferd this with sad visage
But wel he knewe that next him self certeyn
She loued here children best in euery wise
But now of wommen will I asken pleyn
Yif these assaies miȝt not suffice
What coude a sturdy husbond more deuyse
To preue here wifhod and here stedfastnesse
And he continuyng euer in sturdinesse
But there ben folk of such condicioıı̄un
That whan they han a certain purpos take
They can not stynte of here entencioun
But riȝt as they were bounden to A stake
They will not of here furst purpos slake
Riȝt so this Markes fully hath purposid
To tempte his wif as he was furst disposid.
He wayteth if by word or contenᵃnce
That she to him were chaungid of corage
But neuer coude he fynde in here variaunce
She was ay in oon hert and in visage
And ay the further that she was in age
The more trewe if that it were possible
She was to him in loue the more penible
For which it semed thus that of hem ij
There nas but oon wille but as walter liste
That same lust was here plesaunce also
And god be thanked all fill for the beste
She shewid well for no wordes vnreste
A wif as of here self no thing ne sholde
Wille in effect but as her husbond wolde
The slaunder of walter ofte and wide spradde
That of A cruell hert he wikkidly
For he a pouer womman weddid hadde
Hath murdred bothen his children priuely
Such murmoᵘur was among hem comonly
No wonder for to the peples ere
Ther cam no word but that they mordred were
Which that as his peple there bifore
Had loued him wel the slaundre of his defame
Made hem that they hated him therfore
To ben a murdrer it is an hateful name
But natheles for ernest ne for game
He of his cruell purpos nolde stynte
To tempte his wif was set all his entent.
Whan that this douȝter twelue yere was of age
He to the court of rome in subtill wise
Enformed of his will sent his message
Commaunding him such bulles to deuyse
As to his cruell purpos may suffice
How that the pope as for his peples reste
Bad him to wedde an othir wif yef that him leste.
I sey he bad they shulde counterfete
The popes bulles makyng mencioıı̄un
That he hath leue his furst wif to lete
As by the popes dispensacioıı̄un
To stynte rancour and discencioıı̄un
Betwix his peple and him thus spake the bulle
The which they han publisshed at the fulle.
The rude people as it no wondir is
Wenden full well that it had ben riȝt so
But whan that tyding came to Grisildes
I deme that here hert was full woo
But she I like sadde for euermo
Disposid was this humble creature
The aduersite of fortune to endure.
Abiding euer his lust and his plesaunce
To whom she had gyuen here seluen all
As to here verrily worldly suffisaunce
But shortely if this story telle I shall
This Markes writen hath inespeciall
A lettir in which he shewid his entent
And sikerly he to Boloigne it sent.
To the Erle of Pauyk the which that had tho
Weddid his sustir preid he specially
To bringe hom agein his children two
In honourable estat openly
But oon thing he him preid vtterly
That he no wiȝt thouȝ they wolde enquere
Shulde not telle whoz children that they were
Bt seide the mayden shulde weddid be
Vnto the Markes of saluces anon
And as this Erle was praid riȝt so did he
For at a day sette he on his way is gon
Toward saluces and lordes many oon
In riche array this mayden for to gyde
Here yong brothir riding be here side
Arayed was toward here mariage
This fressh may full of gemmys clere
Hir brothir which that vij yere of age
Arrayed eke full fressh in his manere
And thus in gret noblesse and with glad chere
Toward Saluce ryding his iornay
From day to day the shape hem in here way

Among all this aftir his wikked vsage
This Markes yet his wif to tempte more
To the vtterest preef of her corage
Fully to han experience and lore
Yef that she were as stedefast as before
He on a day in open audience
Full bostefully hath seid all this sentence
Certes Grisildes. I had I nough plesaunce
To haue you to my wif for your godenesse
As for your trouthe and your obeysaunce
Not for your lynage ne for your richesse
But now I knowe well in verry sothfastnesse
That in gret lordship if I woll auyse
There is gret seruitude in sondry wise.
I may nat as euery plouȝ man may
My people constreyneth me to take
An othir wif and cryen day be day
And eke the Pope rancour for to slake
Consentith it that I dar vndertake
I cam and nakid mot I torne agein
Al your plesaunce folwe wolde I fayn
But yet I hope it be not your entent
That I smokles oute of your paleis went.
Ye coude not // so dishonest a thing do
That thilke wombe in which your children lay
Shulde before this people in my walkyng
Beseen all bare wherfor I you pray
Let me not like A worme go by the way
Remembre you myn owne lord so dere
I was your wif thouȝ I vnworthy were.
Wherfor in guerdoıı̄un of myn maydenhede
Which that I brouȝt and not awey it bere

And yef that she be riche of hie parage
Than seist thou that it is a tormentrye
To suffre here pride and here malecolye
And yef that she be faire thou verry knaue
Thou seist that euery holour will here haue
She may no while in chastite abide
That is assayled vpon eche a side
Thou seist that some folk desireth us for richesse
Som for oure shap and som for our fairnesse
And some for she can eithir synge or daunce
And some for gentilnesse and daliaunce
Some for here handes and here armes smale
Thus goth al to the deuill by thi tale
Thou seist men may not kepe a castell wal
It may so longe assailed be ouer all
And yef that she be foule thou seist that she
Coueyteth euery man that she may see
For as a spaynel she will on him lepe
Till that she fynde som man here for to chepe
Ne non so grey goos goth there yn the lake
As seist thou will be wythouten a make
And seist it is an hard thing for to wolde
A thyng that noman will his thankes holde
Thus seist thou lorell whan thou gost to bedde
And that no wise man nedith for to wedde
Ne noman that entendeth vnto heuene
With wilde thonder dynt and fyry leuene
Mote thi wikkid necke be to broke
Thou seist that dropping houses and eke smoke
And chiding wyues make men to fle
Out of here owne houses O benedicite
What eyleth such an holde man for to chyde
Thou seist we wyues will oure vices hide
Till we be fast and than we will hem shewe
Well may that be a prouerbe of a shrewe
Thou seist that oxen asses hors and houndes
They bene assaied at dyuers stoundes
Basyns lauours or that men hem bye
Spones stoles and all such husbondrye
And so be pottes clothes and array
But folk of wyues make non assay
Till they be weddid olde dotard shrewe
And than saist thou we will oure vices shewe
Thou seist also that it displesith me
But if thou wilt preyse my beaute
And but that thou poure alwey vpon my face
And clepe me faire dame in euery place
And but thou make a feste on thilke day
That I was born and make me fressh and gay
And but thou do my norice honour
And to my chambre wythynne my bour
And to my fadres folk and his allyes
Thou seist thou olde barell full of lyes
And yet of oure apprentice Iankyn
For his crisp heer shynyng as gold so fyne
And for he squyereth me bothe vp and doun
Yet hast thou cauȝt a fals suspectioıı̄un
I will him nouȝt thouȝ thou were dede to morwe
But telle me this why hidest thou with sorwe
The keyes of thi cheste awey from me
It is my gode as well as thin parde
Whan wenest thou make an ydiot of oure dame
Now by the lord that callid is saint Iame
Thou shalt not thouȝ that thou were wood
Be maistir of my body and of my good
That oon thou shalt forgo maugre thin eyen
What helpith on me enquere or spyen
I trowe thou woldest locke me in thi cheste
Thou shuldest sey wif go where thou leste
Take your disport I nill leue no tales
I knowe you for a trewe wif dam Alice
We loue noman that takith kepe or charge
Where that we gon we will be at oure large
Of alle men blessid mot he be
The wise Astrologen Daun Protholome
That seith this prouerbe in his almageste
Of alle men his wisdom is hyest
That rekkith not who hath the world in honde
By this prouerbe thou shalt vnderstonde
Haue thou Inouȝ what dar the rekke or care
Hou merily that othir folkes fare
For certes olde dotard by your leue
Ye shall haue queynte riȝt I now at eue
He is to gret a nygard that woll werne
A man to liȝt a candel at his lanterne
He shall neuer the lasse liȝt parde
Haue thou I now thou dar not pleyne the
Thou seist also that yef we make us gay
With clothing and with precious array
That it is perill of oure chastite
And yet with sorwe thou wilt enforce the
And sey these wordes in the Apostles name
In habite made with chastite and shame
The wommen shall apparaill you qd he
In honest array aftir your degree
And not in tressid heer and gay
Ne in thinges of costelew array
As perles ne with golde ne clothes riche
Aftir thi texte ne aftir thi rubrich
I will not worche as moch as is a gnatte
Thou seidest this that I was like a catte
But who so will senge a cattis skyn
That woll dwoll the catte dwellen yn
And yef the cattis skyn be slike and gay
She woll not dwellen in house half a day
But forth she will or any day be dawed
To shewe here skyn and go a caterwawed
This is to say if I be gay sir shrewe
I woll renne oute my borell for to shewe
Sir olde fooll what helpeth the to espyen
Thouȝ thou prey Argus with his .C. yen
To be my warde corps as he can best
In feith he shall not kepe me but if me lest
Yet coude I make his berd so mote I the
Thou seidest eke that there were thinges three
The which thinges troublen all the erthe
That no wiȝt may endure the fierthe
O leue sir shrewe seint Iohn short thi lif
Yet prechest thou and seist an hatefull wif
I rekenyd is oon of this meschaunces
Ben there non othir resemblaunces
That ye may likne youre ꝑper/parables to
But yef a sely wif be oon of tho
Thou liknest eke a wommans loue to helle
To bareyn lond there water may not dwelle
Thou liknest eke also to wilde fyre
The more it brennith the more it hath desire
To consume euery thing that brent will be
Thou seist like // wormes shende a tree / as
Riȝt so a womman distroieth here husbonde
This knowen they that ben to wyues bonde
Lordinges riȝt thus as ye han vnderstond
Bar I stifly my olde husbondes on hond
That thus they seiden in here dronkenesse
And all was fals but that I toke witnesse
On Iankyn and of my nece also
A lord the peyne I dede hem and the woo
Full gilteles by goddis swete pyne
For as an hors I coude byte and whyne
I coude pleyne and I was in the gilt
Orellis often tyme I had ben spilt
Who so to melle comith first grynt
I pleyne first so was oure werre stynt
They were full glad to excusen hem full blyue
Of thing of which they neuer gilt here lyue
Of wenches wolde I beren him on honde
Whan that for sike thei miȝt vnnethes stonde
Yet tikelid I his herte for that he
Wende I had had of him so gret chierte
I swere that all my walkyng out by niȝt
Was for to espien wenches that he diȝt
Vnder that colour had I full many a mirthe
For all such wit is yeue us in oure birthe
Deceyte weping spynnyng god hath yeue
To wommen kyndely whill they may lyue
And thus of oon thing I auaunte me
Atte the ende I had the bette in eche degree
By sleiȝte or force or som maner thing
As by continuell murmoᵘur or grucching
Namely a bedde they had meschuᵃnce
There wolde I chide and do hem no plesaunce
I wolde no lenger in the bedde abyde
Yef that I felt his arme ouer my side
Till he had made his raunsom vnto me
Than wolde I suffre him to do his nycete
And therfor euery man this tale I telle
Wynne who so may for all is for to selle
Wyth empty hond men may non haukes lure
For wynnyng wold I all his lust endure
And make me a feyned appetite
And yet in bacoıı̄un had I neuer delite
That made me that euer I wold hem chide
For thouȝ the xxxx had seten him beside
I wolde nouȝt spare hem at her owne bord
For by my trouthe I quitte hem word by word
As helpe me verry god omnipotent
Thouȝ I riȝt now shulde make my testament
I ne owe hem a word for it is quitte
I brouȝt it so a boute be my witte
That they must yeue it vp as for the beste
Orellis had we neuer bene in reste
For thouȝ he lokid as a wood lyoıı̄un
Yet shulde he faile of his conclusioıı̄un
Than wolde I sey gode leef take keep
Hou mekely lokith wilkyn oure sheep
Come nere my spouse and let my ba thi cheke
Ye shulden be all pacient and meke
And haue a swete spiced conscience
Sith ye preche so of Iobes pacience
Suffreth alwey syn ye so wel can preche
And but ye certein I shall you teche
That it is faire to haue a wif in pees
Oon of us two must bowen douteles
And sith a man is more resonable
Than womman is ye must ben sufferable
What eileth you to grucche and grone
Hit is for ye wolde haue my queynte allone
Why take it all lo haue it euery del
Petir I shrewe you but if ye loue it wel
For I wolde selle my bele shose
I coude walke as fressh as is A rose
But I will kepe it for your owne toth
Ye be to blame by god I sey you soth
Such maner wordes had we on honde
Now will I speke of my fierthe husbond
My fierthe husbond was A reuelour
This is to seyn he had A paramour
And I was yong and full of ragerye
Styborn and strong and ioly as A pye
I coude well daunce to an harpe smale
And synge I wys as any nytyngale
Whan I had dronke A drauȝt of swete wyn
Metelleus the foule cherle the swyne
That with A staf by raft his wif here lif
For she dranke wyn I nough and if I had bene his wif
Ne shulde he not haue kept me from drynke
And aftir wyne on venus must I thinke
For also siker as colde engendrith hayle
A likerous mouth must haue A likerous tayle
A womman vynolent is no defense
This knowen lecchours by experience
But lord crist what it remembrith me
Vpon my youthe and vpon my iolite
It tikeleth me aboute myn herte rote
Vnto this day it doth myn herte bote
That I haue had my worlde as in my tyme
But age allas it will all envenyme
Hath me be rafte my beaute and my leste
Let go fare well the deuill it all breste
The floure is gon ther is nomore to telle
The bren as I best can now must I selle
But yet to riȝt mery wold I fonde
Now will I telle of my fierthe husbond
I sey I had in hert gret despite
That he of any othir had delyte
But he was quytte by god and be saint Ioce
I made him of the same wode a groce .
Nat of my body in no foule manere
But certeinly I made folk such chiere
That in his owne grece I made him frye
For anger and for verry ielousye
By god in erthe I was his purgatory
For which I hope his soule be in glory
For god it wot he sat full ofte and songe
Whan that his shoo full bitterly him wronge
Ther was no wiȝt saue god and he that wist
In many wise hou sore that I him twist
He dyed whan I cam from Iherusalem
And lithe I graue vnder the rode beem
All is his tombe nouȝt so corious
As was the sepulcre of him Daryus
Which that Appellus wrouȝt so sotilly
It nys but wast to burye him so preciously
Lat him farewell god yef his soule reste
He is now in his graue and in his cheste
Now of my .v. husbond woll I telle
God lete neuer his soule to come in helle
And yet was he to me the moost shrewe
That fele I on my rybbes all by rewe
And euer shall vnto myn ending day
But in oure bedde he was so fressh and gay
And therwith also wel coude he me glose
Whan that he wolde haue my bele shose
That thouȝ that he had bet me on euery bone
He coude wynne agein my loue anon
I trowe I loued him best for that he
Was of his loue daungerous to me
We wommen haue if that I shall not lye
In this mater a queynte fantasie
Wayte what thing we may not liȝt haue
There aftir woll we crye and craue
Forbede us thing and that we desiren we
Prese on us faste and than woll we flee
With daunger we oute all oure chaffare
Gret prese at market makith dere ware
And to gret chepe is holden at litill price
This knoweth euery womman that is wise
My .v. husbonde god his soule blesse
Which that I toke for loue and no richesse
He was somtyme a Clerk of Oxenford
And had laft scole and went at hom to bord
With my gossib dwelling in oure toun
God saue here soule his name was Alisoıı̄un
She knewe myn herte and eke my pryuite
Bet than oure parissh prest as mote I the
To here bewreyed I my counseill al
For had my husbond pissed on a wal
Or done a thing that shuld a cost his lif
To here and to an othir worthi wif
And to my Nece which that I loued wel
I wolde a tolde his counseill euery del
And so I dede full often god it wot
That made his face often rede and hote
For verry shame and blamyd him self that he
Had tolde to me so gret a priuite
And so befell that ones in a lent
So often tymes I vnto my gossib went
For euer I loued yet to be gay
And for to walke in March Aueryl and May
Fro house to house to here sondry tales
That Iankyn Clerk and my gossib Dam Alice
And I my self in to the feldes went
Myn husbond was at londoıı̄un all that lent
I had the better leyser for to pleye
And for to se and eke for to be seye
Of lusty folk where wist I what my grace
Was shapen for to be or in what place
Therfor made I my visitacions
To vigilies and to processions
To preching eke and to this pilgrymages
To pleying of miracles and of mariages
And wered vpon my gay scarlet gytes
This wormes ne this mothis ne thez mytes
Vpon myn perell frete hem neuer a dele
And woste thou why for they were vsed wel
Now will I tellen forth that happid me
I sey that in the feldes walked we
Till truly we had such daliaunce
This Clerk and I that of my purueaunce
I spak to him and seid him hou that he
Yef I were widewe shulde wedde me
For certeinly I sey for no bobaunce
Yet was I neuer withouten purueaunce
Of mariage ne of othir thinges eke
I holde a mouses hert not worth a leke
That hath but an hole for to sterte to
And yef that I fayle than is all I do
But now sir lat me se what I shall seyn
A haa by god I haue my tale agein
Whan that my fourthe husbond was on bere
I wepte algate and made sory chere
As wyues moten for it is vsage
And with my kerchef couerid my visage
But for I was purueyed of a make
I wept but small and that I vndertake
To chirche was myn husbond born on morwe
With neigbours that for him made sorwe
And Iankyn oure Clerk was oon of tho
As helpe me god whan that I saugh him go
Aftir the beere me thouȝt he had a peyre
Of leggis and feet so clene and feyre
That all myn herte it was vnto his holde
He was I trowe xx wynter olde
And I was xl. and I shall sey soth
But yet I had alwey a coltes toth
Gatte tothed I was and that be cam me wel
I had the prynte of seint venus seal
As helpe me god I was a lusty oon
And faire and riche and yonge and well begon
And truly as myn husbondes tolde me
I had the best quoniam that miȝt be
Myn ascendent was taure and Mars therynne
Allas Allas that euer loue was synne
I folwed ay myn inclinacioıı̄un
Whan they shewed me her peticioıı̄un
That made me I coude not withdrawe
My chambre of venus from a gode felawe
What shulde I sey but at the monthes ende
This ioly clerk Iankyn that was so hende
Hath wedded me with gret solempnite
And to him yaf I all the lond and fee
That euer was me yeuen there before
But aftirward repentid me full sore
He nolde suffre no thing of my list
Be god he smote me ones on the list
For that I rente oute of his book a leef
That of the stroke myn ere wexe all deef
Styborne I was as is a lyonesse
And of myn tonge a verry iangeleresse
And walke I wolde as I hadde beforn
From house to house thouȝ the contrary he had sworn
For which he often tymes wolde preche
And me olde romeyn gestis teche
How he simplicius gallus left his wif
And here forsok for terme of alle his lif
Nouȝt but for opene hede he here say
Lokyng out at his dore vpon a day
An othir Romayn tolde he me by name
That for his wif was at a someres game
Withouten his witing he forsook here eke
And than wolde he vpon his bible seke
That ilke prouerbe of ecclesiaste
Where he cōmmaundeth and forbedith faste
Man shall not suffre his wif go royle aboute
Than wolde he sey riȝt thus withouten doute
Who so bildeth his hous all of salwes
And priketh his blynde hors ouer the falwes
And suffre his wif to go seken halwes
Is worthi to ben honged on the galwes
But all for nouȝt I sette not an hawe
Of his prouerbe ne of his olde sawe
Ne I wolde not of him corrected be
I hate hem that my vices telle me
And so do mo god wot of us moo than I
This made him with me wode outerly
I nolde not forbere him in no caas
Now will I sey you soth be seint Thomas
Why that I rent oute of his book a lef
For which he smot me for that I was def
He hadde a book that gladly niȝt and day
For his disport he wolde rede all day
He clepith it valerye and Theofrast
Of which book he lough alwey ful fast
And eke there was a Clerk somtyme at Rome
A Cardinall that hiȝt seint Ierome
That made a book ageyn Iouynyan
In which book ther was eke Terculan
Crisippus Trocula and Helowys
That was Abbesse not fer from Parys
And eke the ꝑper/parables of salamon
Ouydes art and bokes many oon
And alle these were bounden in oon volume
And euery niȝt and day was his custume
Whan him had leyser and vacacioıı̄un
From othir worldly occupacioıı̄un
To reden in this book of wicked wyues
He knewe of hem mo legendis and lyues
Than ben of gode wyues in the bible
For trusteth well it is an impossible
That any clerk will speke gode of wyues
But yef it be of holy seintes lyues
Ne of non othir womman neuer the mo
Who peyntith the lyon telle me who
By god if wommen had writen storyes
As Clerkes han withynne here oratoryes
And let here lechour diȝt here all the niȝt
Whill that the corps lay in the flore vp riȝt
And some haue dryue nayles in here brayn
Whill that they slept and thus they han hem sleyn
Some haue yeue poisoıı̄un in here drynke
He spak more harme than hert may thinke
And therwith all he knewe mo prouerbes
Than in this world there growen gras or herbes
Bet is qd he thine habitacioıı̄un
Be with a lyoıı̄un or a foule dragoıı̄un
Than with a womman vsing for to chide
Bet is qd he hie in the roof abide
Than with a wickid womman doun in the house
They bene so wickid and so contrariouse
They haten that her husbondes loueth ay
He said that a womman cast her shame awey
Whan she cast of her smok and further mo
A faire womman but if she be chast also
Is like a goldryng in a sowes nose
Who wolde wene or who wold suppose
The woo that in myn herte was and pyne
And whan I sey he nolde neuer fyne
To reden on this cursed boke all niȝt
All sodeinly iij leues haue I pliȝt
Out of his book as he redde and eke
I with my fest so toke him on the cheke
That in oure fire he fill bacward adoun
And vp he stirte as doth a wood lyoıı̄un
And with his fest he smote me on the hede
That in the flore I lay as I were dede
And whan he say hou stille that I lay
He was agast and wold a fledde awey
Till at the last out of my swouȝ I brayde
O hast thou slein me fals theef I sayde
And for my land thou hast mordered me
Or I be dede yet will I kysse the
And nere he come and knelid faire adoun
And saide dere spouse Alisoıı̄un
As helpe me god I shall neuer smyte
That I haue don it is thi self to wyte
Foryeue it me and that I the beseke
And yet eft sone I hit him on the cheke
And said theef thus must I me wreke
Now woll I dye I may no lenger speke
But at the last with moch care and woo
We fill accorded by us seluen two
He yaf me all the bridell in myn hond
To haue the gouernᵃnce of house and lond
And of his tonge and of his lond also
And made him brenne his book riȝt tho
And whan that I had goten vnto me
By maistry all the souereynte
And that he had seid myn owne swete wif
Do as the list terme of all thi lif
Kepe thine honoᵘur and kepe eke myn estat
Aftir that day we had neuer debate
God helpe me so I was to him as kynde
As any wif from denmark vnto ynde
And also trewe and so was he to me
I pray to god that sitte in mageste
So blisse his soule for his mercy dere
Now will I sey my tale if ye will here
The frere lough whan he had herd all this
Now dame qd he so haue I ioye and blisse
This is a longe preambule of a tale
And whan the sompnoᵘur herd the frere gale
Loo qd the sompnoᵘur goddis armes two
A frere will entremente him euer moo
Loo gode men a frere and eke a flye
Woll falle in euery dissh and make a medly
What spekest thou of preambulacioıı̄un
What aumble or trotte or pees or go sitte adoun
Thou lettist this disport in this manere
Ye wilt thou so sir sompnoᵘur qd the frere
Now be my feith I shall or that I go
Telle of a sompnoᵘur such a tale or two
That alle the folk shall laughen in this place
Now ellis frere I will be shrewe thi face
Qd this sompnoᵘur and I beshrewe me
But yef I telle tales ij or three
Of freres or I come to Sydyngborne
That I shall make thin herte for to morne
For well I wot thi pacience is gon
Oure oost cryed pees and that anon
And seide let the womman telle here tale
Ye fare as folk that dronken ben of Ale
Do dame telle forth your tale and that is best
All redy sir qd she riȝt as you lest
If I haue licence of this worthi frere
Yes dame telle forth qd he and I will here .
Here endith the Prolog of the wif of Bathe With here tale folwing

(base) Telleth youre tale / and lat the Somnour be
(base) ¶ Nay quod the Somnour / lat hym seye to me
(base) What so hym list whan it comth to my lot
(base) By god / I shal hym quyten euery grot
(base) I shal hym telle / which a gret honour
(base) It is / to be a flaterynge lymytour
(base) And of / many another manere cryme
(base) Which nedeth nat rehercen / for this tyme
(base) And his office / I shal hym telle ywys
(base) ¶ Oure hoost answerde / pees namoore of this
(base) And after this / he seyde vnto the frere
(base) Tel forth youre tale / leeue maister deere
(base) Here endeth the prolog

div.l: (base) Whilom / ther was dwellynge in my contree
(base) An Erchedekne / a man of hy degree
(base) That boldely / dide execucioun
(base) In punysshynge of Fornicacioun
(base) Of wicchecraft and eek of Bawderye
(base) Of diffamacioun / and auoutrye
(base) Of chirche Reues / and of testamentz
(base) Of contractes / and eek of lakke of sacramentz
(base) Of vsure / and of Symonye also
(base) But certes / lecchours / dide he grettest wo
(base) They sholde syngen if that they were hent
(base) And smale tytheres were foule yschent
(base) If any persoun / wold vpon hem pleyne
(base) Ther myghte asterte hym no pecunial peyne
(base) For smale tithes and for smal offryng
(base) He made the peple ful pitusly to syng
(base) For er the bysschop caght hem with hys hooc
(base) They were in the erchdeknys book /
(base) And thanne had he thurgh hys Iurisdiccion
(base) Power to do on hem correccion
(base) He hadde a Somnour / redy to his hond
(base) A slyer boy / nas noon in Engelond
(base) For subtilly / he hadde his espiaille
(base) That taughte hym / wher hym myghte auaille
(base) He koude spare / of lecchours / oon or two
(base) To techen hym / to foure and twenty mo
(base) For theigh this Somnour / wood were as an hare
(base) To telle his harlotrye / I wol nat spare
(base) For we been / out of his correccioun
(base) They han of vs / no Iurisdiccioun
(base) Ne neuere shullen / terme of hir lyues
(base) ¶ Peter / so been wommen of the Styves
(base) Quod the Somnour / yput out of my cure
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) ¶ Pees with myschaunce / and with mysauenture
(base) Thus seyde oure hoost / and lat hym telle his tale
(base) Now telleth forth / thogh that the Somnour gale
(base) Ne spareth nat myn owene mayster deere
(base) ¶ This false theef this Somnour / quod the frere
(base) Hadde alwey / baudes redy to his hond
(base) As any hauk to lure in Engelond
(base) That tolde hym / al the secree that they knewe
(base) For hire aqueyntance / was nat come of newe
(base) They weren / hise Approwours pryuely
(base) He took hymself / a greet profit ther by
(base) His maister knew nat alwey / what he wan
(base) Withouten mandement a lewed man
(base) He koude somne / on peyne of cristes curs
(base) And they were glade / for to fille his purs
(base) And make hym / grete festes atte nale
(base) And right as Iudas / hadde purses smale
(base) And was a theef right swich a theef was he
(base) His maister / hadde but half his duetee
(base) He was / if I shal yeuen hym his laude
(base) A theef / and eek a somnour / and a baude
(base) He hadde eek wenches / at his retenue
(base) That wheither that sir Robert / or sire hewe
(base) Or Iakke / or Rauf or who so that it were
(base) That lay by hem / they tolde it in his ere
(base) Thus was the wenche and he / of oon assent
(base) And he wolde fecche / a feyned mandement
(base) And somne hem to Chapitre / bothe two
(base) And pile the man / and lete the wenche go
(base) ¶ Thanne wolde he seye / freend I shal for thy sake
(base) Do stryke hire / out of oure lettres blake
(base) Thee thar namoore / as in this cas trauaille
(base) I am thy freend / ther I thee may auaille
(base) Certeyn / he knew of bryberyes mo
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Than possible is / to telle in yeres two
(base) For in this world / nys dogge for the bowe
