(base) Bet than this somnour / knew a sly lecchour
(base) Or an Auouter / or a paramour
(base) And for that was / the fruyt of al his rente
(base) Therfore on it / he sette al his entente
(base) ¶ And so bifel / that ones on a day
(base) This Somnour / euere waityng on his pray
(base) For to somne an old wydewe / a Ribibe
(base) Feynynge a cause / for he wolde brybe
(base) Happed / that he say / bifore hym ryde
(base) A gay yeman / vnder a Forest syde
(base) A bowe he bar / and arwes brighte and kene
(base) He hadde vpon / a courtepy of grene
(base) An hat vpon his heed / with frenges blake
(base) ¶ Sire quod this Somnour / hayl / and wel atake
(base) ¶ Wel come quod he / and euery good felawe
(base) Where ridestow / vnder this grene shawe
(base) Seyde this yeman / wiltow fer to day
(base) ¶ This Somnour hym answerde / and seyde nay
(base) Here faste by quod he / is myn entente
(base) To ryden / for to reysen vp a rente
(base) That longeth / to my lordes duetee
(base) ¶ Artow thanne a Bailly ; / ye quod he
(base) He dorste nat for verray filthe and shame
(base) Seye that he was a Somnour / for the name
(base) ¶ Depardieux quod this yeman / deere brother
(base) Thow art a bailly / and I am another
(base) I am vnknowen / as in this contree
(base) Of thyn aqueyntance / I wolde praye thee
(base) And eek of bretherhede / if that yow leste
(base) I haue gold / and siluer in my cheste
(base) ¶ If that thee happed / to come in oure shire
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Al shal be thyn / right as thow wolt desire
(base) ¶ Graunt mercy quod this Somnour / by my feith
(base) Euerich in ootheres hond / his trouthe leyth
(base) For to be sworn bretheren / til they deye
(base) In daliaunce / they ryden forth and pleye
(base) ¶ This Somnour / which that was / as ful of Iangles
(base) As ful of venym / been thise waryangles
(base) And euere enqueryng vpon euery thyng
(base) Brother quod he / where is now youre dwellyng
(base) Another day / if that I sholde yow seche
(base) This yeman hym answerde / in softe speche
(base) ¶ Brother quod he / fer in the North contree
(base) Where as I hope / som tyme I shal thee see
(base) Er we departe / I shal thee so wel wisse
(base) That of myn hous / ne shaltow neuere mysse
(base) ¶ Now brother quod this Somnour / I yow preye
(base) Teche me / whil that we ryden by the weye
(base) Syn that ye been a Baillyf / as am I
(base) Som subtiltee / and tel me feithfully
(base) In myn office / how I may moost wynne
(base) And spareth nat for conscience ne synne
(base) But as my brother / tel me how do ye
(base) ¶ Now by my trouthe / brother deere / seyde he
(base) As I shal tellen thee / a feithful tale
(base) My wages been / ful streyte / and ful smale
(base) My lord is hard to me / and daungerous
(base) And myn office / is ful laborous
(base) And therfore / by extorcions I lyue
(base) For sothe I take / al that men wol me yeue
(base) Algate / by sleighte / or by violence
(base) Fro yeer to yeer / I wynne al my dispence
(base) I kan no bettre tellen / feithfully
(base) ¶ Now certes quod this Somnour / so fare I
(base) I spare nat to taken / god it woot
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) But it be to heuy / or to hoot
(base) What I may gete / in conseil priuely
(base) No manere conscience / of that haue I
(base) Nere myn extorcioun / I myghte nat lyuen
(base) Ne of swiche Iapes / wol I nat be shryuen
(base) Stomak ne Conscience / ne knowe I noon
(base) I sherewe / thise Shryftesfadres euerychon
(base) Wel be we met by god / and by seint Iame
(base) But leeue brother / tel me thanne thy name
(base) Quod this Somnour / in this mene whyle
(base) This yeman / gan a litel for to smyle
(base) ¶ Brother quod he / woltow that I thee telle
(base) I am a feend / my dwellyng is in helle
(base) And here I ryde / aboute my purchasyng
(base) To wite / wher men wolde yeue me any thyng
(base) My purchas / is theffect of al my rente
(base) Looke how thow rydest for the same entente
(base) To wynne good / thow rekkest neuere how
(base) Right so fare I / for ryde wold I now
(base) Vnto the worldes ende / for a preye
(base) ¶ A quod this Somnour / benedicite what sey ye
(base) I wende / ye were a yeman trewely
(base) Ye han a mannes shap / as wel as I
(base) Han ye a figure thanne / determynat
(base) In helle ther ye been / in youre estat
(base) ¶ Nay certeynly quod he / ther haue we noon
(base) But whan vs liketh / we kan take vs oon
(base) Or ellis make yow seme / we ben shape
(base) Som tyme / lyk a man / or lyk an Ape
(base) Or lyk an Aungel / kan I ryde or go
(base) It is no wonder thyng theigh it be so
(base) A lousy Iogelour / kan deceyue thee
(base) And pardee yet kan I / moore craft than he
(base) ¶ Whi quod this Somnour / ryde ye thanne or goon
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) In sondry shap / and nat alwey in oon
(base) ¶ For we quod he / wol vs swiche formes make
(base) As moost able is / oure preyes for to take
(base) ¶ What maketh yow / to han al this labour
(base) ¶ Ful many a cause / leue sire Somnour
(base) Seyde this feend / but alle thyng hath tyme
(base) The day is short / and it is passed pryme
(base) And yet ne wan I no thyng in this day
(base) I wol entende / to wynnyng if I may
(base) And nat entende / oure wittes to declare
(base) For brother myn / thy wit is al to bare
(base) To vnderstonde / althogh I tolde hem thee
(base) But for thow axest why labouren we
(base) For som tyme / we been goddes Instrumentz
(base) And meenes / to doon his comandementz
(base) Whan that hym list / vpon his creatures
(base) In diuers art and in diuerse figures
(base) Withouten hym / we han no myght certayn
(base) If that hym lyst to stonde ther agayn
(base) And som tyme / at oure preyere / han we leue
(base) Oonly the body / and nat the soule greue
(base) Witnesse on Iob / whom that we diden wo
(base) And som tyme / han we myght of bothe two
(base) This is to seyn / of soule and body eke
(base) And som tyme / be we suffred for to seke
(base) Vpon a man / and do his soule vnreste
(base) And nat his body / and al is for the beste
(base) Whan he with standeth / oure temptacioun
(base) It is / a cause / of his sauacioun
(base) Al be it that it was / nat oure entente
(base) He sholde be sauf but that we wolde hym hente
(base) And somtyme / be we seruant vnto man
(base) As to the Erchebisshop / Seint Dunstan
(base) And to the Apostles / seruant eek was I
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) ¶ Yet tel me / quod the Somnour feithfully
(base) Make ye yow newe bodyes / thus alway
(base) Of Elementz / the feend answerde nay
(base) Som tyme we feyne / and som tyme we aryse
(base) With dede bodyes / in ful sondry wyse
(base) And speke as renably / and faire and wel
(base) As to the Phitonissa / dide Samuel
(base) And yet wol som men seye / it was nat he
(base) I do no fors / of youre dyuynytee
(base) But o thyng warne I thee / I wol nat Iape
(base) Thow wolt algates wite / how we be shape
(base) Thow shalt her afterwardes / my brother deere
(base) Come there / thee nedeth nat of me to lere
(base) For thow shalt by thyn owene experience
(base) Konne in a chayer / rede of this sentence
(base) Bet than Virgile / whil he was on lyue
(base) Or Dant also / now lat vs ryde blyue
(base) For I wol holde / compaignye with thee
(base) Til it be so / that thow forsake me
(base) ¶ Nay quod this Somnour / that shal nat bityde
(base) I am a yeman / knowen is ful wyde
(base) My trouthe wol I holde / as in this cas
(base) For theigh thow were / the deuel Sathanas
(base) My trouthe wol I holde / to thee my brother
(base) As I am sworn / and ech of vs til oother
(base) For to be trewe brother / in this cas
(base) And bothe we goon / abouten oure purchas
(base) Taak thow thy part what that men wol thee yeue
(base) And I shal myn / thus may we bothe lyue
(base) And if that any of vs / haue moore than oother
(base) Lat hym be trewe / and parte it with his brother
(base) ¶ I graunte quod the deuel / by my fey
(base) And with that word / they ryden forth hir wey
(base) And right at the entryng of the townes ende
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) To which this Somnour / shoop hym for to wende
(base) They saye a Cart that charged was with hey
(base) Which that a Cartere / droof forth in his wey
(base) Deep was the wey / for which the Carte stood
(base) This Cartere smoot and cryde as he were wood
(base) Hayt Brok hayt Scot what spare ye for the stones
(base) The feend quod he / yow fecche body and bones
(base) As ferforthly / as euere were ye foled
(base) So muchel wo / as I haue with yow tholed
(base) The deuel haue al / bothe hors and Cart and hey
(base) ¶ This Somnour seyde / heer shul we han a pley
(base) And neer the feend he drogh / as noght ne were
(base) Ful pryuely / and rowned in his ere
(base) Herkne my brother / herkne by thy feith
(base) Herestow nat how that the Cartere seith
(base) Hent it anon / for he hath yeue it thee
(base) Bothe hey / and Cart and eek his caples thre
(base) ¶ Nay quod the deuel / god woot neuer a del
(base) It is nat his entente / trust thow me wel
(base) Axe hym thy self if thow nat trowest me
(base) Or ellys stynt a while / and thow shalt se
(base) ¶ This Cartere / taketh his hors vpon the croupe
(base) And they bigonne / drawen and to stoupe
(base) Heyt now quod he / ther Ihu crist yow blesse
(base) And al his handes werk bothe moore and lesse
(base) That was wel twight myn owene lyard boy
(base) I pray god saue thee / and Seint loy
(base) Now is my Cart out of the slow pardee
(base) ¶ Lo brother quod the feend / what tolde I thee
(base) Heere may ye se / myn owene deere brother
(base) The Carl spak o thyng but he thoghte another
(base) Lat vs go forth / abouten oure viage
(base) Heere wynne I no thyng vpon cariage
(base) ¶ Whan that they coomen / som what out of towne
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) This Somnour / to his brother gan to rowne
(base) Brother quod he / here woneth an old rebekke
(base) That hadde almoost as leef to lese hir nekke
(base) As for to yeue a peny / of hir good
(base) I wol han twelue pens / thogh that she be wood
(base) Or I wol somne hire / vnto oure office
(base) And yet god woot of hire knowe I no vice
(base) But for thow canst nat as in this contree
(base) Wynne thy cost taak heer ensample of me
(base) This Somnour / clappeth at the wydwes gate
(base) Com out quod he / thow olde viritrate
(base) I trowe thow hast som frere / or preest with thee
(base) ¶ Who clappeth seyde this wyf / benedicitee
(base) God saue yow sire / what is youre swete wille
(base) ¶ I haue quod he / of somonce a bille
(base) Vp peyne of cursyng looke that thow be
(base) To morn / bifore the Erchedeknes knee
(base) Tanswere to the court of certeyn thynges
(base) ¶ Now lord quod she / crist Ihu kyng of kynges
(base) So wisly helpe me / as I ne may
(base) I haue been syk and that ful many a day
(base) I may nat go so fer quod she / ne ryde
(base) But I be deed / so priketh it in my syde
(base) May I nat axe a libel / sire Somnour
(base) And answere there / by my procutour
(base) To swich thyng as men wole opposen me
(base) ¶ Yis quod this Somnour / pay anon lat see
(base) Twelf pens to me / and I wol thee acquyte
(base) I shal no profit han ther by / but lyte
(base) ¶ My Maister hath the profit / and nat I
(base) Com of / and lat me ryden hastily
(base) Yif me .twelue. pens / I may no lenger tarye
(base) ¶ Twelf pens quod she / now lady Seinte Marie
(base) So wisly help me god / out of care and synne
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) This wyde world / thogh that I sholde wynne
(base) Ne haue I nat twelue pens / with Inne myn hoold
(base) Ye knowen wel / that I am poure and oold
(base) Kythe youre almesse / on me poure wrecche
(base) ¶ Nay thanne quod he / the foule feend me fecche
(base) If I thexcuse / theigh thow shul be spilt
(base) ¶ Allas quod she / god woot I haue no gilt
(base) ¶ Pay me quod he / or by the swete Seinte Anne
(base) As I wol bere awey / thy newe panne
(base) For dette / which thow owest me of oold
(base) Whan that thow madest / thyn housbonde cokewold
(base) I payde at hom / for thy correccioun
(base) ¶ Thow lyxt quod she / by my sauacioun
(base) Ne was I neuere er now / wydwe ne wyf
(base) Somoned vnto youre court in al my lyf /

(base) In which in to this day in noble wyse
(base) Men doon to crist and to his Seinte seruyse
(base) Here is ended the Nonnes tale
¶ And here beginneth the Prolog of the Pardoner

ordinges qd he in chirche whan

div.l: I peyne me to han an haute speche
I ring it out as goth a belle
For I can all be rote all that I telle Pardoner .
My teme is alwey oon and euer was
Radix malorum est cupiditas
First I pronounce whens that I come
And than my bulles I shewe all and some
Oure liege lordes seal on my patent
That shewe I first my body to warent
That noman be so bolde prest ne clerk
Me to distourben of cristes holy werk
And aftir that telle I forth my tales
Bulles of es and of Cardinales
Of Patriarkes and busshoppis I shewe
And in latyn I speke wordes fewe
To saueren with my predicacioıı̄un
And for to styre men to deuocioıı̄un
Than shewe I forth my long cristall stones
I crammed full of cloutes and bones
Relikes thei bene as wenen they echeon
Than haue I in latoıı̄un a shulder bone
Which that was an holy Iewes shep
Gode men sey I take of my wordes kepe
Yef that this bone be wasshe in any welle
Yef kowe or calf shepe or oxe selle
That any worme hath eten or ony worme stonge
And thus bere I the peple on honde
That it is hole anon and furthermore
Of pokkes and scabbes and of euery sore
Shall euery shep be hole that of this welle
Drinketh a drauȝt take hede what I telle
Yf that the gode man that the bestis oweth
Woll euery woke or the cok croweth
Fasting drinke of this welle a drauȝt
As thilke holy Iewe oure eldres tauȝt
His bestes and his store shall multiplie
And sir also it helith ielousye Pardoner .
And thouȝ a man be falle in ielouse rage
Let maken with this water his potage
And neuer shall he more his wif mys trist
They he the sothe of here wiste
All had she taken prestis ij or iij
Here is a meteyn eke that ye may se
He that his hond will put in this meteyn
He shulde haue multiplieng of his greyn
Whan he hath sowen be it whete or otes
So that he parte woll of pense and grotes
And men and wommen o thing warne I you
Yef any wiȝt be in this chirche now
That hath don synne so horrible that he
Dar nat for shame of it shryuen be
Or any womman be she yong or olde
That hath I made here husbond Cokewold
Such folk shull haue no power ne grace
To offren to my relike in this place
And who so fyndeth him withouten blame
They will come vp and offre in goddis name
And I assoile him by the Auctorite
Which that by bulle was graunted me
By this gaude haue I wonne euery yere
A . C . mark syn I was pardonere
I stode like a Clerk in my pulpet
And shewe leude peple and doun I sitte
I preche so as ye haue herd before
And telle an . C . iapes more
Than peyne I me to strecche forth the nekke
And Est and west vpon the people I bekke
As doth a doue sitting vpon a berne
Myn hondes and my tonge gon so yerne
That is ioye to se my besinesse
Of Auarice and of such cursidnesse Pardoner .
Is all my preching for to make hem fre
To yeue her penyes and namely vnto me
For myn entent nys but for to wynne
And no thing for correccioıı̄un of synne
I recche neuer whan that thei be buried
Thouȝ that her soules go a blakberied
For certes many a predicacioıı̄un
Cometh often tyme of euill entencioıı̄un
Som for plesaunce of folk and for flaterye
To ben auaunced by ypocrisie
And som for veinglory and for hate
For when I dar not othir wise debate
Than will I stynge him with my tonge smert
In preching so that he shall not astert
To be defamed falsly yef that he
Hath trespaced vnto my brotheren and to me
For thouȝ I telle nat his propir name
Men shall well knowe that it is the same
By simonye and be othir circumstaunces
Thus quyte I folk that don us displesaunces
Thus spite I my venym vnder hewe
Of holinesse to seme holy and trewe
But shortly myn entent I wil deuise
I preche of no thing but of couetise
Therfor my teme is and euer was
Radix malorum est cupiditas
Then can I preche ageins the same vice
Which that I vse and that is auarice
But thouȝ my silf be gilty in that synne
Yet can I make othir folk to twynne
From Auarice make hem sore repente
But that is nat my principall entent
I preche no thing but for couetise
Of this mater it ouȝt I now suffice Pardoner .
Then telle I hem ensamples many oon
Of olde stories longe tyme agon
For leude people louen tales olde
Which thinges can they reporte and holde
What trowe ye whiles I may preche
And wynne golde and siluer whiles I teche
That I will lyue in pouerte welfully
Nay nay I coude it neuer truly
For I will preche and begge in sondry londes
I will not do no labour with my thonkes
Ne make baskettis and lyue pouerly
Be cause I will not begge ydely
I will non of the Apostles counterfete
I will haue mony wolle chese and whete
All were it yeuen of the porest page
Othir of the porest widewe in A village
Thouȝ her children shuld sterue for famyne
Nay I will drynke no licour but the wyn
And haue I a ioly wenche in euery a toun
But herkeneth lordinges my conclusioıı̄un
Your likyng is that I shall telle A tale
Now haue I dronke a drauȝt of corny Ale
By god I hope I shall telle you a thing
That shall be reson be at your likyng
For thouȝ my self be A foull vicious man
A morall tale yet I you telle can
Which I am wont to preche for to wynne
Now holde your pees my tale I will begynne .

Here endith the Prolog of the Pardoner
And here begynneth his tale folwing

n flaundris whilom was a company

div.l: Of yong folk that haunted foly Pardoner .
As ryot hasard stives Tauernes
Where as with harpes lutes and giternes
They daunce and pley at dys bothe day and niȝt
And ete also and drynke ouer her miȝt
Throuȝ which they do the deuel sacrifice
Withynne the deueles temple in cursid wise
By superfluence abhominable
Here othes ben so gret and dampnable
That it is grisly for to here hem swere
Oure blessid lordes body they to tere
Hem thouȝt Iewes rent him nat I nouȝ
And eche of hem at othir synnes lough
And riȝt anon cam tumblesters
Fetyse and smale yong fruterers
Syngers with harpes baudes waferers
Such bene verrily the deuelis officers
To coole and blowe the fyre of lecchery
That is annexed to gloteny
The holy writ take I to my witnesse
That lecchery is in wyn and dronkenesse
Lo hou that dronken loth vnkendely
Lay by his douȝteres ij vnwetingly
So dronke he was he nys what he wrouȝt
Heroudes who so hath the story souȝt
Whan he of wyn was replet at his feste
Riȝt at his owne table gaf his heste
To sle the baptist Iohn ful gilteles
Senek seith a gode word douteles
He saith he can no difference fynde
Bytwix a man that is ouȝt of his mynde
And a man that is dronkelew
But that wodenesse is fallen in A shrewe
Perseuerid lenger than doth dronkenesse
O gloteny full of cursidnesse Pardoner .
O cause first of oure confusioıı̄un
O original of oure dampnacioıı̄un
This crist had brouȝt out his wordes ayen
Loo hou dere and shortely for to seyn
Aboute was the cursid vilanye
Corrupte was this world with gloteny
Adam oure fader and his wif also
From paradys to labour and to woo
Were dryuen for that vice it is no drede
For whiles that Adam first as I rede
He was in paradys and whan that he
Ete of the frute defended of the tree
Anon he was oute cast to woo and peyne
O gloteny on the well ouȝt us pleyne
Hou wist a man hou many maladies
Folweth of excesse and of glotenyes
He wolde be the more mesurable
Of his diete sittyng at the table
Alas the short throte the tendre mouth
Maketh that Est west north and south
In erthe in eyre makith man to swynke
To gete a gloton deynte mete and drynke
Of this mater O poule wel canst thou trete
Mete vnto the wombe and wombe eke vnto the mete
Shall god distroie bothe as poule saith
Alas O foulyng it is be my feith
To sey this worde and fouler is the dede
Whan men so drynketh of the white and of the rede
That of his throte he makith his priuete
Throuȝ which cursed superfluite
The Apostill weping seith pitously
Ther walken many of such as you told I
I sey it now weping with pitous voice
That ben enmyes of cristes crosse Pardoner .
Of which ende is her deth wombe is her god
O wombe . O bely . O stynkyng cod
Fulfilled of donge and of corrupcioıı̄un
At eithir ende of the soule is the soun
How gret coste and labour is it to fynde
This Cokes hou they stampe streyne and grynde
And turnen substaunce in to accident
To fulfille all thi licorous talent
Oute of the harde bones knokke they
The mary for they cast not awey
That may go throuȝ the golet softe and soote
Of spicery of leues barbe and rote
Shall ben his sause I mad by delite
To make him yet a newer appetite
But certes he that haunteth such delices
Is deed whiles he leueth in tho vices
A leccherous thing is wyn and dronkenesse
It is full of stryuyng and full of wrecchidnesse
O dronken man disfigured is thi face
Foule is thi breth foule art thou to enbrace
And throuȝ thi dronken nose cometh thi soun
As they thou seidest ay sampsoıı̄un sampsoıı̄un
And yet god wot sampsoıı̄un dranke neuer wyn
Thou fallest as were A stiked swyn
Thi tonge is lost all at thin honest cure
For dronkenesse is verry sepulture
Of mannys wit and his discressioıı̄un
In whom that drynke hath dominacioıı̄un
He can no counseil kepe it is no drede
Now kepe you from the white and from the rede
Namely from the white wyn of lepe
That is to selle in fisshe strete and in chepe
This wyne of spayne crepith subtilly
In othir wynes growyng fast by Pardoner .
Of which ther riseth fumosite
That whan a man hath dronken drauȝtes iij
And weneth that he be at hom in chepe
He is in spayne riȝt at the toun of lepe
Ne at rochel ne at burdeux toun
And they woll than sey sampsoıı̄un sampsoıı̄un
But herkeneth lordinges I you prey
That alle the souerain acces I dar wel say
Of victory in the olde testament
That throuȝ the verry god omnipotent
Were don in abstinence and in praier
Lokith the bible and ye may it here
Loketh Attela the gret conqueroᵘur
Died in his slepe with shame and dishonoᵘur
Bleding ay at his nose in dronkenesse
A Capitayn shuld lyue in sobirnesse
And ouer all this auise you riȝt well
What was cōmmaunded vnto lamuel
Nat samuel but lamuel say I
Redith the bible and fyndeth expressely
Of wyn reuyng to hem that haue iustice
No more of this for it may wel suffice ;
And now that I haue spoke of glotenye
Now wol I defende you of hasardye
Hasard is verry moder of lesinges
And of deceyte cursed forswerynges
Blaspheme of crist manslauȝter and wast also
Of bataile and of tene and also furthermo
It is reproue and contrary to honoᵘur
For to ben holden a comoıı̄un hasardour
And euer the hiȝer he is of estat
The more he is holden dessolat
If that A prynce vse hasardie
In all gouernaunce and polecye Pardoner .
He is as by comoun opinioıı̄un
I holde the lasse in reputacioıı̄un
Stilbon that was holde A wise imbassiatoᵘur
Was sent in to Corinthe with full gret honoᵘur
From Calidonie to make him alliaunce
And whan he cam happed his chaunce
That all the grettest that were of that lond
Pleying at the hazard he hem fond
For which as sone as it miȝt be
He stale him hom agein in to his cuntre
And seide ther nil I nat lese my name
I wol not take of me so gret A fame
You for to allye to non hazardours
Sendith othir wise embassiatours
For by my trouth me were leuer deye
Than I to you shuld hazardours allie
For ye that ben so glorious in honours
Shuld nat allie you with hasardours
As by my will ne as be my trete
This wise philosophre thus said he
Loo eke that to the kyng Demetrows
The king of Perches as the boke said thus
Sent him a peire of dys of gold in scorn
For he had vsed hasardie beforn
For which he set his glorye and renoun
At no valu ne reputacioıı̄un
Lordes miȝt fynde othir pley
Honest I now to dryue the cart awey
Now wol I speke of othes false and grete
A word or ij as othir bokes entrete
Gret sweryng is a thing abhominable
And false swering is more reprouable
The hiȝe god for bad swering at all
Witnesse on Matheu but in speciall Pardoner .
Of swering seith the holy Ieromie
Thou shalt swere soth thine oth and not lye
And swere in dome and eke in riȝtwisnesse
But idell swering is A cursidnesse
Be holde and se that in the first table
Of high goddes hestes abhominable
Hou that the seconde heest of him is this
Take nat my name in ydilnesse amys
Loo rather he forbedith such swering
Or homicide or othir cursed thing
I sey that as by ordre thus it stondeth
This knoweth they that his hestes vnderstandeth
Hou that the seconde of god is that
And furthermore I wil the telle all plat
That vengeaunce shal not parte from his hous
That of his othes is so outerageous
By god his precious hert and his nayles
And by his blood that is in hayles
Viij is my chaunce and thine is v . and iij
By goddis armes if thou false be
This dagger throuȝ thine herte shall go
This frute cometh of the bicchid bones two
Forsweryng . Ire . falsnesse . homicide
Now for the loue of crist that for us died
Leueth your othes gret and smale
Now sirs now wol I telle forth my tale
This ryotours iij of which I you telle
Long erst or prime rang any belle
Were set hem in A tauerne to drynke
And as they sat thei herd a belle clynke
Byfore A corps that was caried to his graue
That oon of hem gan calle to his knaue
Go bet qd he and axe redily
What corps is this that passith forby Pardoner .
And loke that thou reporte his name well
Sir qd this boy it nedith neuer a dell
It was me tolde or ye cam here ij owres
He was parde an olde felaw of youres
All sodeinly was he slayn this niȝt
For dronke as he sat vpon his benche vp riȝt
Ther cam A preuy theef men clepen deth
That in this contre all the peple sleth
And with his spere he smot his herte atwo
And went his wey withouten wordes moo
He hath a Ml slayn in his pestilence
And mastir or ye cam in his presence
Me thinketh that it were necessarye
For to bewar of such an aduersarie
Beth redy for to mete him euermore
Thus tauȝt me my dame I sey namore
Be seint Mary seide this tauerner
The childe saith soth for he hath slayn this yere
Hennes ouer A myle in A gret village
Bothe man and wommām childe and page
I trowe his habitacioıı̄un be there
To be auysed gret wisdom it were
Er that he did a man a dishonour
Ye goddis mercy qd this riotour
Is it such perill with him for to mete
I shal him seke be wey and be strete
I make A wugh by goddis digne bones
Herkene felawes we iij ben all ones
Lete eche of us hold vp hond to othir
And eche of us be come othirs brothir
And we will sle this false traytoᵘur deth
He shall be dede he that somany sleth
By goddis dignite or that it be niȝt
To gidre han these iij her trouthe I pliȝt Pardoner .
To lyue and dye eche of hem for othir
As thouȝ he were his owne sworne brothir
And they vp stert and drank in this rage
And forth thei gone toward that village
Of which the tauerner hath spoken beforn
And many A grisly othe than haue they sworn
And cristes blessid body they to rent
Deth shall be deed if that we may hent
Whan thei han gon nat fully half a myle
Riȝt as they wolde haue troden ouer A stile
An olde pore man with hem he mette
This olde man full mekely hem grette
And seide thus now lordes god you se
The proudest of these riotours iij
Answerid agein what carle with harde grace
Why art thou all for wrappid saf thi face
Why leuest thou so longe in gret age
This olde man gan loke in his visage
And seide thus for I can not fynde
A man thouȝ I walked in to ynde
Neithir in citee neithir in non village
That will chaunge his youthe for myn age
And therfor mot I haue myn age stille
As long tyme as it is goddis wille
Ne deth alas ne will not haue my lif
Thus walke I like A recheles caitif
And on the ground which is my modres gate
I knokke with my staf erly and late
And sey leue moder lete me ynne
Lo I wanse flessh blode and skyn
Allas whan shall my bones ben at rest
Moder with you wold I chaunge my chest
And in my chambre long tyme haue be
Ye for an here cloute to wrappe me Pardoner .
But yet to me she will not do that grace
For which all pale and welkid is my face
But sirs to you it is no curtesy
To speke to an olde man vilanye
But he trespase in word orellis in dede
In holy writ ye may your self wel rede
Ayens an olde man hore vpon his hede
Ye shul arise wherfor I yeue you reed
Ne doth vnto an olde man harme now
No more than men dede vnto you
In age if that ye so longe abide
And god be with you where ye go or ride
I mote go thider as I haue to do
Nay olde cherll be god thou shalt not so
Seide this othir hazardour anon
Thou partest not so liȝtly be seint Iohn
Thou spak riȝt now of that ilke traytoᵘur deth
That in this contre all oure frendes sleth
Haue here my trouth as thou art his aspie
Telle where he is or thou shalt abye
Be god and be the holi sacrament
For sothely thou art oon of his assent
To sle us yonge folk false theef
Now sirs if it be you so leef
To fynde deth turne up this croked wey
For in that groue I lafte him be my fey
Vnder a tree and there he will a bide
Ne for your boost he nil him no thing hide
Se ye that Oke there shall ye him fynde
God saue you that bouȝt ayen mankynde
And you amende thus seide this olde man
And euerich of these riotours ran
Til thei come to the tree and there thei fonde
Of florence fyne of gold I croimed rounde Pardoner
Well ny a vij busshellis as hem thouȝt
No lenger than aftir deth thei souȝt
But eche of hem so glad was of that siȝt
For that the florences so faire were and so briȝt
That doun thei sette hem by the precious hoord
The werst of hem so spak the first word
Brotheren qd he take kepe what I sey
My wit is gret thouȝ that I borde and pley
This tresour hath fortune to us yeuen
In mirthe and iolite oure lif to lyuen
And liȝtly as it cometh so woll we spende
Ey goddis precious dignite who wende
This day that we shuld haue so faire a grace
But miȝt this golde be caryed from this place
Home to myn house orellis vnto youres
For well I wot that all this golde is oures
Than were we in high felicite
But truly be day it may not be
Men wolde sey that we were theues strong
And for oure tresour don us hiȝe honge
This tresour must be caried be niȝt
As wisly and as slyly as we miȝt
Therfor lete loke among us alle
To drawe and let se where the cut wil falle
He that hath the cut with herte blithe
Shall renne to towne also swithe
To bringe us bred and wyn priuely
And two of us shall kepe full subtily
This tresour wel and yef he wil nat tarye
Whan it is niȝt we wol this tresour carye
Be oon assent where as us best best
The oon of hem brouȝt the cut in his fest
And bad hem drawe and loke on whom it will falle
And it fell on the yongest of hem alle Pardoner
And forth // toward he fill anon // toun
And also sone as he was gon
That oon of hem spak thus vnto the othir
Thou wost wel thou art my owne sworn brothir
And here is gold and that full gret plente
That it shall departed be among us iij
But natheles if I can shape it so
That it departed were among us two
Were thou nat mochel holden vnto me
Yes qd he that I not hou shulde be
Shall it be counsaill said the first shrewe
And I shall telle the in wordes fewe
What we shall don and bringe it wel aboute
I graunte qd that othir oute of doute
That by my trouth I will not the bewreye
Now qd I furst thou wotest wel be tweye
And ij of us shall be strenger than oon
Loke whan he is set and that anon
Arise as they thou woldest with him pleye
And I shall rid renne him throuȝ his sides tweye
Whiles that thou strogelest with him as in game
And with thi dagger loke thou do the same
And then shall all this gold departed be
My dere frende betwix me and the
Then may we bothe oure lustes fulfille
And pleye at dys riȝt at oure owne wille
And thus accorded ben these shrewes twey
To sle the thirde as ye herd me sey
¶ This yongest which that went to the toun
Full ofte in herte he rolled pop and doun
The beaute of these florences newe and briȝt
O lord qd he if that I so miȝt
Haue all this tresour to my self allone
There is noman that lyueth vnder the trone Pardoner .
Of god that shuld lyue as merily as I
And at the last the fend oure enmy
Put in his thouȝt that he shuld poysoıı̄un bye
With which he miȝt slee his felawes tweye
For why the fend him fond of such lyuyng
That he had leuer him to sorwe bringe
For this was outerly his false entent
To slee hem bothe and neuer to repent
And forth he goth no lenger wold he tarye
In to the toun vnto A potecarye
And preid that he wolde him selle
Som poison that he miȝt his ratons kelle
And eke ther was a polket in his hawe
That as he said his capons had I slawe
And seide he wolde a wreke him if he miȝt
Of vermyn that distroied him be niȝt
The appotecary answerid and thou shalt haue
A thing that al so god my soule saue
In all the world ther nys no creature
That eteth or drinketh this confecture
Nat but the mountenᵃnce of a corn of whete
That he ne shal his lif anon for lete
Ye sterue he shall and that in lasse while
Than thou wilt go A pace not but a myle
This cursed man hath in his hond I hent
Of the apotecarye as I say you verement
This poison in A box and sithen he ran
In to the nexte strete vnto a man
And borwed him large botellis iij
And in this wyn this poison put he
The iij he kepith clene for his drynke
For all the niȝt he shope him to swynke
In carying of the gold oute of that place
And whan this riotour with sory grace Pardoner .
Had full with him hise grete botelis iij
To his felawes agein repaired he
What nedith it to sermone therof more
For riȝt as thei had cast his deth before
Riȝt so thei haue him slayn and that anon
And whan that this was don than spak that oon
Now lete us sitte and drynke and make us mery
And aftirward we will his body berye
And sone aftir it happed hem ꝑper/par case
To take the botell there poison was
And drank and gaf his felaw drink also
For which anon they steruen bothe ij
But certes I suppose that neuer Auycene
Wrote neuer in no canoıı̄un in no fene
Mo wondir stories of imposynynges
Thus had these wrecchis ij her endinges
Thus ended ben these homicides ij
And eke of the false poisoner also
O cursid synne full of all cursidnesse
O traytouresse homicide O wickidnesse
O gloteny . O luxurie . O hasardye
Thou blasphemoᵘur of crist with vilany
And othes grete of vsage and of pride
Allas mankynde hou may it be tide
Therto thi creatour which that the wrouȝt
Sith all this that ye on the rode bouȝt
Thou art so fals and so vnkende alas

Your name I entre in to my rolle anon

If any of you will of deuocioıı̄un

Cometh forth anon and knelith here adoun

That ye may haue A sufficient pardonere
To assoile you in contre as ye ryde
For aduentures which that may be tide
For ꝑper/paraduenture there may falle oon or ij

Loke such A suerte is to you alle
That I am in your felaship I falle
That may assoile you bothe more and lesse
Whan that the soule from the body shal passe
I rede that oure oost shall begynne
For he is most envolute in synne
Come forth sir oost and offre vp anon
And thou shalt kisse the relikes euery cheon
Ye for A grote vnbokele anon thi purse Pardoner .
Nay nay qd he than haue I cristes curse
Let ben qd he it shall not be so theye
Thou woldest make kisse thine olde breke
And swere it were A relik of a seint
Thouȝ it were with thi fundament depeynt
But by that crosse which that seint Eleyne fonde
I wold I had thi colyons in myn hond
In stede of relikes or of seyntuarye
Let cut hem of I will the help hem carye
They shulde be shryned in an hogges torde
This pardoner answerid nat oo wurd
So wroth he was he wolde no wurd seye
Now qd oure oost I will no lenger pleye
With the ne with non othir angry man
But riȝt anon the worthi kniȝt began
Whan that he sauȝ that all the peple louȝ
Nomore of this it is riȝt I now
Sir pardoner be glad and mery of chiere
And ye sir oost that be to me so dere
I pray you that ye kisse the pardoner
And pardoner I pray the draw nere
And as we did let us lauȝe and pley
Anon they kissed and riden forth her wey .
¶ Here endith the Pardoners tale

div.ab: (base) Here bigynneth Chaucers tale of Melibeus

(base) A yong man whilom called Melibeus myghty and
riche bigat vp on his wif that called was Prudence a
doghter which that called was Sophie

(base) vp on a day bifel that
he for his desport is went in to the feeldes hym to pleye

(base) his
wif and eek his doghter hath he laft inwith his hous of

which
the dores weren faste yshette
(base) thre of his olde foos han it espied and setten laddres to the walles of his hous and by wyndowes ben entred

(base) and betten his wif and wounded his doghter with
fyue mortal woundes in fyue sondry places

(base) this is to seyn
in hir feet in hir handes in hir erys in hir nose and in hir
mouth and leften hire for deed and wenten awey

(base) Whan Melibeus retourned was in to his hous and seigh al this meschief he
lyk a mad man rentynge his clothes gan to wepe and crye

(base) Prudence his wyf as ferforth as she dorste bisoughte hym of
his wepyng for to stynte

(base) but nat for thy he gan to crye and
wepen euere lenger the moore

(base) This noble wif Prudence
remembred hire vp on the sentence of Ouyde in his book that
cleped is the remedie of loue wher as he seith

(base) he is a fool
that destourbeth the moder to wepe in the deth of hir child
til she haue wept hir fille as for a certeyn tyme

(base) and thanne
shal man doon his diligence with amyable wordes hire to reconforte and preye hire of hir wepyng for to stynte

(base) for which
reson this noble wyf Prudence suffred hir housbonde for to
wepe and crye as for a certeyn space

(base) and whan she say hir
tyme she seyde hym in this wise Allas my lord quod she
why make ye your self for to be lyk a fool
(base) for sothe it aperteneth nat to a wys man to maken swich a sorwe

(base) yowre
doghter with the grace of god shal warisshe and escape

(base) And al were it so that she right now were deed ye ne oghte nat as
for hir deth youre self to destroye

(base) Senec seith the wise man
shal nat take to greet disconfort for the deth of his children

(base) but
certes he sholde suffren it in pacience as wel as he abideth the
deth of his owene propre perrsone

(base) This Melibeus answerde anon
and seyde What man quod he sholde of his wepyng stynte
that hath so gret a cause for to wepe

(base) Ihus crist oure lord hym
self wepte for the deth of lazarus his freend

(base) Prudence
answerde Certes wel I woot attempree wepynge is no thyng
defended to hym that sorweful is amonges folk in sorwe but
it is rather graunted hym to wepe

(base) The Apostle Poul vn to
the Romayns writeth Man shal reioysse with hem that maken ioye
and wepen with swich folk as wepen

(base) but thogh attempree

wepyng be graunted outrageous wepyng certes is defended

(base) Mesure
of wepyng sholde be considered after the loore that techeth vs
Senec

(base) Whan that thy freend is deed quod he lat nat thyne eyen
to moyste ben of terys ne to muche drye al thogh the teerys
come to thyne eyen lat hem nat falle

(base) And whan thou hast
forgoon thy freend do diligence to geten another freend and
this is moore wysdom than for to wepe for thy freend which
that thou hast lorn for ther Inne is no boote

(base) And therfore if ye
gouerne yow by Sapience put awey sorwe out of youre herte

(base) Remembre yow that Ihus Syrak seith A man that is ioyous and
glad in herte it hym conserueth florisshynge in his age but
soothly sorweful herte maketh his bones drye

(base) he seith eek
thus that sorwe in herte sleeth ful many a man

(base) Salomon
seith that right as Moththes in the Shepes flees anoyeth
to the clothes and the smale wormes to the tree right so anoyeth sorwe to the herte

(base) wher fore vs oghte as wel in the deth

(base) Remembre yow vp on the pacient Iob whan he
hadde lost his children and his temporel substance and in his body

(base) Oure lord quod he hath yeue it me

hath wold right so it is doon yblessed be the name of oure

(base) To thise forseyde thynges answerde Melibeus vn to

ther to profitable but trewely myn herte is troubled with this

vp on this matere

fore vn to oure Art it is nat pertinent to norice werre ne parties

(base) by cause of the wrong and of the wikkednesse that

(base) And ek
by reson of the grete richesse and power of the parties bothe

(base) for
the whiche resons it were a ful greet peril to erren in this matere

(base) Wher fore Melibeus this is oure sentence we conseile

this he that soone demeth soone shal repente

(base) and that shewed oure lord Ihus crist by ensample for whan that the womman that was taken in auoutrye
was broght in his presence to knowen what sholde be doon
with hir persone al be it that he wiste wel hym self what

(base) vp roos tho oon of thise olde

hi.hi: Here beginneth the Nonnes Prestes tale of Chauntecler ⁊and Pertelote .

div.l: Was whilom dwelling in a narwe cotage
Beside a groue dwelling in a dale
This widewe of whom I telle my tale
Synnes thilk day she was a wif
In pacience ledde a full simple lif
For litell was her catell and her rent
By husbondry of such as god her sent
She fonde her self and eke her douȝteres two
Thre large sowes had she and nomo
Three keen and eke a sheep that hiȝt malle
Ful soty was her boure and eke her halle
In which she ete many a slender mele
Of poinant sauce her nedith neuer a dele
No deynte morsell passid her throte
Her dyet was according to her cote
Replecioıı̄un made her neuer seke
Attemꝑper/par diet was all her phisik
And excercise was and hertes suffisaunce
And the goute let her neuer for to daunce
Ne poplexie shent not her hede
Ne wyne drank she non white nor rede
Her borde was most serued with white and blak
Melk and broun bred in which she fand no lak
Seynde bacoıı̄un and somtyme an ey or twey
For she was as it were a maner deye
A gardyn she had closed all a boute
With stikkes and a drye diche all a boute
In which she had a Cok that hiȝt Chaunteclere
In all the lond of crowing nas his pere
His voice was merier than the mery orgon
On masse daies that in the chirche goon
Wel sikerer was his crowing in his logge Chauntecler ~
Than is A clokke in abbey or in orelogge
By nature he croweth eche assencioıı̄un
Of equenocciall in thilke toun
For when degrees xv. were ascended
Than crew he that it miȝt not be amended
His combe was redder than the fyne corall
And batailed as it were a castell wall
His bill was blak and as the Ieet it shone
I like azure were his leggis and his toon
His nayles whitter were than the lily flour
And like bornesshid gold was his colour
This gentill cokke had in his gouernᵃnce
Seuene hennes to don him plesaunce
Which were sustres and his paramours
And wondir like to him as of coloures
Of which the fairest hewed in her cote
Was clepid faire damisell Pertelote
Curteis she was discret and debonair
And compenable and bar her self so faire
Sethines thilk day she was seueniȝt olde
That truly she hath in herte in holde
Of Chaunteclere loken in eueri sith
He loued her so that wel was him ther with
But such a ioye it was to here him singe
Whan that the briȝt sonne began to springe
In swete accord my lef is faren a londe
For thilke tyme as I haue vnderstonde
Bestes and briddes coude speke and synge
And so befell that in the dawening
As Chaunteclere amonges his wyues alle
Sat on the perche that was in the halle
And next him sat this faire Pertelote
This Chaunteclere gan grone in his throte
As a man that in his dreem drecchid sore Pertelote ~
And whan this Pertelote thus herd him rore
She was agast and seide herte dere
What eileth you to grone in that manere
Ye be a verry sleper fy for shame
And he answerid and seide thus madame
I pray you that ye take it nouȝt agreef
By god me thouȝt I was in such mischief
Riȝt now that yet myn herte is sore a fliȝt
Now god qd he my sweuene recche ariȝt
And kepe my body out of foule prisoıı̄un
Me mette that I romed vp and doun
Withinne oure yerd where as I sauȝ a beest
Was like an hounde and wolde haue made arest
Vpon my body and wolde haue had me deed
His colour was bitwen white and reed
And tipped was his tayle and vp stood his eres
With blak on like the remenᵃnt of his heres
His snoute smal with glowing eyen twey
Yet for his loke almost I dey
This caused me my groning douteles
A voy qd she fy on you herteles
Allas qd she for by that god aboue
Now haue ye lost myn hert and my loue
I can not loue a coward be my feith
For certes what so eny womman seith
We alle desiren if it may be
To haue husbondes wise hardy and free
And secree ne no nigard ne fole
Ne him that is agast of eueri tooll
Ne non auauntour by that god aboue
Hou dorst ye say for shame to your loue
That any thing miȝt make you aferd
Haue ye no manes hert and a berde
Allas and can ye ben agast of sweuenes Chauntecler ~
No thing god wot but vanite in sweuene is
And ofte of fume and of complexions
Sweuenes engendren of replexions
Whan humors ben to habundant in a wiȝt
Certes this dreem which ye haue met to niȝt
Cometh of gret superfluite
Of your gret colerik parde
Which causeth folk to dreden in her dremes
Of arwes and of fire with rede lemes
Of red bestes that thei wolde hem bite
Of contek and of whelpes gret and lite
Riȝt as the humoᵘur of malencoly
Causeth many man in his sleep crye
For fere of beres or of boles blake
Orellis blake deuelis woll him take
Of othir humors coude I telle also
That worken many a man in his slepe full woo
But I will passe as liȝtly as I can
Loo Catoıı̄un which is so wise a man
Seide he nat thus ne do ye no force of dremes
Now sir qd she whan we flie fro this bemes
For goddis loue as takith som laxatyue
Vpon perill of my soule and of myne lyue
I counseill you the best I will nat lie
Ye beth of colerik and of malencolie
Ye purge you for ye ne shall nat tarie
Thouȝ in this toun is non appotecary
I shall my self to herbes telle you
That shall be for your hele and your prow
And in the gardyn the herbes shall ye fynde
The which haue of here propirtees the kynde
To purge you beneth and eke aboue
Foryete nouȝt this for goddes owne loue
Ye bene full colerik of complexioıı̄un Pertelot ~
Whan the sonne is in his assencioıı̄un
Ne fynde you replete of humoᵘurs hote
And yef he do I dar wel ley a grote
That ye shall haue a feuer tercian
Or an hagu that may be your ban
A day or ij ye shall haue digestyues
Of wormes or ye take your laxatyues
Of laurel centaure and fumytere
Orellis of elbere that groweth there
Of quaterpuce or of gaytres beryes
Of herbe Iue growing in your gardyn there mery is
Pekke hem riȝt vp as thei growe and ete hem yn
Be mery husbond for your fader kyn
Dredith no dreme I can sey you nomore
Madame qd he graunt mercy for your lore
But natheles as touching Dam Catoıı̄un
That hath of wisdom such a gret renoıı̄un
By god men may in olde bokes rede
Thouȝ that he bad no dremes for to drede
Of many man more of Auctoritee
Than euer Catoıı̄un was so mote I the
That alle the reuerse seyn of his sentence
And han wel founden by experience
That dremes ben significacions
As well of ioye as of tribulacions
That folk enduren in this lif present
Ther nedith to make of this argument
The verry preef shewith it in dede
One of the grettest Auctoᵘur that men rede
Saith thus that ij felawes went
On pilgrimage in a full gode entent
And happid so they cam in to a toun
Where as there was such a congregacioıı̄un
Of people / and eke of streyte herbigage Chauntecler ~
That they founde not as moch as a cotage
In which thei miȝt bothe I loggid be
Wherfor thei most of necessite
As for that niȝt departen companye
And eche of hem goth to his hostelrie
And toke his logge as it wolde falle
That oon of hem was logged in a stalle
Fer in the yerd with oxen of the plouȝ
That other man was logged wel Inouȝ
As was his aduenture or his fortune
That vs all gouerneth as in comune
And so it be fell long or it was day
This man mette in his bedde there he lay
How that his felaw gan vpon him calle
And he seide allas for in an oxes stalle
This niȝt I shall be murdered as I lie
Now helpe me dere brothir or I dye
In alle hast come to me he saide
This man oute of his sleep for fere he braide
But whan that he was wakid out of his sleep
He torned him and toke of this no kepe
Him thouȝt his dreem nas but a vanite
Thus twies in his sleping dremed he
And at the thridde tyme yet his felawe
Cam as him thouȝt I am nowe slawe
Byholde my body wounded dep and wide
Arise vp erly in the morn tyde
And at the west gate of the toun qd he
A cart full of donge ther shalt thou see
In which my body is hid full preuily
Do thilke cart arest boldely
My gold caused my deth soth to sayn
And tolde eueri point how he was slayn
With a full pitous face pale of hewe Pertelot ~
And trust wel this dreem he fond full trewe
For on the morn as sone as it was day
To his felawes Inne he toke the way
And whan that he come to this oxe stalle
Aftir his felaw he began to calle
The hosteler answerid him anoon
And saide sir your felawe is goon
As sone as day he went out of toun
This man gan anon falle in suspeccioıı̄un
Remembring of his dreem that he mette
And forth he goth no lenger wolde he lette
Vnto the west gate of the toun he fonde
A donge cart went as it were to donge londe
That was arraied in the same wise
As ye herd the dede man deuise
And with an hardy hert he gan to crye
Vengeaunce and iustice of this felonye
My felaw murdred is this same niȝt
And in this cart he lieth gaping vp riȝt
I crie vpon the ministres qd he
That schuld rule and kepe this citee
Harrow allas here lieth my felaw slayn
What shall I more vnto this sayn
The people vp sterte and cast the cart to the ground
And in the middel of the donge thei founde
This dede man that murdred was all newe
O blisfull god that art iuste and true
Loo hou thou bewreiest murdre all wey
Murdre will out that se we day be day
Murdre is al waltsom and alabhominable
To god that is so iuste and resonable
That he wil nouȝt suffred it heled be
Thouȝ it a bide a yere or ij or three
Murdre wil out that is my conclusioıı̄un Chauntecler ~
And riȝt anon ministres of the toun
Haue hent the carter and sore him pyned
And eke the hostiler so sore engyned
That thei beknewe her wickidnesse anon
And were hanged by the necke bon
Here may men see that dremes ben to drede
And certes in the same book I rede
Riȝt in the next Chapitre aftir this
I gabbe not so haue I ioye or blisse
Two men that wold haue passid ouer the see
For certein cause in to a ferre contre
If that the wynd ne had ben contrarye
That made hem in a citee for to tarie
That stood full mery vpon an hauen side
But oo day ayenst the euen tide
The wynde gan chaᵘnge and blowe as hem lest
Ioly and glad thei wenten vnto rest
And casten hem full erly for to seile
But herken hou that a man fille in gret pereill
That oon of hem in sleping as he lay
Him mette a wondre dreem agein the day
Him thouȝt a man stode be his beddis side
And him cōmmaunded that he shuld a bide
And saide him thus if thou to morwe wende
Thou shalt be dreynt my tale is at an ende
He woke and tolde his felawes what he mette
And praied hem his viage for to lette
As for that day he preid for to a bide
His felaw that lay by his beddis side
Gan for to laugh and scorned him full faste
No dreem qd he makith so myn hert agast
That I will lette for to do my thinges
I set nouȝt a straw be thi dremynges
For sweuenes ben but vanitees and iapes Pertelote ~
Men dreme all day of oules and apes
And of many a mase ther with all
Men dreme of thinges that neuer was ne neuer shall
But sith I see that thou wilt here abide
And thus forsleuthen welfully thi tide
God wot it reweth me and haue good day
And thus he toke his leue and went his way
But or that he had half his cours I seiled
Note I not whi ne what mischaunce it eiled
But casuelly the shippes botme rent
And ship and man vnder the water went
In siȝt of othir shippes him beside
That with him sailed at the same tide
And therfor faire Pertelote so dere
By such ensamples olde maist thou lere
That noman shuld be to recheles
Of dremes for I say douteles
That many a dreme full sore is for to drede
Loo in the lif of seint kenelme I rede
That was kenelphus sone the noble king
Of mercurik hou kenelme mette a thing
A litel or he was murdred on a day
His murdre in his a visioıı̄un he say
His norice him expouned eueridell
His sweuene / and for to kepen him well
Fro tresoıı̄un but he was but vij yere olde
And therfor litill tale hath he tolde
Of eny dreme so holi was his herte
By god I had leuer than my sherte
That ye had red his legende as haue I
Dame Pertelote I sey you truly
Macrobeus that writeth the a visioıı̄un
In Affryk with the worthi Ciprioıı̄un
Affermeth dremes and seith that thei ben Chauntecler ~
Warnyng of thinges that men aftir seen
And furthermore I pray you loke well
The olde testament of Daniell
Yef ye holde dremes any vanite
Rede eke of Ioseph and othir shul ye see
Whethir dremes ben som tyme I sey nat all
Warnyng of thinges that shall aftir fall
Loke of Egipte the king Daun Pharaoo
His boteler and his baker also
Whethir thei ne felte non effect in dremes
Who so will seke Octy of sondry realmes
May rede of dremes many a wondir thing
Loo Cresus which that was of lide king
Mette he nat that he sat vpon a tree
Which signified that he shuld hanged be
Loo here Andromacha Ectores wif
That day that Ector shulde lese his lif
She dremed on the same niȝt beforn
Hou that the lif of Ector shulde be lorn
Yef thilke day he were hent in bataile
She warned him but it miȝt not auaile
He went for to fiȝt natheles
But he was slayn of oon Achilles
But thilke tale is longe to telle
And it is nere day I may no lenger dwelle
Truli I say as for conclusion
That I shall haue of this a vision
Aduersitees and I further sey more
That I ne telle of laxatiue no store
For thei ben venymous I wot it well
I hem defie I loue hem neuer a dele
Now let us speke of mirthe and leue all this
Madame Pertelote so haue I blisse
Of oo thing god sent me hath large grace Pertelote ~
For when I see your beaute of your face
Ye ben so scarlet rede abouten your yen
Hit makith all my drede for to dyen
For as siker as is in principio
Mulier est hominis confusio
Madame this sentence of this latyn is
Wommām his manes ioye and his blisse
For whan I fele a niȝt youre soft side
Al be it that I may not on you ride
For that your perche is maked narwe allas
I am so full of ioye and solace
That I defie bothe sweuene and dreem
And with that word he fley doun from the beme
For it was day and eke his hennes alle
And with a clokkyng he gan hem calle
For he had found a corne lye in the yerde
Riall he was and namore a ferde
He fethered Pertelote . xxty tyme
And trade as ofte or it were pryme
He loketh as it were a grym lyoıı̄un
And on his toes he loketh vp and doun
Him deynes not to sette his fete to ground
And clokkith whan he hath a corne I founde
And to him than ran his wyues alle
Thus riall as a prince in his halle
Leue I this Chaunteclere in his pasture
And aftir will I telle his aduenture
Whan the month in which the world began
That hiȝt Marche that god first made man
Was complet and passed were also
Synnes Marche began xxxty daies and two
Bifell that Chaunteclere in all his pride
His vij wyues walkyng be his side
Cast vp his yen to the briȝt sonne Chaıı̄untecler ~
That in the signe of Taurus had I ronne
Twenty degrees and oon and somdel more
He knewe be kynde and be subtill lore
That his prime he kreew with blisfull steuene
The sonne he seide is clomben vpon heuene
Twenty degrees and oon and more I wis
Madame Pertelote my worldeles blisse
Herke these blisfull birdes hou thei singe
And se the fressh floures hou thei springe
Full is myn herte of reuel and of solace
But sodeinly him fel a sorwefull case
For euer // ende the // latter of ioye is woo
God wot that wordly ioye is sone a goo
And if a retorik that can faire endite
In a cronicle saufly miȝt it write
As for a souerain notabilite
Now eueri wise man now let him herkene me
This story is also trewe I vndertake
As is the book of launcelet de lake
That wommen helde in full gret reuerence
Now wol I torne agein to my sentence
A Colefox full of sleithe and iniquite
That in the groue had woned yeres three
By his Imaginacioıı̄un aforn cast
The same niȝt throuȝ the hegge brast
In to the yerd ther Chaunteclere the faire
Was wonte and eke his wyues to repaire
And in bedde of wortes stille he lay
Till it was passed vndren of the day
Waiting his tyme on Chaunteclere to falle
As gladly doon theȝ homicides alle
That in awaite liggeth to murdre men
O false murderer lorkyng in thi den
O now scariot oo now genylounye Chauntecler ~
False dissimuloᵘur o gret Symonie
That brouȝtest Troye all outerly to sorwe
O Chaunteclere o cursed be that morwe
That thou in to the yerd fly fro the bemes
Thou were full warned by thi dremes
That thilke day was perlous to the
But that god woll mot nedes be
Aftir the opinioıı̄un of certain clerkes
Witnesse on him that any good clerk is
That in scole is gret altercacioıı̄un
In this case and gret disputacioıı̄un
And hath ben of an C . Mˢ . men
But I ne can bulte it to the bren
As can the holi doctour Augustyn
Or boecy or the busshop Bradwyn
Whethir that god for witing
Streyneth me nedely to do a thing
Nedeli clepe I necessite
Or if the free choise be graunted me
To do that same thing or to do it nouȝt
For god wot it or I was wrouȝt
Or of this weting streineth neuer a dele
But by necessite condicionell
I will not haue to do of such matere
My tale is of a Cok as ye may here
That toke his counseill of his wif with sorwe
To walke in the yerde vpon a morwe
That he had met the dreme that I you tolde
Wommans counsaill ben full ofte colde
Wommans counsaill brouȝt us first to woo
And made Adam from Paradis to go
Ther as he was full mery and wel at ese
But for I wol nat wommen in no thing displese
Yef I counceill of hem wolde blame Chaıı̄untecler ~
Passe ouer for I seid it in my game
Rede auctors where thei trete of such matere
And what thei sey of wommen here
These ben the bokes wordes and not myn
I can non harme of no womman deuyne
Faire in the sond to bathe her merily
Lyth Pertelote and all here susteris by
Ayen the sonne Chaunteclere so free
Songe merier than the mere maiden in the see
For phisiliogus saith witterly
Hou that thei singen wel and merily
And so befell o hou that he cast his ye
Among the wortes vpon a botterflie
He was ware of the fox that lay full lowe
No thing lust him than for to crowe
And cried oon Cok . Cok and vp he sterte
As a man that affraied were in his herte
For naturelly a beest desireth to flee
From his contrary if he may it see
Thouȝ he neuer est had seyn it with his ye
This Chauntecler whan he gan him spie
He wold a fled but the fox anon
Seide gentill sir allas whither will ye goon
Be ye affraied of me that am your frende
Now certes I were worse than a fende
If I to you wolde harme or vilanye
I am not comen your counseill to aspie
But truly the cause of my comyng
Was for to herken hou that ye syng
For truly ye haue as mery a steuene
As any aungell hath that is in heuene
Ther with ye haue in musik more feling
Than had Boys or any othir that can singe
My lord your fader god his soule blisse Chauntecler ~
And eke your moder of her gentilnesse
Han in my house I ben to me gret ese
And certes sir full fayn wol I you plese
But for men spekith of singing I will sey
So mote I wel brouken myn yen twey
Saue you I ne herde neuer man singe
As did your fader in the mornyng
Certes it was of hert all that he songe
And for to make his voice more strong
He wold so peynen him that with bothe his yen
He most winken so loude he wolde cryen
And stonde vpon his tiptoon ther with all
And strecchid forth his necke that was small
And eke he was of such discrecioıı̄un
That ther no was man in the regioıı̄un
That him in his song or wisdam miȝt passe
Yeu woll radde in daun thare asse
Among his verse ther was a Cok
For a prestis sone yaf him a cnok
Vpon his legges whiles he was yong and nise
He made him for to lese his benefice
But certein there is non comparisoıı̄un
Bytwix the wisdam and discressioıı̄un
Of your fader and of his subtilitee
Now singeth sir for seint Charite
Late se conne ye your fadir counterfete
This Chauntecler his wenges gan bete
As man that coude nat this treson nat aspie
So was he rauisshed with his flaterie
¶ Allas ye lordes many a false flatour
Is in your court and many a losengoure
To plesen you more by my feith
Than he that sothfastnesse to you saith
Redeth Ecclesiastre of flaterie Chauntecler ~
Be war ye lordes of here treccherie
This Chauntecler stode hiȝe vpon his toes
Strecching his necke and hielde his yen close
And gan to crowe loude for the nones
And Daun Russell stert vp at ones
And by the gargate he hent Chauntecler
And on his bak toward the wode him bere
For yet was ther no man that it him shewid
O desteny maist thou nat be eschewid
Allas that Chaunteclere fill from the bemes
Allas his wif ne thouȝt on dremes
And on a friday fill all this mischaᵘnce
O venus that art goddesse of plesaunce
Sethenes that thi seruaunt was Chaunteclere
And in thi seruice did all his power
More for delite than the world to multiplie
Whi woldest thou suffre him on thi day to dye
O gaufred dere maistir souerain
That whan thi worthi king Richard was slayn
Whi ne haddest thou compleyned his deth so sore
Whi ne had I now thi sentence and thi lore
The friday for to chiden as dide ye
For on a friday sothely slayn was he
Than woll I shewe you hou that I coude pleyne
For Chauntecleres loue and for his peyne
Certes such crye ne lamentacioıı̄un
As the ladyes whan ylioıı̄un
And whan Pirous with his streite swerde
Hent kyng Pryom by the berd
And slowe him as seith Enides
Made neuer as the hennes in the close
Whan thei had sey of Chaunteclere this siȝt
But souereinly Dame Pertelote shriȝt
Well louder than did Hastrubaldes wif Chauntecler ~
Whan that her husbond had lost his lif
And that romayns had brent cartage
She was so full of torment and of rage
That welfully in to the fire she stert
And brent her self with a stedfast hert
O wofull hennes riȝt so criden ye
As whan that Nero brend the Citee
Of Rome crieden the senatours wyues
For that her husbondes losten her lyues
Withouten gilt this Nero hath hem slayn
Now woll I torne to my tale a gein
This seli widewe and her douȝteres two
Herden these hennes crieden and maden woo
And out at the dore stert thei anon
And sawe the fox toward the wode goon
And bare vpon his bak the Cok awey
And cried out harrow and welawey
A . ha the fox and aftir him thei ran
And eke with staues many an othir man
Ran . Collow oure dogge Talbot and Gerland
And Malkyn with a distaf in her hand
Ran cow and calf and eke the veri dogges
So ferd were for berking of the dogges
And shoutyng of the men and the wommen eke
Thei ronne so hem thouȝte here herte breke
Thei yellid as fendes doon in helle
The dogges cried as men wolde hem quelle
The gees for fere flowen ouer the trees
Out of the hyues came the swarm of bees
So hidous was the noise a Benedicite
Certes Iak straw and his mene
Ne made neuer shoutes half so shrille
Whan that they wolden any fleming kille
As thilk day was made vpon the fox Pertelot ~
Of bras thei brouȝten bemes and of box
Of horne and bone in which thei blew and pouped
And ther with all thei steked and thei houped
It semed as that heuene shuld falle
Now gode men herkenith alle
Loo hou fortune torneth sodeinly
The hope and pride eke of her enmy
This Cok that lay vpon this foxes bak
In all his drede vnto the fox he spak
And seid sir as if that I were as ye
Yet shuld I sey as wistly god helpe me
Turneth ayen ye proude cherles alle
A verry pestilence vpon you falle
Now am I come to the wodes side
Maugre your hede the Cok shall here abide
The fox answerid in feith it shall be doon
I will him ete in feith and that anon
And he spak that word all sodeinly
This Cok brak from his mouth delyuerly
And whan the fox saw that he was goon
And hiȝe vpon a tree he fly anoon
Allas qd he . A chaunteclere allas
I haue to you don qd he a trespas
In as moche as I haue maked you a ferd
Whan I you hent and brouȝt you to this yerd
But sir I did it to no wickid entent
Come a doun and I shall telle you what I ment
I shall sey soth to you god helpe me so
Nay than qd he than I shrewe us bothe ij
And first I shrewe my self bothe blood ⁊and bones
Yf thou begile me any ofter than ones
Thou shalt nomore with thi flatery
Do me to singe and winke with myn ye
For he that winketh whan that he shulde see Phisicus ~
All welfully / god let him neuer the
Nay qd the fox god yef him meschaᵘnce
That is so indiscret of gouernᵃnce
That iangeleth whan he shuld holde his pees
Loo such it is to be reccheles
And necligent and trust on flaterie
But ye that holden this tale a folie
As of a fox and of a Cok and of an henne
Takith the moralitee gode men
For seint Poule seith all that writen is
To oure doctrine it is writen I wis
Taketh the frute and let the chaf be stille
Now gode god if it be thi wille
As seith my lord so make us alle gode men
And bringe us to his hiȝe blisse Amen .

l.hi:
Here endith the Nonnes Prestes tale .
And here beginneth A tale of the Maister of Phisik

div.l: (base) ¶ Here bigynneth the Phisiciens tale
(base) THer was as telleth Titus Liuius
(base) A knyght that called was Virginius
(base) Fulfild of honour and of worthynesse
(base) And strong of freendes and of greet richesse
(base) ¶ This knyght a doghter hadde by his wif
(base) No children hadde he mo in al his lif
(base) Fair was this mayde in excellent beautee
(base) Abouen euery wight that man may see
(base) For Nature hath with souereyn diligence
(base) Yformed hire in so greet excellence
(base) As thogh she wolde seyn lo I nature
(base) Thus kan I forme and peynte a creature
(base) Whan that me list who kan me countrefete
(base) Pigmalion noght thogh he ay forge and bete

div.l: (base) Or graue or peynte for I dar wel seyn
(base) Apelles zanzis sholde werche in veyn
(base) Outher to graue or peynte or forge or bete
(base) If they presumeden me to countrefete
(base) For he that is the formere principal
(base) Hath maked me his vicaire general
(base) To forme and peynten erthely creaturis
(base) Right as me list and ech thyng in my cure is
(base) Vnder the Moone that may wane and waxe
(base) And for my werk right no thyng wol I axe
(base) My lord and I been ful of oon acord
(base) I made hire to the worship of my lord
(base) So do I alle myne othere creatures
(base) What colour that they han or what figures
(base) Thus semeth me that nature wolde seye
(base) This mayde of age twelue yeer was and tweye
(base) In which that nature hadde swich delit
(base) For right as she kan peynte a lilye whit
(base) And reed a Rose right with swich peynture
(base) She peynted hath this noble creature
(base) Er she were born vpon hir lymes free
(base) Wher as by right swiche colours sholden be
(base) And Phebus dyed hath hir tresses grete
(base) Lyk to the stremys of his burned hete
(base) And if that excellent was hir beautee
(base) A thousand fold moore vertuous was she
(base) In hire ne lakked no condicioun
(base) That is to preyse as by discrecioun
(base) As wel in goost as body chaast was she
(base) For which she floured in virginitee
(base) With all humilitee and abstinence
(base) With all atemperance and pacience
(base) With mesure eek of beryng and array
(base) Discreet she was in answeryng alway

div.l: (base) Thogh she were wise Pallas dar I seyn
(base) Hir facound eek ful wommanly and pleyn
(base) No countrefeted termes hadde she
(base) To seme wys but after hir degree

(base) My throte is kit vnto my nekke boon
(base) Seyde this child and as by wey of kynde
(base) I sholde haue dyed ye longe tyme agoon
(base) But Ihu crist as ye in bokes fynde
(base) Wol that his glorie laste and be in mynde
(base) And for the worship of his moder deere
(base) Yet may I synge O alma loude and clere
(base) This welle of mercy Cristes moder swete
(base) I loued alwey as after my konnynge
(base) And whan that I my lyf sholde forlete
(base) To me she cam and bad me for to synge
(base) This Antheme verraily in my deiynge
(base) As ye han herd and whan that I had songe
(base) Me thoughte she leyde a greyn vpon my tonge
(base) Wher fore I synge and synge moot certeyn
(base) In honour of that blisful mayden free

And here beginneth the Prolog of the Marchᵃunt

div.l: Of dyuers aduentures maden layes
Renyng her first britoıı̄un tonge
Which layes with her instrumentez songe Arueragus
Or ellis redden hem for her plesaunce
And one of hem I haue in remembrᵃunce
Which I shall sey with gode will as I can
But sires be cause I am a borell man
At my begynnyng first I you beseche
Haue me excused of my rude speche
I lerned neuer retorik certein
Thing that I speke it mote be bare and pleyn
I slept neuer vpon the mount of Pernaso
Ne lerned neuer Marcus Tulius Scithero
Colours ne knowe I non withouten drede
But such colours as growen in the mede
Orellis suche as men dye or peynte
Colours of retorik ben so queynte
My spirit feleth nouȝt of such matere
But if ye list my tale ye may here .

Here endith the Prolog of the Marchaunt
And here beginneth his tale folwing
