div.l: Ther was a kniȝt that loued and did his payne
And many a labour and many a gret emprise
To serue a lady in his best wise
He for his lady wrouȝt or she was wonne
For she was on the fairest vnder the sonne
And eke therto come of so hiȝe kynrede
That wel vnnethe dorst this kniȝt for drede
Telle her his woo and his distresse
But at the last she for his worthinesse
And namely for his meke obeissaunce
Hath such pitee cauȝt for his penᵃnce Arueragus .
That priuely she fel of his accord
To take him for her husbond and her a lord
Of such lordship as men han ouer her wyues
And for to lede the more in blisse her lyues
Of his free will swor he as a kniȝt
That neuer in all his lif be day ne niȝt
Ne shulde vpon him take no maistrie
Ageins her will ne kithe her ielousye
But to her obeie and folwe her will in all
As any louer to his lady shall
Saue that the name of souereynte
That wolde he haue for shame of his degree
She thankid him and with gret humblesse
She seide sir sith of your gentilnesse
Ye profre me to haue so large a reyne
Ne wold neuer god bitwix us tweyne
As in my gilt were eithir woo or strif
Sir I will be your humble trewe wif
Haue here my trouthe till that myn herte breste
Thus beth thei bothe in quiete and in reste
But oo thing sires safly dar I sey
That frendes eueri to othir must obeie
If thei will longe holde company
Loue will nat be constreyned be maistry
Whan mastrie cometh the god of loue anon
Beteth the wynges and farwel he is goon
Loue is a thing as any spirit free
Wommen of kynde desiren liberte
And nat to be constreyned as a thrall
And so don men if the soth seyn shall
Loke that who most pacienty is in loue
He is at his auauntage al a boue
Pacience is an hiȝe vertu certeyn
For it venquesseth as this clerkes seyn Dorigen .
Thinges that rigour shulde neuer atteyne
And of ech aduersite no wisdam is to compleyne
Lerneth to suffre orellis so mote I goon
Ye shull it lerne whedir ye will or noon
For in this world certein there no wiȝt is
That he ne doth or seith somtyme amys
Ire sekenesse or constellacioıı̄un
Wyn woo or chᵃunging of complexiou
Causeth full ofte to do amys or speken
On eueri wrong a man may not be wreken
Aftir the tyme most be temꝑper/paraunce
To eueri wiȝt that can discret gouernᵃunce
And therfor hath this worthi wise kniȝt
To lyue in ese sufferaunce he be hiȝt
And she to him ful wisely began to swere
That neuer shulde ther be defaute in here
Here may men see in humble wise accord
Thus hath she take her husbond and here lord
Seruᵃnt in loue and lord in mariage
Then was he bothe in lordship and seruage
Seruage nay but in lordship a boue
Sith he hath bothe his lady and his loue
His lady certes and his wif also
The which that lawe of loue accordeth to
And whan he was in his prosperite
Home with his wif he goth to his contre
Nat fer fro Pepinark there his dwelling was
Where as he liueth in blisse and in solas .
¶ Who coude telle but if he had weddid be
The ioye the ese and the prosperite
That is betwix an husbond and a wif
A yere and more lastid this blisful lif
Till that this kniȝt of which I speke of thus
That of Caired was cleped Arueragus Arueragus .
Shope him to go and dwelle a yere or tweyne
In Engelond that clepid was Britayne
To seke in armes worship and honoᵘur
For alle his lust he sette in such labour
And dwellid there ij yere the boke seith thus
Now will I stynte of this Arueragus
And speke I wol of Dorigen his wif
That loueth her husbond as her hertes lif
For his absence wepith she and siketh
As don these noble wyues whan hem liketh
She morneth waketh waileth fasteth pleyneth
Desire of his presence her so distreyneth
That all this wilde worlde she set at nouȝt
Here frendes which that knewe her heuy thouȝt
Conforten here in all that euer they may
Thei prechen her thei tellen her niȝt and day
That causeles she sleeth her self allas
And eueri comfort possible in this case
Thei done to her all her besinesse
Al for to make her lete her heuinesse
By processe as ye knowen euerichoıı̄un
Men may so longe graue in a ston
Till som figure there yn emprentid be
So longe han thei conforted her til she
Receyued hath by hope and by resoıı̄un
The emprentyng of here consolacioıı̄un
Throuȝ which her gret sorwe gan aswage
She may not alwey dure in such rage
And eke Arueragus in all her care
Hath sent her letteres home of all his welfare
And that he wil come hasteli ayen
Orellis had this sorwe her herte slayn
Her frendes saw her sorwe gan to slake
And praied her on knees for goddes sake Dorigen .
To come and romen her in companye
Awey to dryue her derke fantasy
And finally she graunted that request
For wel she say that it was for the beste
Now stode her Castell fast by the see
And often with her frendes walkid she
Here to disport vpon the banke an high
Where as she many a ship and barge seigh
Sayling here course where as thei list to goo
But yet was that A parcell of her woo
For to her self full ofte allas seith she
Is there no ship of so many as I see
Woll bringe my lord home than were myn herte
All warisshed of this peynes smerte
Anothir tyme she wold sitte and thinke
And cast her yen dounward from the brynke
And whan she sy the grisly rokkes blake
For verry fere so wolde here herte quake
That on her fete she miȝt nat her susteyne
Than wolde she sitte vpon the grene
And pitously in to the see beholde
And seith riȝt thus with sorweful sikes colde
Eterne god that throuȝ thi purueyaunce
Ledest the world by certein gouernᵃnce
In ydell as men seyn ye nothing make
But lorde these grisely fendely rokkes blake
That semen rather a foule confusioıı̄un
Of werke than any faire creacioıı̄un
Of such a parfiȝt wise god and a stable
Why han ye wrouȝt this werk vnresonable
For by this werk South . North . West ne Est
There nys I fostred man . brid ne beste
No gode to my wit but annoyeth
Se ye nat lord hou mankynde it distroieth Arueragus .
An hundred thousand bodyes of mankynde
Han these rokkes slayn al be thei nouȝt in mynde
Which mankynde is so faire parte of thi werk
That thou it madest like to thine owne merke
Than semed it ye had a gret charite
Toward Mankynde but hou than may it be
That ye than make such menes it to distroye
Which menes do no good but euer annoye
I wot wel clerkes wol sayn as hem leste
By argumentez that all is for the beste
Thouȝ I ne can the causes not I knowe
But thilke god that made wynd to blowe
As kepe my lord this is my conclusioıı̄un
To clerkes lete I all disputacioıı̄un
But wolde god that alle these rokkes blake
Were sonken in to helle for his sake
Thus wolde she sey with many a pitous tere
These rokkes sleen myn herte riȝt for fere
Her frendes saw that it was no disport
To rome by the see but discomfort
And shopen hem to pley som wher elles
Thei leden here by reuers and by welles
And eke in othir places delectables
They dauncen and pleyen at chesse and tables
So on a day riȝt in the morwe tide
Vnto A gardyn that was ther be side
In which that thei had made her ordenᵃnce
Of vitaile and of othir purueiaunce
Thei goon and pleyn hem all the long day
And this was on the vjte morwen fof May
Which had peinted with his softe shoures
This gardyn full of leues and of floures
And craft of mannys hand so curiously
Arraied had this gardyn truly Aurelius .
That neuer was there gardyn of such price
But it were the verri Paradise
The odour of floures and the fressh siȝt
Wolde han made any hertes liȝt
That euer was born but if so gret sekenesse
Or to gret sorwe helde it in distresse
So full it was of beaute with plesaunce
And aftir dyner gan thei to daunce
And songen also saue Dorigen allone
Which made alwey her compleynt and her mone
For she ne say him on the daunce goo
That was her husbond and her loue also
But natheles she must a tyme a bide
And with gode hope let her sorwe slide
Vpon this daunce among othir men
Daunced a squier befor Dorigen
That fressher was and iolier of array
As to my dome than is the moneth of May
He singeth daunceth passing eny man
That is or was sithe that the world began
Ther with he was if men shuld discryue
Oon of the best faryng men on lyue
Yonge strong riȝt vertuous riche and wise
And wel beloued and holden in gret price
And shortely if the soth telle I shal
Vnwiting of this Dorigen at all
This lusti squier seruᵃnt vnto venus
Which that clepid was Aurelius
Had loued her best of any creature
But neuer dorst he telle his greuᵃnce
Two yere and more as was his aduenture
Withouten cuppe he drank all his penᵃnce
He was appaired ne no thing wolde he pleie
Saue in his songes somdel wold he seye Aurelius .
His woo as in general compleyning
He seid he loued and was biloued no thing
Of such mater made he many layes
Songes compleyntes roundeles virelayes
How that he dorst nat his sorwe telle
But languissheth as a fire doth in helle
And die he must he seid as did Ekko
For Narsisus dorst nat telle his woo
In othir maner than ye here me seye
Ne durst not to here his owne woo bewreie
Saue that paraduenture som tyme at daunces
Ther yong folk kepen her obseruᵃnces
It may wel be he loked on her face
In such a wise as men that axen grace
But no thing wist she of his entent
But natheles it happid so or that thei went
Be cause that he was hir neiȝboᵘur
And was A man of wurship and honoᵘur
And had I knowen him of tyme yore
Thei fil in speche and further more and more
Vnto his purpos fill Aurelius
And whan he saw his tyme he said thus
Madame qd he be god that this world made
So that I wist I miȝt your herte glade
I wolde that day that your lord Arueragus
Went ouer the see that I Aurelius
Had went ther neuer I shuld come agein
For wel I wot my seruice is in veyn
My guerdoıı̄un is but bresting of myn herte
Madame rewe vpon my peynes smerte
For with oo wurd ye may me slee or saue
Here at youre feet god wold that I were graue
I ne haue as now no leiser for to sey
Haue mercy on me swete or ye will do me deye Dorigen .
She gan to loke vpon Aurelius
Is this your will qd she and sey ye thus
Neuer arst qd she ne wist I what ye ment
But now Aurely I knowe your entent
By thilke god that yaf me soule and lif
Ne shal I neuer be an vntrewe wif
In word ne werk as fer as I haue wit
I will ben his to whom I am knyt
Take this for a small answere as of me
But aftir that I pleyn thus qd she
Aurely qd she be hiȝe god aboue
Yet woll I graunte you to be your loue
Syn that I see you so pitously compleyne
Loke what day that Britayne
Ye remeue all the rokkes stone by stone
That they ne lette ship ne bote gone
I sey whan ye haue made the coste so clene
Of rokkes that ther nys no stone I sene
Than woll I loue you best of any man
Haue here my trouth in all that euer I can
For well I wot that it shall neuer be tide
Lete such foly out of your herte slide
What deynte shuld a man haue in his lif
For to loue an othir māmnys wif
That her body whan so that him liketh
Aurelius full ofte sore siketh
Is there non othir grace in you qd he
No by that lord qd she that makid me
Woo was Aurely whan that he this herde
And with a sorwefull hert he thus answerd
Madame qd this were an impossible
Than mot I die a sodein deth horrible
And with that word he torned anoon
Tho come her othir frendes many oon Aurelius .
And in the Alleyes romed vp and doun
And no thing wist of this conclusioıı̄un
But sodeinly began to reuele newe
Till that the briȝt sonne lost his hewe
For the horisolnte hath be reft his sonne the liȝt
This is as moch to say that it was niȝt
And home thei gone in ioye and in solace
Saue oonly wrecchid Aurelius Allas
He to his hous goth with sorwefull herte
He seith he may not from his deth a sterte
Him semed that he felt his herte colde
Vp to heuene his handes he gan holde
And on his knees bare he set him doun
And in his rauyng saide his Orisoun
For verry woo oute of his witte he braide
He nist what he said but thus he praied
With pitous herte his pleynt hath he begonne
Vnto the goddes and furst vnto the sonne
He seide Apollo god and gouernour
Of eueri planete herbe tree and flour
That yeuest aftir thi conclusioıı̄un
To eche of hem his tyme and his sesoıı̄un
And thine herberugh chaungeth lowe and high
Lord Phebus cast thi merciable ye
On wrecchid Aurely which that am but lorn
Loo lord my lady hath my deth I sworn
Withouten gilt but thi benignite
Vpon my dedely hert haue som pitee
But well I wot lord Phebus if you lest
Ye may me helpen for ye may best
Now vouchesaf that I may you deuise
How that I may be holpe and in what wise
Youre blisfull sustir lucina luna the shene
That of the see is chief goddesse and quene Dorigen .
Thouȝ Neptunus haue depthe in the see
Yet Emꝑper/paresse abouen him is she
Ye knowe wel lord that riȝt as luna the dere
Is to be quyked and liȝted of your fire
For which she folweth you ful besily
Riȝt so the see desireth naturelly
To folwen her as she that is goddesse
Bothe in the see and reuers more and lesse
Wherfor lord Phebus this is my request
Do this miracle or do myn herte brest
That now next at this opposicioıı̄un
Which in the signe shal be of the lyoıı̄un
As preieth her so gret a flood to bringe
That . v . fadme at the lest it ouer springe
The hiȝest rokke in Armorik Britayne
And let this endure daies twayne
Than certes to my lady may I sey
Holdeth your hest the rokkes arn awey
Lorde Phebus doth this miracle for me
Pray her she go no faster course than ye
I sey this preieth your sustir that she goo
No faster course than ye this yeres twoo
Than shall ye ben at fulle euyn alway
And spring flood last bothe niȝt and day
And but she vouchesaf in this maner
To graunte me souerain lady dere
Prey here to synkyn eueri rokke a doun
In to her owne derke regioıı̄un
Vnder the ground there Pluto dwellith ynne
Or neuer mo shall I my lady wynne
Thi temple in Darphos wol I barfoot seke
Lord Phebus on the teres on my cheke
And of my peyne haue som compassioıı̄un
And with that word in swoune he fill adoun Arueragus .
And long tyme he lay forth in a traunce
His brothir which that knewe of his penᵃnce
Vp cauȝt him and to bedde hath him brouȝt
Dispeired in this torment and this thouȝt
Let I this woful creature lye
Chese he for me whethir he will lyue or dye
¶ Arueragus with hele and gret honoᵘur
As he that was of chiualrie the flour
Is come home and othir worthi men
O blisfull art thou now Dorigen
That hast thi lusti husbond in thine armes
The fressh kniȝt the worthi man of Armes
That loueth the as his hertes lif
No thing list him to be Imaginatif
If any wiȝt had spoke whiles he was oute
To here of loue therof had he no doute
He nouȝt entendeth to such matere
But daunceth iusteth and maketh her gode chiere
And thus in ioye and blisse I let hem dwelle
Of the seke Aurelius woll I telle
In languor and in torment furiouse
Two yere and more lay this wrecchid Aurelius
Or ony on erthe he miȝt goon
Ne comforte in this tyme had he non
Saue of his brothir which that was A Clerc
He knewe of all this woo and al this werk
For to non othir creature certeyn
Of this mater he dorst no wurd seyn
Vnder his breest he bare it more secree
Than euer did Pamfilus and Galathe
His brest was hole withouten for to sene
But in his herte ay was the arwe kene
And wel ye knowe that of a sursanure
In surgery is ꝑper/parilous the cure Dorigen .
But men miȝt touche the Arwe or come therby
His brothir wepith and waileth priuely
Till at the last he fill in remembrᵃunce
That whiles he was at Orliaunce in Fraunce
An C . clerkes yonge that ben likerous
To reden artes that ben curious
Seken in eueri halk and in eueri herne
Particuler science for to lerne
He him remembred that vpon a day
At Orliaunce in study a boke he say
Of magik naturel which his felaw
That was that tyme A Bachiller of lawe
Al were he there to lerne an othir craft
Had priuely vpon his dexte I lefte
Which book spak moch of the oꝑper/paracions
Touching the xxviijty mansions
That longen to the mone and such foly
As in oure daies is nouȝt worth A. flie
For holi chirche feith in oure beleue
Ne suffreth non illusioıı̄un vs to greue
And whan this boke was in his remēmbraunce
Anon for ioye his herte gan to daunce
And to him self he seid priuely
My brothir shall be holpen hastily
For I am siker that there be sciences
By which men make gret apparences
Such as thez subtill tregetours pley
Full ofte at festes haue I herd men sey
That Tregetours wit in an halle large
Haue made comen yn a water and a barge
And in the halle rowen vp and doun
Som tyme semed ther cometh a grym lyoıı̄un
And somtyme floures springing in a mede
Som tyme A vyne of grapes white and rede Arueragus .
Some tyme A castell al of lyme and ston
And whan hem liked auoided it anon
Thus semed it to eueri māmnes siȝt
Now than conclude I thus if that I miȝt
At Orliaunce som olde felaw fynde
That hath thez moneth mansions in his mynde
Or othir Magik naturel aboue
He shuld wel make my Brothir haue his loue
For with an apparence A clerk miȝt make
To māmnes siȝt that all the rokkes blake
Of britayne were I voided euerichoıı̄un
And shippes by the brinke come and goon
And in such forme endure a day or two
Than were my brothir warisshed of his woo
Than most she nedes holden here heste
Orellis he shal shame her at the leste
What shuld I make a lenger tale of this
Vnto his brotheres bed I comen he is
And such comfort he gaf him for to goon
To Orliaunce that he vp stert anon
And on his wey than onward is he fare
In hope to ben lessid of his care
Whan thei were come almost to that citee
But if it were a two forlong or three
A yong clerc romyng by him self thei mette
Which that in latyn thriftely thei grette
And aftir that he seide a wondir thing
I knowe the cause qd he of your comyng
And or thei further any fote wente
He tolde hem all that was in here entent
This Britoıı̄un clerk asked him of felawes
The which that he had knowen in olde dawes
And he answerid him that thei dede were
For which he wepte ful many a tere Aurelius .
Doun from his hors Aurelius liȝt anon
And with the Magicien forth is he goon
Home till his house and made hem wel at ese
Hem lakkid no vitaile that miȝt hem plese
So well arraied house as there was oon
Aurelius in his lif say neuer non
He shewed hem or thei went to soper
Forestes Parkes ful of wilde dere
Ther saw he hertes with hornes hye
The grettest that euer were seyn with ye
He say of hem an C . slayn with houndes
And some with Arwes blede with bitter woundes
He saw whan voided were this wilde dere
This fauconers vpon A faire ryuer
That with her haukes han the heron hent
Tho say he kniȝtes iuste verrament
And aftir this he did him such plesaunce
That he him shewid his lady on a daunce
On which he daunced him self as he thouȝt
And whan this maistre that this Magik wrouȝt
Saw it was tyme he clapt his handes too
And farewell al oure reuel was a goo
And yet remeued thei neuer out of the hous
Whil thei sey all this siȝt merueilous
But in his stody where as his bokes be
Thei seten stille and no wiȝt but thei thre
To him this mastir callid his squier
And seide him thus is redy oure soper
Almost an houre it is I vndertake
Sith I you bad oure soper for to make
Whan thes worthi men went with me
In to my studie where as my bokes be
Sir qd this squier whan it liketh you
It is al redy thouȝ ye wol riȝt now Aurelius .
